headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conferen
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer;
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice President's of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. 
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record $4.8 billion. We opened
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record $4.8 billion. We opened 3 stores, including our first store in Huntsville Alabama, a new flagship store in downtown Los Angeles. For the quarter, comp store sales declined 1.8% against the 4.7% increase in the prior year. In addition to headwinds from a tougher comparison and a highly competitive environment, the negative impact from cannibalization increased for the third consecutive quarter. 
We continue to be a destination for the holidays, with comps for Thanksgiving and Christmas week showing a nice lift over prior run rates. For the first 5 to -- from the first 5 to the last 11 weeks of the quarter, traffic and basket trends on both the 1- and 2-year basis showed improvement. We stepped up our value offerings to customers, primarily through more and deeper promotions, such as our customer appreciation Love Fest and 3-day sale and supplements, which were supported through social media, digital ads and select radio ads. Over the remainder of the year, we plan to continue our promotional strategy, including more personalized offers and increase and broaden our price investments as well.
Cost savings and SG&A, primarily salaries and benefits, were more than offset by investments in value and technology as well as deleverage in areas such as occupancy and depreciation, resulting in a 58 basis point decline in OM. We produced an 8.3% EBITDA margin, $0.46 in diluted earnings per share, $53 million in free cash flow and a 14% adjusted return on invested capital. 
In keeping with our new capital allocation strategy, we returned $679 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.4 billion in total available capital and $1. billion in total debt. 
Last quarter, we outlined our 9-point plan to fundamentally evolve the business, including active steps to improve our price perception and further differentiate and enhance our shopping experience. We're on track with that plan and would like to share some highlights of the progress we're making in several areas.
We continue to open innovative retail stores such as our downtown L.A. store, which broke regional records for opening-day and first-day sales and its first week sales and has already established itself as a full service grocery store and culinary destination. Featuring exciting venues such as the Claim Chef second outpost and our very own 8 [ph] bar, offering daily specials brunch as well as signature craft cocktails and beers. This store offers a fun and compelling in-store experience and is representative of how we continue to evolve for our customers. 
We welcome, who is our Global Vice President of Culinary and Hospitality. Tim has worked with some of the most recognized chefs and hotel brands in the world, and we look forward to his leadership in elevating our $3 billion prepared foods and bakery business to an even higher standard. 
Our Exclusive Brand sales increased to over $725 million or 15% of total sales, 150 basis point increase over the prior year. Notable product launches over the past year include a collection of bodycare products for babies, organic Greek yogurt, animal welfare-rated organic slice deli meats and an expanded assortment of seasonal and holiday items. 
Our Instacart sales continue to grow nicely, and we now offer delivery in 16 markets with many stores seeing sales as a percentage of total store in the mid- to high single digits and several stores averaging baskets over $100. We are in the process of expanding the service to more stores and several new markets this year. 
Our new labor scheduling program is now active across majority of our customer service teams. While still in the early innings, we are pleased with the labor savings we are seeing. We expect to have the program substantially in place across all U.S. customer service teams by the end of Q2 and a program to 2 additional teams in Q3. 
We are close to completing the pilot phase of our new point-of-sale system rollout, which is now being tested in select stores in 10 regions. We expect to complete the pilot phase over the next month, after which, the rollout will accelerate, and we are on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. 
In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we have accelerated the first component of our national Affinity program. We're excited to announce today the launch of digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market mobile app, expanding the functionality beyond recipes and shopping lists. Coupons have been the top request among users. And now with a simple stand at the register, preloaded digital coupons can automatically be applied to matching items in the shopper's basket. We encourage everyone to download the app today and take advantage of deep discounts on everyday staples like milk, yogurt and granola, seasonal offers like $5 off dozen Whole trade roses just in time for Valentine's Day and more. This is a win for customers, a win for us as well as we will gain actionable customer data on a national scale. Over the coming months, we will expand and improve our offers as well as launch our national digital sales flyer, bringing our customers great savings on what they love to their fingertips. 
In addition, we have committed to expanding our Affinity test to a new market in Q3, our newly designed rewards program builds one of the best elements of our initial test but with lower costs.
Finally, with 13 365 Whole Foods Market lease is now signed. We are pleased to share the opening scheduled for our first stores. We expect to open several late California in late May, Lake Oswego in Oregon in July and Bellevue, Washington in August. We invite you to check out 365 by wfm.com for a taste of what's to come. 
Turning out our updated outlook for the year. We are raising our EPS outlook to reflect our slightly better-than-expected Q1 results. We saw an improvement in traffic trends over the course of Q1. And while we have seen some negative impact from weather events in the first 3 weeks of Q2, we are hopeful that comps improve going forward as comparisons get easier and our sales-building initiatives gain traction. We note, however, that there could be some offsetting impact from a ramp up in price investments and promotions through the year. Based on our Q1 results, we now expect the year-over-year decline in operating margin for the fiscal year of up to 70 basis points, reflecting increased value efforts as the year progresses, the year-over-year decline in gross margin, excluding LIFO, in Q2 through Q4, is expected to be greater than the 86 basis point decline in Q1. We expect our gross margin investment to be partially offset by a sequential increase in SG&A leverage. And excluding $0.02 to $0.05 per share in estimated net accretion related to debt finance buybacks, we expect fiscal year EPS of $1.53 or greater or $1.07 or greater for the remainder of the year. 
In closing, we are making measurable progress in our strategic plan to fundamentally evolve our business and we'll continue to do so over the remainder of the year. We believe we have taken the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term. 
We will now take questions.

componenttextpreview: Sure. We -- in Q1, as we've mentioned, we started to -- we started ramping up our margin investment with more promos. We had a big Love Fest promo that lasted through most much of the quarter. We had a big 365 weekend promo and then a big 3-day sale in su
componenttext: Sure. We -- in Q1, as we've mentioned, we started to -- we started ramping up our margin investment with more promos. We had a big Love Fest promo that lasted through most much of the quarter. We had a big 365 weekend promo and then a big 3-day sale in supplements. And we also -- those types of promos we're going to continue. We now launched digital coupons. We're going to be really continuing to increase our promo activity throughout the year. We also started to do additional investments in premature departments in Q1. And we plan on continuing that and focusing even more in those as the rest of the year goes on. So wrapping that into the big outlook for the year just I think confirming what we're saying is that we expect the investment Q2 to Q3 to continue to be incrementally greater than we saw in Q1.

componenttextpreview: Sure. We are doing both. I mean, there are certain very important categories that we know that we need to be competitive on an everyday basis on. And so we are -- we're working to systematically identify those and move pricing on those to make sure that w
componenttext: Sure. We are doing both. I mean, there are certain very important categories that we know that we need to be competitive on an everyday basis on. And so we are -- we're working to systematically identify those and move pricing on those to make sure that we're competitive. There's a fair number with low prices on so far this year and have plans to do more as the year goes on. But we've also found that we have always been a kind our company's always had a strong high low strategy. That's what our customers respond to. And so we feel that the best way to show our customers value is to ramp up on the promotional side.

componenttext: Well, first of all, we just want to affirm that we're on track with that target we set out for ourselves. We make good progress where we expect it to be. But fair to say that the biggest bucket in there is the labor and benefits. That is the biggest expense of the company and that's where we've gotten significant improvement. As so do you want to add anything to that David or Ken.

componenttext: I will just say that one of the things that we're doing is really looking at where we can not have the service smarter service in our stores. And that is the process and also looking at the back of the house stores where areas we can streamline and create more efficiencies to consistency of practices and development of standard operating pressures in our stores and that's really where we're seeing ourselves driving the savings from a labor standpoint in the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: I would also say as we're building the labor model for the new 365 stores really lot of good lessons and we're complying them to Whole Foods Market in terms of again smarter service, just-in-time labor scheduling and we're applying those things now and realizing the savings over the course of this year and next year.

componenttext: Well, we're seeing a lot of opportunities for 365 just like our Whole Foods stores. But it's just a -- it's not necessarily by design. We're looking everywhere. And we're -- the plan is to try and cluster stores 365 where possible. And we're doing that in Southern California, but we also have leases in other isolated markets as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the country's promoting our produce, our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a group, we've kind o
componenttext: I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the country's promoting our produce, our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a group, we've kind of gone back and rethought exactly how we want to bring the brand forward. And we're starting with our efforts in promo and prices ACL outline onto the digital platforms like David and Jason were talking about. And I can see our brand campaign our future but I think we are doing work on our brand by getting our message out in these different platforms and ways and I think it'll evolve from there.

componenttext: What's different in what you're really referring to is that we haven't launched a big national television campaign. And that's been a conscious decision on our part. headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the quarter to date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast north coast has? Have you quantified that?
componenttext: On the quarter to date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast north coast has? Have you quantified that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do. Not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of
componenttext: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do. Not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of volatility within the 3-week period. We also saw the 2-year comps decelerate in the nonweather regions as well as in the weather-affected regions. So essentially, it's just too short a period of time to draw any conclusions. We have the trends from before the storms, but we don't have much information about trends after the storms. So it's difficult to do. The -- we also had the Super Bowl shift with -- from week to week although it was within the 3 weeks. So it didn't really affect the year-over-year number, but it did affect our ability to really quantify the impact of the storm. And that's why we haven't put a number to it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Well the $0.02 that we put at the bottom of the range is the accretion, the net accretion that we will have if we don't do any additional buybacks for the year and the $0.05 is if we spend the rest of the $324 million that's remaining out of the $1 billion that we borrowed. So it's just an update based on actual rates, actual timing of the bond and actual timing of the buyback so far.

componenttext: I would just say that we really don't want work on developing SOPs that we're going to launch throughout the company this year. Standard operating practices, which our focusing on a lot of production teams and high-volume teams in our stores. We also -- the work around the labor scheduling cannot understate power of that technology advancement in terms of matching up our schedule to our customer flow as well as implementing that into the other teams within the store to improve their scheduling relative to the workflow as well. So those 2 in itself are significant advancements for us in terms of streamlining and advancing the productivity in our stores.

componenttext: Also one of the things perhaps not fully appreciated is that the 365 stores are going to a leapfrog ahead on many of the practices that we will be evolving and Whole Foods Market. We can put them in. There's no culture, there's no legacy there to overcome. So we can go radical on 365 stores. And assuming those are going to work as well as the thing we do carry transformation within the mother brand Whole Foods Market. So we're proceeding as rapidly as we think it's prudent at Whole Foods Market. But with 365 stores, we won't have anything holding them back. So in some ways, we think they represent the future for Whole Foods Market will be evolving. So of course, we're going to encourage people to take a look at those doors when they're open.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: One more bucket at which we're also looking across all the functions at Whole Foods Market to see how we can do the work differently whether it's the member services or marketing or any one of the functional areas we've been doing deep dives on, thinking through how we're doing the work, where the resources are allocated where savings can be found. And as we've said to you last quarter, we're going to just fundamentally look at our business and see how we can evolve it to be eliminate redundancies and be more cost effective. And I feel like the whole company has really embraced that effort and we're making progress.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Foods Market stores are going to be they're going to be larger stores. They're going to will ha
componenttext: One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Foods Market stores are going to be they're going to be larger stores. They're going to will have a lot of innovation and there's going to be a lot of prepared foods. There's going to be a lot of exciting things about those stores. That's why when you talk about downtown Miami or downtown L.A. You're talking about fairly large stores that are really exciting fun stores to be in. With the 365 stores, opening now they're going to take the smaller footprint be very curated product mix really focused on creating value for customers, convenient quick shopping experience. So over the long run, you won't see small Whole Foods Market stores open up. That's going to be the purview of the 365. That's going to give 365 go in a lot of markets. We think the Whole Foods can't go bigger, more exciting boxes. And we're going to work for the Whole Foods Market stores to be very differentiated with a much more exciting experience than our competitors bring. So that's kind of our basic strategy. And we're working now in real estate. Now we have -- it's not going to be perfect for a while because working stores that are in the queue. But as we go through the real estate process, the smaller stores that come through real estate now are being slotted to be 365 stores. And the larger exciting stores, particularly in Irvine densely populated urban areas, are going to be Whole Foods Market. We think there's -- we got lots of growth room for both concepts and we're particularly excited to get those 365 stores open because I think people are going take very different perception of our company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi. Its A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce cost were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it's been. Looking forward to the rest of this year. We're estimat
componenttext: Hi. Its A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce cost were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it's been. Looking forward to the rest of this year. We're estimating somewhere between 1% and 2% inflation. There's -- some of the pressure that was on inflation past couple of years the drought in California seem to be easing a bit. It's been raining out there. There's good snowpack in the mountains. We've already seen prices of certain commodities like almonds and pistachios coming down. So we think it'll be a pretty moderate inflation for the rest of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We for -- and center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President under Perishables, Don Clark, of developing a category ma
componenttext: As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We for -- and center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President under Perishables, Don Clark, of developing a category management strategy that beyond what we've done here in the past. And through that strategy, we're going to be identifying -- looking carefully at all the different categories in center store and deciding where specifically strategically we want to do price investments, promotions, things like that. And we'll be doing those in very close cooperation with our suppliers. So we see that as something that will be -- we're going to be testing this year. And it'll be an emerging for us as the year goes on into next year.

componenttext: I just thought I'd remind that we don't define the competitive challenge is just a pricing challenge. We also define much more broadly with efforts to expand our digital platforms, our reach to our customers, our marketing messages all those things where we can communicate our differences and the quality. headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Acie, so I guess, you guys had a little inflation as I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business has appears deflation particularly in meat. A little inflation, they're down probably double digit. Is that kind of messages that limiting or do y
componenttext: Acie, so I guess, you guys had a little inflation as I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business has appears deflation particularly in meat. A little inflation, they're down probably double digit. Is that kind of messages that limiting or do you expect it to limit in any way your guy's ability to pass through some of this inflation with a conventional world deflating? And I know there is some sort of spread I think in the past you talk about sort of trying to maintain.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's take that shall take an example like for instance in beef. There's been the conventional commercial meat market has had seen deflation. We're not seeing as much because the unique antibiotic free meat that we sell an organic meat we sell are p
componenttext: Well, let's take that shall take an example like for instance in beef. There's been the conventional commercial meat market has had seen deflation. We're not seeing as much because the unique antibiotic free meat that we sell an organic meat we sell are pretty locked in with contracts to ensure supply. So over the course of the year, we'll see some of that ease down. But what we think is when you've got a differentiated product, you have a certain -- it's going to sell -- if you could sell it at a different price than the conventional market. I agree with you that there is a certain relationship that needs to happen. But what we see the same thing in organic we see the same thing organic produce demand is high in those categories. And so there isn't the kind of deflation in those categories that there isn't some of the conventional product categories. So everybody is paying -- everybody's affected by that. And so we don't see where we sell so much organic product that there's really deflation and there. So it does not really affecting our ability to the competitive in large categories of what -- of where we do business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conferen
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer;
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice President's of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. 
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better leverage in salaries and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. 
For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better leverage in salaries and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record $4.8 billion. We opened 3 stores, including our first store in Huntsville, Alabama, a new flagship store in downtown Los Angeles. For the quarter, comp store sales declined 1.8% against the 4.7% increase in the prior year. In addition to headwinds from a tougher comparison and a highly competitive environment, the negative impact from cannibalization increased for the third consecutive quarter. 
We continue to be a destination for the holidays, with comps for Thanksgiving and Christmas week showing a nice lift over prior run rates. For the first 5 to -- from the first 5 to the last 11 weeks of the quarter, traffic and basket trends on both the 1- and 2-year basis showed improvement. We stepped up our value offerings to customers, primarily through more and deeper promotions, such as our Customer Appreciation Love Fest and 3-day sale and supplements, which were supported through social media, digital ads and select radio ads. Over the remainder of the year, we plan to continue our promotional strategy, including more personalized offers and increase and broaden our price investments as well.
Cost savings and SG&A, primarily salaries and benefits, were more than offset by investments in value and technology as well as deleverage in areas, such as occupancy and depreciation, resulting in a 58-basis-point decline in OM. We produced an 8.3% EBITDA margin, $0.46 in diluted earnings per share, $53 million in free cash flow and a 14% adjusted return on invested capital. 
In keeping with our new capital allocation strategy, we returned $679 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.4 billion in total available capital and $1. billion in total debt. 
Last quarter, we outlined our 9-point plan to fundamentally evolve the business, including active steps to improve our price perception and further differentiate and enhance our shopping experience. We're on track with that plan and would like to share some highlights of the progress we're making in several areas.
We continue to open innovative retail stores, such as our downtown L.A. store, which broke regional records for opening-day and first-day sales and its first week sales and has already established itself as a full service grocery store and culinary destination. Featuring exciting venues such as acclaimed chef Roy Choi's second Chego outpost and our very own Eight Bar offering daily specials brunch as well as signature craft cocktails and beers. This store offers a fun and compelling in-store experience and is representative of how we continue to evolve for our customers. 
We welcome Tien Ho as our Global Vice President of Culinary and Hospitality. Tiem has worked with some of the most recognized chefs and hotel brands in the world, and we look forward to his leadership in elevating our $3 billion prepared foods and bakery business to an even higher standard. 
Our Exclusive Brands sales increased to over $725 million or 15% of total sales, 150-basis-point increase over the prior year. Notable product launches over the past year include a collection of body care products for babies, organic Greek yogurt, animal welfare-rated organic slice deli meats and an expanded assortment of seasonal and holiday items. 
Our Instacart sales continue to grow nicely, and we now offer delivery in 16 markets with many stores seeing sales as a percentage of total store in the mid- to high single digits and several stores averaging baskets over $100. We are in the process of expanding this service to more stores and several new markets this year. 
Our new labor scheduling program is now active across majority of our customer service teams. While still in the early innings, we are pleased with the labor savings we are seeing. We expect to have the program substantially in place across all U.S. customer service teams by the end of Q2 and introduce the program to 2 additional teams in Q3. 
We are close to completing the pilot phase of our new point-of-sale system rollout, which is now being tested in select stores in 10 regions. We expect to complete the pilot phase over the next month, after which the rollout will accelerate, and we are on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. 
In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we have accelerated the first component of our national Affinity program. We're excited to announce today the launch of digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market mobile app, expanding the functionality beyond recipes and shopping lists. Coupons have been the top request among users, and now with a simple stand at the register, preloaded digital coupons can automatically be applied to matching items in the shopper's basket. We encourage everyone to download the app today and take advantage of deep discounts on everyday staples like milk, yogurt and granola; seasonal offers like $5 off a dozen Whole trade roses just in time for Valentine's Day; and more. This is a win for customers, a win for us as well as we will gain actionable customer data on a national scale. Over the coming months, we will expand and improve our offers as well as launch our national digital sales flyer, bringing our customers great savings on what they love to their fingertips. 
In addition, we have committed to expanding our Affinity test to a new market in Q3. Our newly designed rewards program builds one of the best elements of our initial test but with lower costs.
Finally, with 13 365 by Whole Foods Market lease is now signed. We are pleased to share the opening schedule for our first stores. We expect to open in Silver Lake, California in late May; Lake Oswego, Oregon in July; and Bellevue, Washington in August. We invite you to check out 365 by wfm.com for a taste of what's to come. 
Turning now to our updated outlook for the year. We are raising our EPS outlook to reflect our slightly better-than-expected Q1 results. We saw an improvement in traffic trends over the course of Q1, and while we have seen some negative impact from weather events in the first 3 weeks of Q2, we are hopeful that comps improve going forward as comparisons get easier and our sales-building initiatives gain traction. We note, however, that there could be some offsetting impact from a ramp-up in price investments and promotions through the year. 
Based on our Q1 results, we now expect the year-over-year decline in operating margin for the fiscal year of up to 70 basis points, reflecting increased value efforts as the year progresses. The year-over-year decline in gross margin, excluding LIFO in Q2 through Q4, is expected to be greater than the 86-basis-point decline in Q1. We expect our gross margin investment to be partially offset by a sequential increase in SG&A leverage. And excluding $0.02 to $0.05 per share in estimated net accretion related to debt finance buybacks, we expect fiscal year EPS of $1.53 or greater or $1.07 or greater for the remainder of the year. 
In closing, we are making measurable progress on our strategic plan to fundamentally evolve our business, and we'll continue to do so over the remainder of the year. We believe we are taking the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term. 
We will now take questions.

componenttext: Sure. We are doing both. I mean, there are certain very important categories that we know that we need to be competitive on an everyday basis on, and so we're working to systematically identify those and move pricing on those to make sure that we're competitive. There's a fair number of items we could low prices on so far this year and have plans to do more as the year goes on. But we've also found that we have always been a kind of -- our company has always had a strong high/low strategy. That's what our customers respond to. And so we feel that the best way to show our customers' value is to ramp up on the promotional side.

componenttext: Well, first of all, we just want to affirm that we're on track with that target we set out for ourselves. We're making good progress where we expect it to be. So do you want to add anything to that, David or Ken?

componenttextpreview: I would just say that one of the things that we're doing is really looking at where we can not have less service. We'll have smarter service in our stores, and that is the process. And also looking at the back of the house of the stores, where are areas t
componenttext: I would just say that one of the things that we're doing is really looking at where we can not have less service. We'll have smarter service in our stores, and that is the process. And also looking at the back of the house of the stores, where are areas that we can streamline and create more efficiencies to consistency of practices and development of standard operating pressures is in our stores. And that's really where we're seeing ourselves driving the savings from a labor standpoint in the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would also say as we're building the labor model for the new 365 stores, we're learning a lot of really good lessons. And we're complying them to Whole Foods Market in terms of, again, smarter service, just-in-time labor scheduling. And we're applying t
componenttext: I would also say as we're building the labor model for the new 365 stores, we're learning a lot of really good lessons. And we're complying them to Whole Foods Market in terms of, again, smarter service, just-in-time labor scheduling. And we're applying those things now and realizing the savings over the course of this year and next year.

And I think, for us, the most exciting part is customers that are registering. So we're up 260% of folks registering us with the app. So thus far, we've gotten lots of favorable reviews. And as you might notice, if you take a look, we have both supplier-funded offers as well as Whole Foods-funded offers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just wanted to add, we also replaced our CRM, our e-mail platform. And in the last 6 months, we have doubled the number of users, registered users, on that platform to be able to -- so we'll be able to reach more customers and to reach them digital
componenttext: Yes. I just wanted to add, we also replaced our CRM, our e-mail platform. And in the last 6 months, we have doubled the number of users, registered users, on that platform to be able to -- so we'll be able to reach more customers and to reach them digitally with the messages. So these things are working in concert together.

componenttext: Question on comps for me. Prior guidance, I think called for around negative 2% in the first quarter, then flat the next 2 and then plus 3 in the fourth quarter. You did as expected in 1Q, but you've reduced the outlook for a year a little bit. So as you think about the cadence for the rest of the year, are there any quarter in particular you're, I guess, a bit less sanguine on? Or is that pacing that you talked about previously, is that still generally what you're looking for?

componenttext: But on the other hand, we did. On the other hand, we did affirm -- we affirmed our annual guidance of 3% to 5% sales growth, and we're continuing to affirm that today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay. Maybe, I'll follow-up after the call on that. One other one for me. Last year at this time, you're, I guess, in the midst of a pretty big advertising push. At the time, you were pleased with the ROI and net spend. We really haven't see
componenttext: Right, right. Okay. Maybe, I'll follow-up after the call on that. One other one for me. Last year at this time, you're, I guess, in the midst of a pretty big advertising push. At the time, you were pleased with the ROI and net spend. We really haven't seen at least, as far as I can tell, the same level of advertising sense. I'm just curious. Is the reason as simple as you're getting a better return from other investments? Or is there some other driver behind it? And I'm just curious why the campaign didn't really get sustained, or at least what I'm seeing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the countries promoting our produce and our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a grou
componenttext: Yes, I mean I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the countries promoting our produce and our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a group, we've kind of gone back and rethought exactly how we want to bring the brand forward. And we're starting with our efforts in promo and prices A.C. outlined onto the digital platforms like David and Jason were talking about, and I could see our brand campaign and our future. But I think we are doing the work on our brand by getting our message out in these different platforms and ways, and I think it'll evolve from there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's different in what you're really referring to is that we haven't launched a big national television campaign, and that's been a conscious decision on our part. It's not to say we won't do one in the future, but we decided we had better priorities or
componenttext: What's different in what you're really referring to is that we haven't launched a big national television campaign, and that's been a conscious decision on our part. It's not to say we won't do one in the future, but we decided we had better priorities or better opportunities or better strategies for trying to promote our new lower prices. And we've got our 365 launch, and we've got a lot of marketing dollars have been spent out there that perhaps not in as visible a way on a national basis.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Bill Kirk with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the quarter-to-date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast north coast have? Have you quantified that?
componenttext: On the quarter-to-date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast north coast have? Have you quantified that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do, not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of
componenttext: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do, not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of volatility within the 3-week period. We also saw the 2-year comps decelerate in the nonweather regions as well as in the weather-affected regions. So essentially, it's just too short a period of time to draw very many conclusions. We have the trends from before the storms, but we don't have much information about trends after the storms. So it's difficult to do. The -- we also had the Super Bowl shift with -- from week to week, although it was within the 3 weeks. So it didn't really affect the year-over-year number, but it did affect our ability to really quantify the impact of the storm. That's why we haven't put a number to it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the guidance, it looks like there's less accretion from the debt-funded buybacks than you had last quarter. Am I saying that right?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the guidance, it looks like there's less accretion from the debt-funded buybacks than you had last quarter. Am I saying that right?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the $0.02 that we put at the bottom of the range is the accretion, the net accretion that we will have if we don't do any additional buybacks for the year. And the $0.05 is if we spend the rest of the $324 million that's remaining out of the $1 bill
componenttext: Well, the $0.02 that we put at the bottom of the range is the accretion, the net accretion that we will have if we don't do any additional buybacks for the year. And the $0.05 is if we spend the rest of the $324 million that's remaining out of the $1 billion that we borrowed. So it's just an update based on actual rates, actual timing of the bond and actual timing of the buyback so far.

componenttext: I was hoping you could talk just a little bit -- you did a great job on extensive. Congratulations. componenttext: Well, I think we touched on a couple on labor scheduling, being that one that we outlined in the script. It's showing tremendous promise, and Ken just spoke a little bit about the efforts around relooking on how work is done. Do you want to add to that Ken?

componenttext: Standard operating procedure.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Standard operating practices, which are focusing on a lot of our production teams and high-volume teams in our stores. We also -- the work around the labor scheduling cannot underestimate the power of that technology advancement in terms of matching up ou
componenttext: Standard operating practices, which are focusing on a lot of our production teams and high-volume teams in our stores. We also -- the work around the labor scheduling cannot underestimate the power of that technology advancement in terms of matching up our schedule to our customer flow as well as implementing that into the other teams within the store to improve the scheduling relative to the workflow as well. So those 2 in itself are significant advancements for us in terms of streamlining and advancing the productivity in our stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also say that our regional Presidents have really taken a leadership position on this and are actively working on all aspects of both labor reduction and the store in large reductions and expenses through common buying on packaging and supplies.
componenttext: I'd also say that our regional Presidents have really taken a leadership position on this and are actively working on all aspects of both labor reduction and the store in large reductions and expenses through common buying on packaging and supplies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, one of the things perhaps not fully appreciated is that the 365 stores are going to leapfrog ahead on many of the practices that we will be evolving in Whole Foods Market. We could put them in. There's no culture. There's no legacy there to overcome
componenttext: Also, one of the things perhaps not fully appreciated is that the 365 stores are going to leapfrog ahead on many of the practices that we will be evolving in Whole Foods Market. We could put them in. There's no culture. There's no legacy there to overcome, so we can go radical on 365 stores. And assuming those are going to work as well as we think they do, they will serve to help accelerate transformation within the mother brand to Whole Foods Market. So we're proceeding as rapidly as we think it's prudent at Whole Foods Market. But with 365 stores, we won't have anything holding them back. So in some ways, we think they represent the future where our Whole Foods Market will be evolving. So of course, we're going to encourage people to take a look at those doors when they're open.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will also add one more bucket which is we are also looking across all the functions at Whole Foods Market to see how we can do the work differently whether it's team member services or marketing or any one of the functional areas we've been doing deep d
componenttext: I will also add one more bucket which is we are also looking across all the functions at Whole Foods Market to see how we can do the work differently whether it's team member services or marketing or any one of the functional areas we've been doing deep dives on, thinking through how we're doing the work, where the resources are allocated and where savings can be found. And as we've said to you last quarter, we're going to just fundamentally look at our business and see how we can evolve it to be eliminating redundancies and be more cost effective. And I feel like the whole company has really embraced that effort, and we're making progress.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really are. A lot of this stuff is not going to be going to be -- it's going to be seen over the next 12 months or so. But Whole Foods Market is undergoing further fundamental transformations. And some of that's beginning to show up, but you're going t
componenttext: We really are. A lot of this stuff is not going to be going to be -- it's going to be seen over the next 12 months or so. But Whole Foods Market is undergoing further fundamental transformations. And some of that's beginning to show up, but you're going to see a lot more of it in the next few quarters.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: One thing that's also -- this is David, that we're encouraged by is many of our new stores are actually opening at the rates that we're eventually going to move in Whole Foods to in terms of interest and expenses and structure. And service is great. Hospitality is great, and that gives us a lot of encouragement as we move the rest of the stores to the new program.

componenttext: We have all that information, and it's not something we're sharing today. And we're in the process of leveraging that across also through the -- when people sign up for the app and the coupons, we will have access to that data as well. So our tools are really sharpening in this regard, and so we do have some insights into that. And you'll see us using those as we apply the efforts in the months ahead, but that's all we're going to say today.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we do have some third-party partners we work with, and we're already personalizing offers in our Affinity test market in Philadelphia and intend to expand that both with the digital offers we have nationwide as well as future programs we're doing with Affinity.

componenttext: If you could take a look please at the quarter just ended, in particular, the holiday period, how would you comment on how customers were trading up or their spending behavior? Did you see any changes in that? Were they responding more to competitive promotions as well?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we all are very excited with the holiday results. Both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week were outstanding. Customers come to us. They trust us with their holidays. A couple anecdotes, organic turkeys were the ones that sold first more than just o
componenttext: Well, we all are very excited with the holiday results. Both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week were outstanding. Customers come to us. They trust us with their holidays. A couple anecdotes, organic turkeys were the ones that sold first more than just our natural birds. So we're seeing lots of results there. More than 1/4 of our stores, both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week, did over $1 million in sales. So customers really trust us with the holiday. We see the -- we see customers do trade up and see they trust us with their family meal.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Congrats on the progress. So the first question I wanted to ask just on new stores. You commented in the script that you're seeing positive performance out of your L.A. location. So if you look at your openings in the last few quarters, how are they comparing aggregate versus your expectations? And you also mentioned earlier that you are seeing better cost structure with those stores. So just want to get a sense of whether you're still on track to meet your hurdles for store openings.

componenttext: Yes, I think we are. And we highlighted L.A. store, but there's others performing very well. So overall, good incremental improvement this year from last year. You guys want to add any color to that or...

componenttext: Burnaby, our new Vancouver store, also opened this past quarter, which -- or actually, this quarter, which is excellent, kind of expanded our footprint of Vancouver. componenttext: Well, I think the -- exciting about Miami is going into -- if you haven't been into our downtown Miami store, you should go there. It is an absolutely exciting store. And the overall experience in that store is really, really exciting, especially around lunchtime. You can barely move in the store.

componenttext: And we're also -- we're really proud to entrust the first 365 store opening with our Southern California region. They're on a roll with Playa Vista downtown L.A. They're also opening La Brea next week and then Irvine and then finally 365 in May.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just think that those -- both of those stores, downtown Miami and downtown L.A., where I was just -- it just, I think, demonstrates, again, that we're continuing to evolve as a company providing best-in-class retail experience, so...
componenttext: And I just think that those -- both of those stores, downtown Miami and downtown L.A., where I was just -- it just, I think, demonstrates, again, that we're continuing to evolve as a company providing best-in-class retail experience, so...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly as Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Food Market stores are going to be -- they're going to be larger stores. They're going
componenttext: Yes. One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly as Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Food Market stores are going to be -- they're going to be larger stores. They're going to have a lot of innovation, and then there's going to be a lot of prepared foods. There's going to be a lot of exciting things about those stores. That's why when you talk about downtown Miami or downtown L.A., you're talking about fairly large stores that are really exciting fun stores to be in. With the 365 stores opening now, they're going to take the smaller footprint with a very curated product mix really focused on creating value for customers, a convenient quick shopping experience. So over the long run, you won't see small Whole Food Market stores open up. That's going to be the purview of the 365. That's going to give 365 stores can go in through a lot of markets. We think that Whole Foods can't go in with these bigger, more exciting boxes. And we're going to work for the Whole Foods Market stores to be very differentiated with a much more exciting experience than our competitors bring, so that's kind of our basic strategy. And we're working now in real estate. Now we have a -- it's not going to be perfect for a while because we're working threesome stores there. They're in the queue. But as we go through the real estate process, the smaller stores that come through real estate now are being slotted to be 365 stores. And the larger exciting stores, particularly in urban, densely-populated urban areas, are going to be Whole Foods Market. We think there's -- we got lots of growth room for both concepts. And we're particularly excited to get those 365 stores open because I think people are going take a -- they have a very different perception of our company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you pointed out, the Whole Foods Market is going to be influenced by 365 and vice versa, by the way. And so what comes out of that? We don't know yet, so...
componenttext: And as you pointed out, the Whole Foods Market is going to be influenced by 365 and vice versa, by the way. And so what comes out of that? We don't know yet, so...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: We're excited about our future, and we think we've got a good strategy. We're excited about our -- the 9-point plan we outlined last quarter. We feel like we're executing against that. headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce costs were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it has been. Looking forward to the rest of this year, we're esti
componenttext: This is A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce costs were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it has been. Looking forward to the rest of this year, we're estimating somewhere between 1% and 2% inflation. There's -- some of the pressure that was on inflation this past couple of years with the droughts in California seems to be easing a bit. It's been raining out there. There's good snowpack in the mountains. We've already seen prices of certain commodities, like almonds and pistachios, coming down. So we think it'll be a pretty moderate inflation for the rest of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We -- in center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President nonperishables, Don Clark, of developing a category mana
componenttext: Sure. As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We -- in center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President nonperishables, Don Clark, of developing a category management strategy to that beyond what we've gone here in the past. And through that strategy, we're going to be identifying, looking carefully at all the different categories in center store and deciding where, specifically, strategically we want to do price investments, promotions, things like that. And we'll be doing those in very close cooperation with our suppliers. So we see that as something that we'll be -- we're going to be testing this year. And it'll be an emerging -- it'll be emerging for us as the year goes on into next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: I just want to add that -- I'd just remind that we don't define the competitive challenges as the -- a pricing challenge. We also define it much more broadly with efforts to expand our digital platforms, our reach to our customers, our marketing message, all those things where we can communicate our differences and our equality. Remember, keep that kind of in the context as you think about this competitive question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.C., so I guess you guys had a little inflation as I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business has a lot of, it appears, deflation, particularly in meat. Do you have a little inflation? They're down probably double digit. Is that kind of -- i
componenttext: A.C., so I guess you guys had a little inflation as I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business has a lot of, it appears, deflation, particularly in meat. Do you have a little inflation? They're down probably double digit. Is that kind of -- is that limiting? Or do you expect it to limit in any way your guy's ability to pass through some of this inflation with a conventional world deflating? And I know there is some sort of spread that, I think, in the past you've talked about sort of trying to maintain.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's take -- let's get an example like for instance in beef. There's been -- the conventional -- commercial meat market has -- had seen deflation. We're not seeing it as much because the unique antibiotic free meat that we sell and organic meat we
componenttext: Well, let's take -- let's get an example like for instance in beef. There's been -- the conventional -- commercial meat market has -- had seen deflation. We're not seeing it as much because the unique antibiotic free meat that we sell and organic meat we sell are pretty locked in with contracts to ensure supply. So over the course of the year, we'll see some of that ease down. But what we think is when you've got a differentiated product, you have a certain -- it's going to sell if you can sell it at a different price than the conventional market. I agree with you that there is a certain relationship that needs to happen. But what we see there, we see the same thing in organic dairy, we see the same thing at organic produce that the demand is high in those categories. And so there isn't the kind of deflation in those categories that there isn't some of the conventional product categories. So everybody is paying a -- everybody's affected by that, and so we don't see where we sell so much organic product that there's really deflation in there. So it is not really affecting our ability to be competitive in large categories of what we -- of where we do business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conferen
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer;
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter conference call. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. 
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better leverage in salaries and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone. 
For the quarter, our sales and gross margin results were largely in line with our expectations, with slightly better leverage in salaries and benefits and a lower tax rate. Our sales increased 3% to a record $4.8 billion. We opened 3 stores, including our first store in Huntsville, Alabama, a new flagship store in downtown Los Angeles. For the quarter, comp store sales declined 1.8% against the 4.7% increase in the prior year. In addition to headwinds from a tougher comparison and a highly competitive environment, the negative impact from cannibalization increased for the third consecutive quarter. 
We continue to be a destination for the holidays, with comps for Thanksgiving and Christmas week showing a nice lift over prior run rates. For the first 5 to -- from the first 5 to the last 11 weeks of the quarter, traffic and basket trends on both the 1- and 2-year basis showed improvement. We stepped up our value offerings to customers, primarily through more and deeper promotions, such as our Customer Appreciation Love Fest and 3-day sale in supplements, which were supported through social media, digital ads and select radio ads. Over the remainder of the year, we plan to continue our promotional strategy, including more personalized offers and increase and broaden our price investments as well.
Cost savings and SG&A, primarily salaries and benefits, were more than offset by investments in value and technology as well as deleveraging areas, such as occupancy and depreciation, resulting in a 58-basis-point decline in OM. We produced an 8.3% EBITDA margin, $0.46 in diluted earnings per share, $53 million in free cash flow and a 14% adjusted return on invested capital. 
In keeping with our new capital allocation strategy, we returned $679 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.4 billion in total available capital and $1. billion in total debt. 
Last quarter, we outlined our 9-point plan to fundamentally evolve the business, including active steps to improve our price perception and further differentiate and enhance our shopping experience. We're on track with that plan and would like to share some highlights of the progress we're making in several areas.
We continue to open innovative retail stores, such as our downtown L.A. store, which broke regional records for opening-day and first-day sales and first week sales, and has already established itself as a full-service grocery store and culinary destination. Featuring exciting venues such as acclaimed chef Roy Choi's second Chego outpost and our very own Eight Bar offering daily specials, brunch as well as signature craft cocktails and beers, this store offers a fun and compelling in-store experience and is representative of how we continue to evolve for our customers. 
We welcome Tien Ho as our Global Vice President of Culinary and Hospitality. Tien has worked with some of the most recognized chefs and hotel brands in the world, and we look forward to his leadership in elevating our $3 billion prepared foods and bakery business to an even higher standard. 
Our Exclusive Brands sales increased to over $725 million or 15% of total sales, 150-basis-point increase over the prior year. Notable product launches over the past year include a collection of body care products for babies, organic Greek yogurt, animal welfare-rated organic sliced deli meats and an expanded assortment of seasonal and holiday items. 
Our Instacart sales continue to grow nicely, and we now offer delivery in 16 markets with many stores seeing sales as a percentage of total store in the mid- to high single digits and several stores averaging baskets over $100. We are in the process of expanding this service to more stores and several new markets this year. 
Our new labor scheduling program is now active across the majority of our customer service teams. While still in the early innings, we are pleased with the labor savings we are seeing. We expect to have the program substantially in place across all U.S. customer service teams by the end of Q2 and introduce the program to 2 additional teams in Q3. 
We are close to completing the pilot phase of our new point-of-sale system rollout, which is now being tested in select stores in 10 regions. We expect to complete the pilot phase over the next month, after which the rollout will accelerate, and we are on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. 
In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we have accelerated the first component of our national Affinity program. We're excited to announce today the launch of digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market mobile app, expanding the functionality beyond recipes and shopping lists. Coupons have been the top request among users, and now with a simple scan at the register, preloaded digital coupons can automatically be applied to matching items in the shopper's basket. We encourage everyone to download the app today and take advantage of deep discounts on everyday staples like milk, yogurt and granola; seasonal offers like $5 off a dozen Whole trade roses just in time for Valentine's Day; and more. This is a win for customers, a win for us as well as we will gain actionable customer data on a national scale. Over the coming months, we will expand and improve our offers as well as launch our national digital sales flyer, bringing our customers great savings on what they love to their fingertips. 
In addition, we have committed to expanding our Affinity test to a new market in Q3. Our newly designed rewards program builds one of the best elements of our initial test but with lower costs.
Finally, with 13 365 by Whole Foods Market leases now signed, we are pleased to share the opening schedule for our first stores. We expect to open in Silver Lake, California in late May; Lake Oswego, Oregon in July; and Bellevue, Washington in August. We invite you to check out 365 by wfm.com for a taste of what's to come. 
Turning now to our updated outlook for the year. We are raising our EPS outlook to reflect our slightly better-than-expected Q1 results. We saw an improvement in traffic trends over the course of Q1, and while we have seen some negative impact from weather events in the first 3 weeks of Q2, we are hopeful that comps improve going forward as comparisons get easier and our sales-building initiatives gain traction. We note, however, that there could be some offsetting impact from a ramp-up in price investments and promotions through the year. 
Based on our Q1 results, we now expect a year-over-year decline in operating margin for the fiscal year of up to 70 basis points, reflecting increased value efforts as the year progresses. The year-over-year decline in gross margin, excluding LIFO in Q2 through Q4, is expected to be greater than the 86-basis-point decline in Q1. We expect our gross margin investment to be partially offset by a sequential increase in SG&A leverage. And excluding $0.02 to $0.05 per share in estimated net accretion related to debt finance buybacks, we expect fiscal year EPS of $1.53 or greater or $1.07 or greater for the remainder of the year. 
In closing, we are making measurable progress on our strategic plan to fundamentally evolve our business, and we'll continue to do so over the remainder of the year. We believe we are taking the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term. 
We will now take questions.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are doing both. I mean, there are certain very important categories that we know that we need to be competitive on an everyday basis on, and so we're working to systematically identify those and move pricing on those to make sure that we're compe
componenttext: Sure. We are doing both. I mean, there are certain very important categories that we know that we need to be competitive on an everyday basis on, and so we're working to systematically identify those and move pricing on those to make sure that we're competitive. There's a fair number of items we've lowered prices on so far this year and have plans to do more as the year goes on. But we've also found that we have always been a kind of -- our company has always had a strong high/low strategy. That's what our customers respond to. And so we feel that the best way to show our customers' value is to ramp up on the promotional side.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is David. I would also say that we're encouraged by activating our customers digitally with some trip-driving promotions in the last few months, $0.25 cup of coffee with our friends at Allegro, $0.99 green smoothies, $0.25 cookies. Those are thi
componenttext: Yes. This is David. I would also say that we're encouraged by activating our customers digitally with some trip-driving promotions in the last few months, $0.25 cup of coffee with our friends at Allegro, $0.99 green smoothies, $0.25 cookies. Those are things that get people up off the couch into the store, and hopefully, they'll continue to buy other things when they come in.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up. I was just hoping you could drill down a little bit on your expanded cost. Clearly, you're seeing some nice leverage in SG&A. Can you just give us a better sense of what are the major buckets of expense savings that you're
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up. I was just hoping you could drill down a little bit on your expanded cost. Clearly, you're seeing some nice leverage in SG&A. Can you just give us a better sense of what are the major buckets of expense savings that you're sort of pulling from to achieve that? Specifically if you could just try to quantify or compartmentalize in savings, particularly when it comes to your $300 million savings target, that will be pretty helpful.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we just want to affirm that we're on track with that target we set out for ourselves. We're making good progress where we expect it to be. I think that's reflected in the numbers. I don't think we're going to break out the components o
componenttext: Well, first of all, we just want to affirm that we're on track with that target we set out for ourselves. We're making good progress where we expect it to be. I think that's reflected in the numbers. I don't think we're going to break out the components of that in particular just because we've -- in the last quarter, we've moved back to SG&A, which contains the DSCs result together. But it's fair to say that the biggest bucket in there is the labor and benefits. That is the biggest expense of the company, and that's where we've gotten significant improvement. So do you want to add anything to that, David or Ken?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say that one of the things that we're doing is really looking at where we cannot have less service but have smarter service in our stores, and that is the process. And also looking at the back of the house of the stores, where are areas that
componenttext: I would just say that one of the things that we're doing is really looking at where we cannot have less service but have smarter service in our stores, and that is the process. And also looking at the back of the house of the stores, where are areas that we can streamline and create more efficiencies through consistency of practices and development of standard operating practices in our stores. And that's really where we're seeing ourselves driving the savings from a labor standpoint in the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would also say, as we're building the labor model for the new 365 stores, we're learning a lot of really good lessons. And we're complying them to Whole Foods Market in terms of, again, smarter service, just-in-time labor scheduling. And we're applying
componenttext: I would also say, as we're building the labor model for the new 365 stores, we're learning a lot of really good lessons. And we're complying them to Whole Foods Market in terms of, again, smarter service, just-in-time labor scheduling. And we're applying those things now and realizing the savings over the course of this year and next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And as you know, we said to you this was going to take us a couple years to work our way through this to get to that run rate, and that's exactly what we're doing.
componenttext: Yes. And as you know, we said to you this was going to take us a couple years to work our way through this to get to that run rate, and that's exactly what we're doing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're seeing a lot of opportunities for 365 stores just like our Whole Foods stores, and we're also finding that we're able to acquire these stores on very favorable rents less in general than our Whole Foods Market stores. We have quite a few of ou
componenttext: Well, we're seeing a lot of opportunities for 365 stores just like our Whole Foods stores, and we're also finding that we're able to acquire these stores on very favorable rents less in general than our Whole Foods Market stores. We have quite a few of our 365 in development in Southern California, but it's just a -- it's not necessarily by design. We're looking everywhere, and we're -- the plan is to try and cluster stores 365 where possible. And we're doing that in Southern California, but we also have leases in other isolated markets as well.

componenttext: Well, just -- I'll answer them and then Jason. It's just been out a week, and I just looked at the usage over the first week.
