componenttextpreview: Yes. We did a soft launch on January 28. We've had -- new downloads of the app have increased 43%. We hit high active users, which was a 50% increase since the end of January. And I think, for us, the most exciting part is customers that are registering.
componenttext: Yes. We did a soft launch on January 28. We've had -- new downloads of the app have increased 43%. We hit high active users, which was a 50% increase since the end of January. And I think, for us, the most exciting part is customers that are registering. So we're up 260% of folks registering us with the app. So thus far, we've gotten lots of favorable reviews. And as you might notice, if you take a look, we have both supplier-funded offers as well as Whole Foods-funded offers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I just wanted to add, we also replaced our CRM, our e-mail platform. And in the last 6 months, we have doubled the number of users, registered users, on that platform to be able to -- so we'll be able to reach more customers and to reach them digitally with the messages. So these things are working in concert together.

componenttext: Question on comps for me. Prior guidance, I think called for around negative 2% in the first quarter, then flat the next 2 and then plus 3 in the fourth quarter. You did as expected in 1Q, but you've reduced the outlook for a year a little bit. So as you think about the cadence for the rest of the year, is there any quarter in particular you're, I guess, a bit less sanguine on? Or is that pacing that you talked about previously, is that still generally what you're looking for?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: But on the other hand, we did. On the other hand, we did affirm our -- we affirmed our annual guidance of 3% to 5% sales growth, and we're continuing to affirm that today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay. Maybe, I'll follow-up after the call on that. One other one for me. Last year at this time you were, I guess, in the midst of a pretty big advertising push. At the time, you were pleased with the ROI and net spend. We really haven't se
componenttext: Right, right. Okay. Maybe, I'll follow-up after the call on that. One other one for me. Last year at this time you were, I guess, in the midst of a pretty big advertising push. At the time, you were pleased with the ROI and net spend. We really haven't seen at least, as far as I can tell, the same level of advertising since. I'm just curious. Is the reason as simple as you're getting a better return from other investments? Or is there some other driver behind it? And I'm just curious why the campaign didn't really get sustained, or at least what I'm seeing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the countries promoting our produce and our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a grou
componenttext: Yes, I mean I think we're -- it's interesting you mentioned that because just this week we started our radio campaign in 12 markets across the countries promoting our produce and our produce price investments and our produce quality. But I think as a group, we've kind of gone back and rethought exactly how we want to bring the brand forward. And we're starting with our efforts in promo and prices A.C. outlined, on the digital platforms like David and Jason were talking about, and I could see a brand campaign in the future. But I think we are doing the work on our brand by getting our message out in these different platforms and ways, and I think it'll evolve from there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's different in what you're really referring to is that we haven't launched a big national television campaign, and that's been a conscious decision on our part. It's not to say we won't do one in the future, but we decided we had better priorities or
componenttext: What's different in what you're really referring to is that we haven't launched a big national television campaign, and that's been a conscious decision on our part. It's not to say we won't do one in the future, but we decided we had better priorities or better opportunities or better strategies for trying to promote our new lower prices. And we've got our 365 launch, and we've got -- a lot of marketing dollars have been spent out there but perhaps not in as visible a way on a national basis.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Bill Kirk with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the quarter-to-date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast snowstorm have? Have you quantified that?
componenttext: On the quarter-to-date trend, how big of an impact did the East Coast snowstorm have? Have you quantified that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do, not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of
componenttext: We have not quantified it. It's a difficult thing to do, not quite as scientific as you might think. On one hand, we had 59 full days of lost sales this year versus 26 days last year, which also had some significant weather events. And there was a lot of volatility within the 3-week period. We also saw the 2-year comps decelerate in the nonweather regions as well as in the weather-affected regions. So essentially, it's just too short a period of time to draw very many conclusions. We have the trends from before the storms, but we don't have much information about trends after the storms. So it's difficult to do. The -- we also had the Super Bowl shift with -- from week to week, although it was within the 3 weeks. So it didn't really affect the year-over-year number, but it did affect our ability to really quantify the impact of the storm. That's why we haven't put a number to it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the guidance, it looks like there's less accretion from the debt-funded buybacks than you had last quarter. Am I seeing that right?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the guidance, it looks like there's less accretion from the debt-funded buybacks than you had last quarter. Am I seeing that right?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the $0.02 that we put at the bottom of the range is the accretion, the net accretion that we will have if we don't do any additional buybacks for the year. And the $0.05 is if we spend the rest of the $324 million that's remaining out of the $1 bill
componenttext: Well, the $0.02 that we put at the bottom of the range is the accretion, the net accretion that we will have if we don't do any additional buybacks for the year. And the $0.05 is if we spend the rest of the $324 million that's remaining out of the $1 billion that we borrowed. So it's just an update based on actual rates, actual timing of the bond and actual timing of the buyback so far.

componenttext: I was hoping you could talk just a little bit -- you did a great job on expenses. Congratulations. componenttext: Well, I think we touched on a couple on labor scheduling, being that one that we outlined in the script, is showing tremendous promise, and Ken just spoke a little bit about the efforts around relooking how work is done. Do you want to add to that Ken?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say that we've really done a lot of work on developing SOPs that we're going to launch throughout the company this year.
componenttext: I would just say that we've really done a lot of work on developing SOPs that we're going to launch throughout the company this year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Standard operating procedures.
componenttext: Standard operating procedures.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Standard operating practices, which are focusing on a lot of our production teams and high-volume teams in our stores. We also -- the work around the labor scheduling; cannot underestimate the power of that technology advancement in terms of matching up o
componenttext: Standard operating practices, which are focusing on a lot of our production teams and high-volume teams in our stores. We also -- the work around the labor scheduling; cannot underestimate the power of that technology advancement in terms of matching up our schedule to our customer flow as well as implementing that into the other teams within the store to improve the scheduling relative to the workflow as well. So those 2 in itself are significant advancements for us in terms of streamlining and advancing the productivity in our stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also say that our regional Presidents have really taken a leadership position on this and are actively working on all aspects of both labor reduction in the store and large reductions in expenses through common buying on packaging and supplies.
componenttext: I'd also say that our regional Presidents have really taken a leadership position on this and are actively working on all aspects of both labor reduction in the store and large reductions in expenses through common buying on packaging and supplies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, one of the things perhaps not fully appreciated is that the 365 stores are going to leapfrog ahead on many of the practices that we will be evolving in Whole Foods Market. We can put them in. There's no culture. There's no legacy there to overcome,
componenttext: Also, one of the things perhaps not fully appreciated is that the 365 stores are going to leapfrog ahead on many of the practices that we will be evolving in Whole Foods Market. We can put them in. There's no culture. There's no legacy there to overcome, so we can go radical on 365 stores. And assuming those are going to work as well as we think they do, they will serve to help accelerate transformation within the mother brand to Whole Foods Market. So we're proceeding as rapidly as we think it's prudent at Whole Foods Market. But with 365 stores, we won't have anything holding them back. So in some ways, we think they represent the future for where Whole Foods Market will be evolving. So of course, we're going to encourage people to take a look at those doors when they're open.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would also add one more bucket which is we are also looking across all the functions at Whole Foods Market to see how we can do the work differently, whether it's team member services or marketing or any one of the functional areas we've been doing deep
componenttext: I would also add one more bucket which is we are also looking across all the functions at Whole Foods Market to see how we can do the work differently, whether it's team member services or marketing or any one of the functional areas we've been doing deep dives on, thinking through how we're doing the work, where the resources are allocated and where savings can be found. And as we've said to you last quarter, we're going to just fundamentally look at our business and see how we can evolve it to be eliminating redundancies and be more cost effective. And I feel like the whole company has really embraced that effort, and we're making progress.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really are. A lot of this stuff is not going to be going to be -- it's going to be seen over the next 12 months or so. But Whole Foods Market is undergoing further fundamental transformations. And some of that's beginning to show up, but you're going t
componenttext: We really are. A lot of this stuff is not going to be going to be -- it's going to be seen over the next 12 months or so. But Whole Foods Market is undergoing further fundamental transformations. And some of that's beginning to show up, but you're going to see a lot more of it in the next few quarters.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing that's also -- this is David -- that we're encouraged by is many of our new stores are actually opening at the rates that we're eventually going to be moving Whole Foods to in terms of interest and expenses and structure. And service is great. H
componenttext: One thing that's also -- this is David -- that we're encouraged by is many of our new stores are actually opening at the rates that we're eventually going to be moving Whole Foods to in terms of interest and expenses and structure. And service is great. Hospitality is great, and that gives us a lot of encouragement as we move the rest of the stores to the new program.

componenttext: We have all that information, and it's not something we're sharing today. So -- but actually, as a result of the Affinity work, we actually, first ever, have our sort of 5 customer segments. And we're -- and we tokenized data, and we're able to track their actual movement. And we're in the process of leveraging that across also through the -- when people sign up for the app and the coupons, we will have access to that data as well. So our tools are really sharpening in this regard, and so we do have some insights into that. And you'll see us using those as we apply the efforts in the months ahead, but that's all we're going to say today.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we do have some third-party partners we work with, and we're already personalizing offers in our Affinity test market in Philadelphia and intend to expand that both with the digital offers we have nationwide as well as future programs we're doing with Affinity.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you could take a look please at the quarter just ended, in particular, the holiday period, how would you comment on how customers were trading off with their spending behavior? Did you see any changes in that? Were they responding more to competitive p
componenttext: If you could take a look please at the quarter just ended, in particular, the holiday period, how would you comment on how customers were trading off with their spending behavior? Did you see any changes in that? Were they responding more to competitive promotions as well?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we all were very excited with the holiday results. Both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week were outstanding. Customers come to us. They trust us with their holidays. A couple anecdotes, organic turkeys were the ones that sold first more than just
componenttext: Well, we all were very excited with the holiday results. Both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week were outstanding. Customers come to us. They trust us with their holidays. A couple anecdotes, organic turkeys were the ones that sold first more than just our natural birds. So we're seeing lots of results there. More than 1/4 of our stores, both Thanksgiving week and Christmas week, did over $1 million in sales. So customers really trust us with the holiday. We see the -- we see customers do trade up and see -- they trust us with their family meal.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly as Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Food Market stores are going to be -- they're going to be larger stores. They're going
componenttext: Yes. One of the things that you can expect to see going forward, particularly as Whole Foods Market is in this transformational shift, is you're going to see the Whole Food Market stores are going to be -- they're going to be larger stores. They're going to have a lot of innovation, and then there's going to be a lot of prepared foods. There's going to be a lot of exciting things about those stores. That's why when you talk about downtown Miami or downtown L.A., you're talking about fairly large stores that are really exciting fun stores to be in. With the 365 stores opening now, they're going to take the smaller footprint with a very curated product mix really focused on creating value for customers, a convenient quick shopping experience. So over the long run, you won't see small Whole Food Market stores open up. That's going to be the purview of the 365. That's going to give -- 365 stores can go into a lot of markets we think that Whole Foods can't go in with these bigger, more exciting boxes. And we're going to work for the Whole Foods Market stores to be very differentiated with a much more exciting experience than our competitors bring, so that's kind of our basic strategy. And we're working now in real estate. Now we have a -- it's not going to be perfect for awhile because we're working through some stores that are in the queue. But as we go through the real estate process, the smaller stores that come through real estate now are being slotted to be 365 stores. And the larger exciting stores, particularly in urban, densely-populated urban areas, are going to be Whole Foods Market. We think there's -- we got lots of growth room for both concepts. And we're particularly excited to get those 365 stores open because I think people are going to take a -- they're going to have a very different perception of our company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce costs were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it has been. Looking forward to the rest of this year, we're esti
componenttext: This is A.C. In Q1, we saw an inflation of around 1%. A few things were up. Our meat costs were up slightly. Our produce costs were down slightly. But overall, about 1%, which is lower than it has been. Looking forward to the rest of this year, we're estimating somewhere between 1% and 2% inflation. There's -- some of the pressure that was on inflation this past couple of years with the droughts in California seems to be easing a bit. It's been raining out there. There's good snowpack in the mountains. We've already seen prices of certain commodities, like almonds and pistachios, coming down. So we think it'll be a pretty moderate inflation for the rest of the year.

Are those efforts unfolding together in lockstep? Or does perhaps the center of the store occur first and the perimeter follow?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We -- in center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President of Nonperishables, Don Clark, of developing a category m
componenttext: Sure. As I said earlier, our focus in Q1 and going forward this year is largely in the perimeter departments. We -- in center store, we're in the process right now with our new Global Vice President of Nonperishables, Don Clark, of developing a category management strategy that -- beyond what we've gone here in the past. And through that strategy, we're going to be identifying, looking carefully at all the different categories in center store and deciding where, specifically, strategically we want to do price investments, promotions, things like that. And we'll be doing those in very close cooperation with our suppliers. So we see that as something that we'll be -- we're going to be testing this year. And it'll be an emerging -- it'll be emerging for us as the year goes on into next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to add that -- I'd just remind that we don't define the competitive challenge as just a pricing challenge. We also define it much more broadly with efforts to expand our digital platforms, our reach to our customers, our marketing message, all
componenttext: I just want to add that -- I'd just remind that we don't define the competitive challenge as just a pricing challenge. We also define it much more broadly with efforts to expand our digital platforms, our reach to our customers, our marketing message, all those things where we can communicate our differences and our quality. So remember, keep that kind of in the context as you think about this competitive question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.C., so I guess you guys had a little inflation. As I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business had a lot of, it appears, deflation, particularly in meat. You have a little inflation; they're down probably double digit. Is that kind of -- is
componenttext: A.C., so I guess you guys had a little inflation. As I'm sure you know the conventional side of the business had a lot of, it appears, deflation, particularly in meat. You have a little inflation; they're down probably double digit. Is that kind of -- is that limiting? Or do you expect it to limit in any way your guy's ability to pass through some of this inflation with the conventional world deflating? And I know there is some sort of spread that, I think, in the past you've talked about sort of trying to maintain.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's take -- let's get an example like, for instance, in beef. There's been -- the conventional -- the commercial meat market has -- had seen deflation. We're not seeing it as much because the unique antibiotic-free meat that we sell and organic me
componenttext: Well, let's take -- let's get an example like, for instance, in beef. There's been -- the conventional -- the commercial meat market has -- had seen deflation. We're not seeing it as much because the unique antibiotic-free meat that we sell and organic meat we sell are pretty locked in with contracts to ensure supply. So over the course of the year, we'll see some of that ease down. But what we think is when you've got a differentiated product, you have a certain -- it's going to sell if -- you can sell it at a different price than the conventional market. I agree with you that there is a certain relationship that needs to happen. But what we see there, we see the same thing in organic dairy, we see the same thing with organic produce that the demand is high in those categories. And so there isn't the kind of deflation in those categories that there isn't some of the conventional product categories. So everybody is paying a -- everybody's affected by that, and so we don't see where we sell so much organic product that there's really deflation in there. So it is not really affecting our ability to be competitive in large categories of what we -- of where we do business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; AC Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Gr
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; AC Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating cash flow and 14% adjusted return on invested capital. We returned $144 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases and in the quarter, $1.3 billion in total available capital and $1.1 billion in total debt.
We have committed to a fundamental restructuring of the cost side of our business. We want to appreciate our leadership throughout the company for the strong discipline in managing expenses. We improved salaries and benefits expense by 96 basis points. However, these savings are more than offset by investments in value, technology and marketing as well as deleverage in areas such as occupancy and depreciation. As a result, operating margin declined 29 basis points, excluding a nonroutine supplier credit in the prior year.
We are facing ongoing headwinds from a highly competitive environment as well as cannibalization but the negative impact on our value -- of our value strategy was the primary factor for the moderation in our comps from Q1. Approximately 80 of the 120 basis point moderation was due to lower increase in average price per item, which is less than 1% was our lowest increase in 5 years. As we communicated last quarter, our value efforts ramped up in Q2 with increased promotions and broader and deeper price investments in select categories. We have increased our marketing spend to raise the visibility of these investments and are seeing a lift in unit volume. We believe improving our value perception is one of the key components in regaining our sales momentum. While we expect some continued sales impact, we plan to expand our price investments and add weekly deep discount promotions in select categories, which we actively marketed nationwide. Food retailing is evolving at an incredibly fast pace, and consumers have more options than ever before. In addition to becoming more competitive on price, we're making measurable progress and fundamentally evolving our business and providing an enhanced experience for our customers across all platforms before, during and after their visit.
I will now share some highlights of our progress. In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we began offering digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market app -- mobile app. This served as the launch of the first component of our national Affinity program as we now have actionable customer data on the national scale. We've already tripled our number of active users year-over-year and are seeing strong coupon redemptions. Later this summer, customers in Dallas will have access within our app to our newly designed rewards program, which builds upon the best elements of our initial program in Philadelphia but with lower cost. We are committed to expanding our personalization efforts. Once this market -- test market is complete, we intend to roll out our rewards program nationally. We intensified our customer acquisition efforts, realizing 30% increase in new customers into our database and a 10% increase in social media followers and engagement in just 1 quarter. With a rapidly growing customer database and a social imprint approaching 13 million followers, we are continuing to invest in digital strategies to convert our strong online traffic into sales. We're excited to announce that for the first time, customers can now order through our wholefoodsmarket.com website for delivery by Instacart, and we look forward to offering continual enhancements that will provide our customers a more seamless experience over time. Instacart has recently expanded to Orange County, Baltimore, Charlotte and San Antonio with additional markets coming soon. Collectively, Whole Foods and Instacart deliver fresh groceries to more households -- households in the United States than anyone else. 
We're continuing to hit major milestones in replacing our legacy systems with new technology platforms. We have completed a pilot phase for our new point-of-sale system and are now accelerating the rollout. We're on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. This new unified system will provide many benefits, including operational efficiencies and consolidated item data to support personalized offers, category management and supplier collaboration. Our new labor scheduling program is now in place across all of our U.S. customer service teams, and we plan to introduce the program to 2 additional store teams in Q3. With this new program, we are saving administrative time and gaining insight on how to spend labor dollars more efficiently to better serve our customers. The benefits of this new tool will be more fully realized next fiscal year and beyond as we implemented company-wide and incorporate best practices into our labor budgeting process. With 19 leases now signed, we're very excited to be just 3 weeks away from opening our first 365 store by Whole Foods Market. Created to complement our Whole Foods Market stores, our new 365 format will offer our same industry-leading standards and dedication to food transparency delivered in a new way. The streamlined format is designed around affordability and convenience and will be supported by enhanced digital experiences. Opening May 25 in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, the 28,000 square foot store will be quickly followed by stores in Lake Oswego, Oregon and Bellevue, Washington. We believe there's a customer demand for both formats and as the second growth vehicle, 365 allows us to attack the value quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. We're excited to get our first 3 stores open and to learn and evolve from there. We are continuing to invest in our team members' development and growth, including creating thousands of new jobs this year. Our 86,000 team members are the essential ingredient in creating our best-in-class customer experience, and we were very pleased to have once again earned a spot on Fortune Magazine's annual list of 100 best companies to work for. We are proud to be one of only 11 companies what made the list every year since its inception 19 years ago.
Turning now to our updated outlook. We expect to be at or below the low end of our prior sales and earnings per share ranges. While we beat our bottom line expectations in the first half of the year, primarily through better-than-projected leverage in salaries and benefits, our comp trends have yet to stabilize. We're hopeful the comps will improve over the course of the year as our sales-building initiatives gain traction and our comparisons get easier. Beginning in week 11 of Q3, we will anniversary the sharp drop in our comps last year after weights and measures audit generated negative national media attention. We expect the offsetting impact from our value strategy to continue, however, as we ramp up our price investments and promotions over the remainder of the year. Given our lower sales projections, we now expect SG&A leverage to be more in line with the 19 basis points we have produced year-to-date. This reflects the positive impact of our cost savings initiatives, net of higher depreciation and other cost, including additional marketing and technology investments we have approved for later in the year. Please refer to our press release for more details.
In closing, we continue to make measurable progress in our 9-point strategic plan to have all of our business and hope our remarks today highlight the fundamental transportation that is taking place within our company. We believe we are taking the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term.
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera, and then also maybe on
componenttext: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera, and then also maybe on top of that, from a category management standpoint, any updates there that you can share?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is a AC. In the pricing, we mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments. And what we've been seeing is as we ramped it up -- we started to really ramp it up to the year and i
componenttext: This is a AC. In the pricing, we mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments. And what we've been seeing is as we ramped it up -- we started to really ramp it up to the year and in Q2, we made more investments, and we did some large national promotions in produce. We had a big citrus promotion early in the year. We had a really big -- our biggest -- we had organic strawberry promotion, which was the biggest promotion we've ever done. And for the first time, we've had marketing to go with it. We did not show marketing around that, and we saw our phenomenal uplift to that. And I'd say that, generally, in the areas where we've done these investments, we've been seeing a good uptick in the units. They haven't been as much as to offset the actual investment themselves, but we think that over the long term as customers get more used to these promos we're doing in these investments that we'll start to capture a larger percentage of their shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I think the big difference is also with these perishable promotions is we're promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally, so we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on social medi
componenttext: This is David. I think the big difference is also with these perishable promotions is we're promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally, so we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on social media with this promotional activity.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. We think this is a lot more visible than what we've done before. You've also asked the question about category management. We're doing a lot of the pick and shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll and intent work for each catego
componenttext: Right. We think this is a lot more visible than what we've done before. You've also asked the question about category management. We're doing a lot of the pick and shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll and intent work for each category, hiring category leaders, really doing all that work. And we see that we're going to probably be laying the foundation through the rest of this fiscal year and we're going to be then running a pilot at the beginning of next fiscal year and in the fall. And then once we moved beyond that pilot, then we'll start to actually roll out category management later next year.

So does that help clarify? But no, we don't have any specific way of, other than that pointing that out us, having how much of that was inflation versus change in our actual lower prices.

componenttext: Yes. This is Jason. We're still in the early innings of this program but, I think, as a whole, we're very excited about the results. Our intention at this point is to continue to add features to our app, inclusive of the digital coupons, leading up to our Affinity rollout, which we'll be piloting our next city up in Dallas and then doing our national rollout following that test.

componenttext: Just wanted to focus on procurement. I think you mentioned a couple of things earlier talking about category management and sort of the time line for the next maybe 12 to 24 months. Just kind of curious, maybe the feedback you're getting from some of your suppliers as coming out of and sort of going into the balance of the year, how we think some of the things that you're doing right now could help the model overall.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's AC again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them were waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because a lot o
componenttext: It's AC again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them were waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because a lot of -- they had to go to 11 different regions often and talk to the buyers in each region. So the idea that they can -- they're going to be able to come to just the global office and talk to the team here, work out the promotions, work out new items, things like that is something that we're very excited about and glad to hear. We know in talking with the suppliers we formed supplier advisory groups and meetings with them. We know that there's a lot of opportunities for us on the cost savings side for increased promotions aspect. There's a lot of opportunities there for us to reap once we can get really rolling with category management. So we're just seeing -- we're seeing a lot of opportunities.

componenttext: So it looks like there were 3 more leased locations that initially had been signed for a regular store that have now changed to 365. Can you talk about that decision-making process? And then, I guess, what would need to be done to pull it off?

componenttext: Yes, well, we did announce 3 conversions to Whole Foods from stores in development in Akron, Toledo and Bloomington, Indiana. And in looking at those markets and the size of the stores, we felt that they were better suited to be 365 location. Particularly as we look at the size of stores, we feel that Whole Foods Market stores going forward should be 45,000-plus square feet, and the stores that we converted were approximately 30,000 square feet. So more value markets and the right size for 365. So we -- that's why we changed those 2 into 365s.

In fact, the very first store was initially a Whole Foods Market, but we added the concept decided before we signed the lease. So again, just change the design to be more appropriate to 28,000 square feet.

componenttext: I was hoping you could speak more to the cadence in the sales trends during the quarter. We've heard others say it's been choppy month-to-month even week-to-week. And so really, if it has bounced around quite a lot, I'm just curious to maybe even drill down even just into some of the 3-week trends that you've seen so far into the quarter. I mean, just how true of a trend line is that if it has been quite volatile? So any comments in there would be helpful.

componenttext: Yes. The improvement that we've seen in the 3 weeks is in items per basket, which will be nice if that trend could continue, but it's 3 weeks. It's a very short amount of time, and I would hesitate to draw any conclusions at all from that because, certainly, things do move around quite a bit from week-to-week and with any short period of time.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it, and we're start
componenttext: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it, and we're starting to see some positive results there, and that's going to continue the rest of fiscal year. So we're -- that's going to be wind to our backs there's been a headwind for the last year. Secondly as we get into the very end of this quarter, we will anniversary the weights and measure audit that happened to us in New York City that went national and definitely took tremendous amount of sales from Whole Foods Market. So when that happens in week 11 of this quarter, we will begin to compare against that. That's going to be a very positive -- that's going to have a very positive effect on comps.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to note that's all settled now. It's been settled for a number of months. So that's just looking in the rearview mirror. And also, as we pick up through the end of the fourth quarter, the comparisons, in general, just gets easier. So the backd
componenttext: I just want to note that's all settled now. It's been settled for a number of months. So that's just looking in the rearview mirror. And also, as we pick up through the end of the fourth quarter, the comparisons, in general, just gets easier. So the backdrop is a bit choppy in terms of the macroeconomic environment, but I think we're not calling it a bottom, but I think there's lots of things that are very encouraging here in terms of the turning point, but too early to call that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your price investments, I knew you lowered prices on quite a few items this year, and there's more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you thi
componenttext: In terms of your price investments, I knew you lowered prices on quite a few items this year, and there's more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you think that you're getting more bang for your buck so far? And how do you plan to balance the 2 going forward?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One, it's very interesting. Doing the price investments, the different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular, like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investme
componenttext: One, it's very interesting. Doing the price investments, the different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular, like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investments we've done, we're studying that the effects, but we're definitely seeing in some markets much more response to them than others. We're seeing in certain departments, we're seeing a lot more response to them than others. So it's still really early in our price investments where we purposely designed this to roll out kind of slow and steady, so we could learn from it and see what people really respond to. And I think, the really exciting thing though that we've been doing is that we're really ramping up our marketing behind them, with our digital coupons, with our national flyer now, it's digital, it's going to be -- we're going to experiment with sending it out to -- in some markets, we're going to be mailing it to people's homes. So that, I think, is really the next big step for us because, I think, I said earlier just lowering some prices here and there, doing some promotions, if people don't really know about them, it's not -- we're not going to get the full effect. And so I'm really excited that we've got now -- we're going to have the marketing muscle behind a lot of what we're doing. We're putting that in place so as we do more investments going forward, we've got -- people are going to know about them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David.I'd also say we're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know we're doing promotions now that we're inviting more customers and through advertising and digital as well as radio and other mediums
componenttext: This is David.I'd also say we're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know we're doing promotions now that we're inviting more customers and through advertising and digital as well as radio and other mediums that they know if they really go for it on the merchandising that the customers are going to come in. We're adding more customers all the time, so it's kind of a virtuous circle between our team members and our customers.

componenttext: This is Walter. If I could just add one comment, I think the idea is we're doing multiple things to serve the customer who now these customers come into the store and also searches online and doing lots of preparation for shopping or even food shopping online. So I think the fact we're reaching out reaching out both with the store through the price engines there which you recognize have a longer lag time, so to speak, to return because it takes a trip to convert that to business, but then also offering the digital offering the customer both of those choices, I think, we're kind of working the mix of short term, medium term and long term in terms of offering our customers venture value.

componenttext: Well, we're still on the path that we laid out before, which is the $300 million over the 2 years. And those, I think, we talked about primarily in the salaries and benefits area, also in restructuring the organization. So we're on track with that. You can see that reflected in the results here. I'm not sure what more specifics are you looking for with that, Stephen.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading the labor efficiencie
componenttext: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading the labor efficiencies. We're doing all kinds of stuff. Ken and David might have some additional color.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I will just point out our leader in distribution our SOP process that we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin. We're seeing a much higher percentage of our inventory moving to the sales floor and out
componenttext: Yes. I will just point out our leader in distribution our SOP process that we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin. We're seeing a much higher percentage of our inventory moving to the sales floor and out of our back rooms. It's -- we want to talk about it more in the next call, but we really feel that this is going to be a larger reduction in excess inventory sitting at the back of our house in addition to a decrease in shrink and also overall improvement in team member morale because the back rooms are in much better shape. So early days but very exciting and Ken and I are planning on rolling this out as fast as we can across all the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched and the power of that is we're simplifying the work for in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies in production that we once had that one p
componenttext: John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched and the power of that is we're simplifying the work for in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies in production that we once had that one person those expert person is producing the product that's then distributed to all the other teams of the stores. We think that's revolutionary in the way in which we'll operate our stores while the higher quality product of experts producing it will take a lot of capital out of the stores that you once had to produce product in multiple places in our stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: New splash, the food tastes great.
componenttext: New splash, the food tastes great.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Walter, just kind of put a big frame on that, I think if you look at their business will say that a lot of energy and time to the customer experience, in the store experience and we had such a pretty strong regional structure and I think as a result o
componenttext: And Walter, just kind of put a big frame on that, I think if you look at their business will say that a lot of energy and time to the customer experience, in the store experience and we had such a pretty strong regional structure and I think as a result of this crossroads and transformation we're going through we're looking at all the systems that supports the processes and how we do work and how we're structured, everything from soup, that's naturally looking at everything in terms of how we can simplify, eliminate redundancies, do work differently, find more savings through just streamlining the organization, and that just led to some at least land of opportunity for Whole Foods I think perhaps other supermarkets have been there and done that, and I think we're just arriving and realizing there's lots there even as we continue to work hard on stepping up the experience that we're delivering to our customers. So I think that's one big way to think about it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And as a follow-up to your -- the last comment on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets had done and you might also mention price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other initiatives,
componenttext: That's helpful color. And as a follow-up to your -- the last comment on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets had done and you might also mention price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other initiatives, and those also some pretty similar to what conventional competitors are doing, so maybe you can provide color on some of the other things are aspects that you are trying to implement and that will actually differentiate Whole Foods from the group rather than moving more closely to them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we only ever case, we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things we need to do in order to be relevant to the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've now seen the changes, but that's not our -- if you look at
componenttext: Well, we only ever case, we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things we need to do in order to be relevant to the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've now seen the changes, but that's not our -- if you look at our 9-point plan and as we continue to talk about it today, we're putting a lot of emphasis on continuing to provide new experiences, different experiences. We're opening up all the digital platforms to able to reach our customers in new ways in different ways than we've been able to do previously. So really, this is about much more than just price investments. I recognize many others have done those as well, and it's part of being in the grocery retail business. You're constantly chewing up much us in these conference calls, you're chewing up everyday in the marketplace as markets change but hopefully what you're a much broader thought process around how we think we can set ourselves apart to differentiate and gain some momentum, and that's as AC mentioned a promotions at the marketing around at which also talks about the quality of the product the opening up some of these platforms to offer new content and new options for customers. For example, they can shop for food now through wholefoodsmarket.com that's a new thing we haven't been able to do before. So in all these ways, I think, we're trying to -- and the 365 John mentioned is, of course, another growth opportunity for the company and serving the customers in new ways. So I think, you take the whole big picture and you say, there's a lot going on here to regain momentum.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also want to share the fact that our commitment to culinary is really what separates us compared to the competitions, and so we have the leadership in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new programs where we have th
componenttext: I also want to share the fact that our commitment to culinary is really what separates us compared to the competitions, and so we have the leadership in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new programs where we have the friends of Whole Foods Market begin really great restaurant concepts into our stores and having these partnerships that are creating a unique experience from a culinary standpoint that really is, by far, above anything that we're competing against right now. So we really feel like the renewed focus on culinary in our stores is big, big differentiator for us as a company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365 stores that you have to go and see. And we've got got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge op
componenttext: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365 stores that you have to go and see. And we've got got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge opportunity for us that's going to help set us apart. And then in all of our stores continue to innovate. You go into our new stores, go into the downtime L.A. take a trip to Southern Californiain  3 weeks, we're opening new brand, see our downtown L.A. store while you're at it and we're opening great new stores are doing tremendous sales, tremendous volumes will continue to innovate from an operational standpoint. Everyone is continuing to try to copy us because innovations are still occurring in Whole Foods Market. That's how we're differentiating. Now if you mean -- sure, we're copying some of the things some of our competitors do. We're learning from everybody and competitors are doing some things better than Whole Foods we certainly want to learn from that and make our company better, but we're not standing still. In fact, I would argue that were probably undergoing far more evolution in our company than ever before. And the final and probably the most important point, nobody, nobody comes close to matching our quality standards. We're the only one -- only supermarket in America that's 100% cage-free eggs animal welfare system that's top-rated in Greenpeace for seafood sustainability. We're doing over $3 billion a year in prepared foods and bakery. We're a large restaurant operator. Our stores are very different than our competitors, and we're not standing still. We're continuing to grow, evolve and differentiate ourselves.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: And that's why 800 people were standing in line this morning for our store opening and our 40th store in our North Atlantic this morning.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that, and are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?
componenttext: Starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that, and are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We noticed last, I think, starting in November that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidth to make sur
componenttext: We noticed last, I think, starting in November that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidth to make sure we follow with them and so in key items that we saw Trader Joe's change pricing on, we change pricing as well in certain items to make sure we maintained our proper bandwidth to them. So -- but I don't think that was highly unusual. I think that Trader Joe's and all our other competitors regularly raise and lower prices, depending on -- sometimes, it's just based on -- and generally, it's based on markets. Like a couple of years ago, last year, olive oil crop in Italy was terrible, and Trader Joe's raised their olive oil prices. And this year, olive oil crop is much better in Europe, and everybody is lowering. They lowered their olive oil prices. So that's -- it's kind of the way it works. I don't think it's anything unusual or stand apart from what normally happens.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1, and we'll get even better in Q3 and then even b
componenttext: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1, and we'll get even better in Q3 and then even better in Q4.

componenttext: I think we have to open them up and see. It's -- sure, we project things out, but it's just data. You need actual results. So answer that  question a bit better. We're expecting them to have a good returns on invested capital and to be very profitable for us. So I think they're going to be accretive, but I mean, we've got to get them up to speed.

componenttextpreview: And john, can you remind us, do they leverage off being closed to other Whole Foods stores because you're not clustering the concept based on the stores you've announced so far, and does that make it harder for that chain to be profitable?
componenttext: And john, can you remind us, do they leverage off being closed to other Whole Foods stores because you're not clustering the concept based on the stores you've announced so far, and does that make it harder for that chain to be profitable?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No. Because all the stores -- from an operation -- although the product selection and the pricing and the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices, the actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all t
componenttext: No. No. Because all the stores -- from an operation -- although the product selection and the pricing and the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices, the actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all the advantages of scale that we have in our regions and scales in purchasing, while we've been able to program the pricing, the products, the strategy, the decor, the design, all of that from Austin. So we think we're getting the best of both worlds there.

componenttext: I wanted to ask, as you guys look at your most like loyal customers or like those core shoppers that are in there every week, your regular guys, have you seen any change in their behavior lately? Or is it really those kind of the casual fringe customer that you see a little bit of a drop off with?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. We've got a pretty good read on that, and I'd say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. I mean where the erosion has happened to the extent it has in the comeback will happen is
componenttext: This is Walter. We've got a pretty good read on that, and I'd say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. I mean where the erosion has happened to the extent it has in the comeback will happen is also what a more broadly called the occasional shoppers who come in in different frequencies and for different amounts. That's where, I think, folks maybe perhaps where we see a little bit more inconsistency. So that's the answer.

componenttext: Just one quick follow-up. As far as marketing goes, how have you guys been, you guys, measuring the marketing efficacy or the return on the marketing and is there any thought to go back to like, I think, it was last year you guys did a national branding and that seem to really have an impact to drive some sales for little while. So I'm just curious about how you're viewing that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the investments we're making, as AC said in detail earlier, is obviously the ultimate measure though the sales is traffic in sales, and you're seeing the first chapter of that is units begin to move a little bit, which then leaves from there on th
componenttext: I think the investments we're making, as AC said in detail earlier, is obviously the ultimate measure though the sales is traffic in sales, and you're seeing the first chapter of that is units begin to move a little bit, which then leaves from there on the digital side I'm sure you measure things differently one of the real advantages of Affinity for us we enjoyed at in Philadelphia and seemed to be in Dallas is we actually create personalized offers and connections with customers, so we can actually -- through the tokenize data, we can actually follow what the customers actually doing over time and we can also look at the segments and how we can respond to groups of customers as well. So we're putting in place some really good tools to be able to measure the investments in there, a lot easier to measure there than than they are on, say, the promos we're doing on the right now because that all comes back just to comps in sales and units and that sort of thing. So that's where I would put out those 2.

componenttext: And also, David, Affinity definitely will be in place from day 1 as well.

componenttext: Our final question comes from Kelly Danielle with BMO Capital.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think if I heard you correctly it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at ot
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think if I heard you correctly it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at other ways, maybe just not promotions but more of an EDLP effort as you kind of broaden some of the price investments to other categories? Or how do you get that -- how do you think you're going to get that elasticity, I guess?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year, we probably did a little more in the EDLP. This year we
componenttext: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year, we probably did a little more in the EDLP. This year were kind of doing a combination. We focused, for instance, in the produce department where we've taken certain categories, and we moved the regular pricing. We moved the regular pricing down in a few categories at the same time we've done some really strong promotions and -- because you've got to kind of do both in order to -- the promotions might bring people in, but once they're in the store, they want to see -- the prices the regular price as they look that are really important if they're going to buy be on the promotion. So it's very important to do both but I think ultimately it's really through the category management program that we're going to be able to determine what is actually the right mix between for -- in each department, for adjusting every day pricing for doing more promotion, we're going to be able to really look and see how not only -- were going to be able to do a lot of testing with that to really understand what is the most effective for our customers because, as Walter was saying earlier, answering the question about our kind of more core shoppers than more occasional shoppers, different strategies work for these different customers. So what we're in the process of doing is really refining our ability and giving ourselves the tools we need to understand how we both price and market to the different customer -- customers we have, which will respond to different promotions and prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. And just in terms of the comparisons, if I could just ask one more quick one. They get a lot easier as we move forward here but last year one of the big initiatives was also some of the remodels. I know some of them were more minor, some of them are more major, but how should we think about cycling may be some of the remodels and the impact from those last year?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is David. With 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refresh from a lot of our stores last year, but we're continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would say, in general, thoug
componenttext: Yes. This is David. With 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refresh from a lot of our stores last year, but we're continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would say, in general, though, we're trying to focus on smaller sized remodel that have a bigger sales impact, doing a lot of focus on prepared foods, bakery and also conversion from full-service menus to self-service menu, so we can -- customers are responding well to that, and we're able to get labor inductions at the same time. So that's kind of where we're focusing our capital spending not a new source.

componenttext: Okay. I want to thank everybody for listening in today. We look forward to updating you on our progress in our Q3 earnings call in late July. Take care. Goodbye.
