headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; AC Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Gr
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; AC Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating cash flow and 14% adjusted return on invested capital. We returned $144 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.3 billion in total available capital and $1.1 billion in total debt.
We have committed to a fundamental restructuring of the cost side of our business. We want to appreciate our leadership throughout the company for the strong discipline around managing expenses. We improved salaries and benefits expense by 96 basis points. However, these savings were more than offset by investments in value, technology and marketing as well as deleverage in areas such as occupancy and depreciation. As a result, operating margin declined 29 basis points, excluding a nonroutine supplier credit in the prior year.
We are facing ongoing headwinds from a highly competitive environment as well as cannibalization, but the negative impact on our value -- of our value strategy was the primary factor for the moderation in our comps from Q1. Approximately 80 of the 120 basis point moderation was due to lower increase in average price per item, which is less than 1%, was our lowest increase in 5 years. As we communicated last quarter, our value efforts ramped up in Q2 with increased promotions and broader and deeper price investments in select categories. We have increased our marketing spend to raise the visibility of these investments and are seeing a lift in unit volume. We believe improving our value perception is one of the key components in regaining our sales momentum. While we expect some continued sales impact, we plan to expand our price investments and add weekly deep discount promotions in select categories, which will be actively marketed nationwide. 
Food retailing is evolving at an incredibly fast pace, and consumers have more options than ever before. In addition to becoming more competitive on price, we're making measurable progress and fundamentally evolving our business and providing an enhanced experience for our customers across all platforms before, during and after their visit.  I will now share some highlights of our progress. 
In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we began offering digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market  mobile app. This served as the launch of the first component of our national affinity program, as we now have actionable customer data on a national scale. We have already tripled our number of active users year-over-year and are seeing strong coupon redemptions. Later this summer, customers in Dallas will have access within our app to our newly designed rewards program, which builds upon the best elements of our initial program in Philadelphia, but with lower cost. 
We are committed to expanding our personalization efforts. Once this market -- test market is complete, we intend to roll out our rewards program nationally. 
We intensified our customer acquisition efforts, realizing 30% increase in new customers into our database and a 10% increase in social media followers and engagement in just one quarter. With a rapidly growing customer database and the social imprint approaching 13 million followers, we are continuing to invest in digital strategies to convert our strong online traffic into sales. We're excited to announce that for the first time, customers can now order through our wholefoodsmarket.com website for delivery by Instacart, and we look forward to offering continual enhancements that will provide our customers a more seamless experience over time. Instacart has recently expanded to Orange County, Baltimore, Charlotte and San Antonio, with additional markets coming soon. Collectively, Whole Foods and Instacart deliver fresh groceries to more households in the United States than anyone else. 
We're continuing to hit major milestones in replacing our legacy systems with new technology platforms. We have completed the pilot phase for our new point-of-sale system and are now accelerating the rollout. We are on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. This new unified system will provide many benefits, including operational efficiencies and consolidated item data to support personalized offers, category management and supplier collaboration. 
Our new labor scheduling program is now in place across all of our U.S. customer service teams, and we plan to introduce the program to 2 additional store teams in Q3. With this new program, we are saving administrative time and gaining insight on how to spend labor dollars more efficiently to better serve our customers. The benefits of this new tool will be more fully realized next fiscal year and beyond as we implement it company-wide and incorporate best practices into our labor budgeting process. 
With 19 leases now signed, we're very excited to be just 3 weeks away from opening our first 365 store by Whole Foods Market. Created to complement our Whole Foods Market stores, our new 365 format will offer our same industry-leading standards and dedication to food transparency delivered in a new way. The streamlined format is designed around affordability and convenience and will be supported by enhanced digital experiences. Opening May 25 in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, the 28,000 square foot store will be quickly followed by stores in Lake Oswego, Oregon and Bellevue, Washington. We believe there is a customer demand for both formats. And as the second growth vehicle, 365 allows us to attack the value quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. We're excited to get our first 3 stores open and to learn and evolve from there. 
We are continuing to invest in our team members' development and growth, including creating thousands of new jobs this year. Our 86,000 team members are the essential ingredient in creating our best-in-class customer experience. And we were very pleased to have once again earned a spot on Fortune Magazine's annual list of 100 Best Companies to Work For. We are proud to be one of only 11 companies who have made the list every year since its inception 19 years ago.
Turning now to our updated outlook. We expect to be at or below the low end of our prior sales and earnings per share ranges. While we beat our bottom line expectations in the first half of the year, primarily through better-than-projected leverage in salaries and benefits, our comp trends are yet to stabilize. We're hopeful the comps will improve over the course of the year as our sales-building initiatives gain traction and our comparisons get easier. Beginning in week 11 of Q3, we will anniversary the sharp drop in our comps last year after a weights and measures audit generated negative national media attention. We expect the offsetting impact from our value strategy to continue, however, as we ramp up our price investments and promotions over the remainder of the year. Given our lower sales projections, we now expect SG&A leverage to be more in line with the 19 basis points we have produced year-to-date. This reflects the positive impact of our cost savings initiatives, net of higher depreciation and other cost, including additional marketing and technology investments we have approved for later in the year. Please refer to our press release for more details.
In closing, we continue to make measurable progress in our 9-point strategic plan to evolve our business and hope our remarks today highlight the fundamental transformation that is taking place within our company. We believe we are taking the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term.
We will now take questions. Our call end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera? And then also maybe on
componenttext: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera? And then also maybe on top of that, from a category management standpoint, any updates there that you can share?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, this is a AC. In the pricing, like we've mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments, and what we've been seeing is as we -- and we've ramped it up. We've started to real
componenttext: Vincent, this is a AC. In the pricing, like we've mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments, and what we've been seeing is as we -- and we've ramped it up. We've started to really ramp that up to the year, and in Q2 we made more investments. And we did some large national promotions in produce. We had a big citrus promotion early in the year. We had a really big -- our biggest -- we had organic strawberry promotion, which was the biggest promotion we've ever done. And for the first time, we've had marketing to go with it. We did national marketing around that, and we saw a phenomenal uplift in that. And I'd say that, generally in the areas where we've done these investments, we've been seeing a good uptick in the units. They haven't been as much as to offset the actual investment themselves, but we think that over the long term, as customers get more used to these promos we're doing in these investments, that we'll start to capture a larger percentage of their shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. The big difference is that we're, also with these perishable promotions is, promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally. So we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on social media
componenttext: This is David. The big difference is that we're, also with these perishable promotions is, promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally. So we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on social media with this promotional activity.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. We think this is just lot more visible than what we've done before. You also asked a question about category management, are we staying with that. We're doing a lot of the pick-and-shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll-and-int
componenttext: Right. We think this is just lot more visible than what we've done before. You also asked a question about category management, are we staying with that. We're doing a lot of the pick-and-shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll-and-intent work for each category, hiring category leaders, really doing all that work. And we see that we're going to probably be laying the foundation through the rest of this fiscal year and we're going to be then running a pilot at the beginning of next fiscal year and in the fall. And then once we move beyond that pilot, then we'll start to actually roll out category management later next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You noted in the press release that the average price per item was down. I think it was 80 basis points for the quarter. I just wanted to dig into this number a bit if I could. And forgive me if you answered this already, but trying to really get a sense
componenttext: You noted in the press release that the average price per item was down. I think it was 80 basis points for the quarter. I just wanted to dig into this number a bit if I could. And forgive me if you answered this already, but trying to really get a sense of how much in your view was driven by some deflationary pass-through versus, I guess, what you might consider price investments above and beyond deflation. And again, I know these are hard numbers to quantify, but any sense of that would be helpful.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Glenda. What we were trying to say was that while average price per item was still up in the quarter, the increase was the lowest increase that we have seen in 5 years, and it was 80 basis points lower increase than what we saw in Q1. So does that
componenttext: This is Glenda. What we were trying to say was that while average price per item was still up in the quarter, the increase was the lowest increase that we have seen in 5 years, and it was 80 basis points lower increase than what we saw in Q1. So does that help clarify? But no, we don't have any specific way of, other than that, pointing that out of how much of that was inflation versus change in our actual lower prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: And I appreciate the commentary on digital coupons in your prepared comments. So just overall, as you look at the digital coupon initiatives, how they performed versus your expectations? And at this point, is there any way to look at to see whether they're driving better traffic, [indiscernible] or even more units in a transaction?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jason. We're still in the early innings of this program, but, I think, as a whole, we're very excited about the results. As you saw, we've significantly increased the number of users for our app. So in addition to both using the coupons, we h
componenttext: Yes, this is Jason. We're still in the early innings of this program, but, I think, as a whole, we're very excited about the results. As you saw, we've significantly increased the number of users for our app. So in addition to both using the coupons, we have a more engaged customer that's now leveraging our app for the other utilities that we're providing. Our intention at this point is to continue to add features to our app, inclusive of the digital coupons, leading up to our affinity rollout, which we'll be piloting our next city up in Dallas and then doing our national rollout following that test.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll also say that our suppliers are really excited about the digital coupons, one of very first times at Whole Foods that our suppliers be able to get back data and analytics on the performance of their promotionals at Whole Foods. So agai
componenttext: This is David. I'll also say that our suppliers are really excited about the digital coupons, one of very first times at Whole Foods that our suppliers be able to get back data and analytics on the performance of their promotionals at Whole Foods. So again, we're in the early innings but very exciting.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Philip Terpolilli with Wedbush.
componenttext: We'll go next to Philip Terpolilli with Wedbush.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to focus on procurements. I think you mentioned a couple of things earlier talking about category management and sort of the time line for the next maybe 12 to 24 months. Just kind of curious, maybe the feedback you're getting from some of you
componenttext: Just wanted to focus on procurements. I think you mentioned a couple of things earlier talking about category management and sort of the time line for the next maybe 12 to 24 months. Just kind of curious, maybe the feedback you're getting from some of your suppliers as coming out of Expo West and sort of going into the balance of the year, how we think some of the things that you're doing right now could help the model overall?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's AC again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them have been waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because a
componenttext: It's AC again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them have been waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because a lot of -- they have to go to 11 different regions often and talk to the buyers in each region. So the idea that they can -- they're going to be able to come to just to the global office and talk to the team here, work out the promotions, work out new items, things like that is something that they've -- we're very excited about and glad to hear. We know -- and talking with the suppliers, we formed  supplier advisory groups and we've had some meetings with them. We know that there's a lot of opportunities for us on the cost saving side, for increased promotions aspect. There's a lot of opportunities there for us to reap once we can get really rolling with category management. So we're just seeing -- we're seeing a lot of opportunities.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Bill Kirk of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Bill Kirk of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it looks like there were 3 more leased locations that initially have been signed for regular stores that are now changed to 365. Can you talk about that decision-making process and then, I guess, what would need to be done to pull it off?
componenttext: So it looks like there were 3 more leased locations that initially have been signed for regular stores that are now changed to 365. Can you talk about that decision-making process and then, I guess, what would need to be done to pull it off?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we did announce 3 conversions to Whole Foods from stores in development in Akron, Toledo and Bloomington, Indiana. And then looking at those markets and the size of the stores, we felt that they were better suited to be a 365 location. Particul
componenttext: Yes. Well, we did announce 3 conversions to Whole Foods from stores in development in Akron, Toledo and Bloomington, Indiana. And then looking at those markets and the size of the stores, we felt that they were better suited to be a 365 location. Particularly as we look at the size of stores, we feel that Whole Foods Market stores going forward should be 45,000-plus square feet and the stores that we converted were approximately 30,000 square feet, so more value markets and the right size for 365. So we -- that's why we changed those 2 to 365s.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is David. We haven't started the design process in any of those stores, so there no added expense to change the concept. In fact, the Silver Lake store, which is the very first store, was initially a Whole Foods Market, but we had the concept de
componenttext: Yes, this is David. We haven't started the design process in any of those stores, so there no added expense to change the concept. In fact, the Silver Lake store, which is the very first store, was initially a Whole Foods Market, but we had the concept decided before we signed the lease. So again, just changed the design to be more appropriate to 28,000 square feet.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Edelstein with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Edelstein with Stephens.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could speak more to the cadence in the sales trends during the quarter. We've heard others say it's been choppy month-to-month even week-to-week. And so really if it has bounced around quite a lot, I'm just curious to maybe even drill dow
componenttext: I was hoping you could speak more to the cadence in the sales trends during the quarter. We've heard others say it's been choppy month-to-month even week-to-week. And so really if it has bounced around quite a lot, I'm just curious to maybe even drill down even just into some of the 3-week trends that you've seen so far into the quarter. I mean, just how true of a trend line is that if it has been quite volatile? So any comments there would be helpful.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the improvement that we've seen in the 3 weeks is in the items per basket, which it would be nice if that trend could continue. But it is 3 weeks. It's a very short amount of time, and I would hesitate to draw any conclusions at all from that because
componenttext: Yes, the improvement that we've seen in the 3 weeks is in the items per basket, which it would be nice if that trend could continue. But it is 3 weeks. It's a very short amount of time, and I would hesitate to draw any conclusions at all from that because certainly things do move around quite a bit from week-to-week and with any short period of time.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it. And we're start
componenttext: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it. And we're starting to see some positive results there, and that's going to continue the rest of fiscal year. So we're -- that's going to be a wind to our backs. And so there's been a headwind for the last -- over the last year. Secondly, as we get into the very end of this quarter, we will anniversary the weights and measures audit that happened to us in New York City that went national and definitely took tremendous amount of sales from Whole Foods Market. So when that happens in week 11 of this quarter, we will begin to compare against that. That's going to be a very positive -- that's going to have a very positive effect on comps.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to note that's all settled now. [indiscernible] has been settled for a number of months, so that's a -- it's just looking in a rearview mirror. And also, I think, just as we pick up through end of the fourth quarter, the comparisons in general
componenttext: I just want to note that's all settled now. [indiscernible] has been settled for a number of months, so that's a -- it's just looking in a rearview mirror. And also, I think, just as we pick up through end of the fourth quarter, the comparisons in general just get easier. So the backdrop is a bit choppy in terms of the macroeconomic environment. But I think we're not calling the bottom, but I think there's lots of things that are very encouraging here in terms of a turning point, but too early to call that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your price investments, I knew you've lowered prices on quite a few items this year and there is more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you
componenttext: In terms of your price investments, I knew you've lowered prices on quite a few items this year and there is more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you think that you're getting more bang for your buck so far? And how do you plan to balance the 2 going forward?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One, it's very interesting doing the price investments. The different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investment
componenttext: One, it's very interesting doing the price investments. The different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investments we've done, we're studying the effects, but we're definitely seeing in some markets much more of a response to them than others. We're seeing -- in certain departments, we're seeing a lot more response to them than others. So it's still really early in our price investments where we've purposely designed this to roll out kind of slow and steady so we could learn from it and see what people really respond to. And I think the really exciting thing, though, that we've been doing is that we're really ramping up our marketing behind them, with the digital coupons, with our national flyer now. It's digital. It's going to be -- we're going to experiment with sending it out to -- in some markets, we're going to be mailing it to people's homes. So that, I think, is really the next big step for us because, I think I said earlier, just lowering some prices here and there and doing some promotions, if people don't really know about them, it's not -- we're not going to get the full effect. And so I'm really excited that we've got now -- we're going to have the marketing muscle behind a lot of what we're doing. We're putting that in place so as we do more investments going forward, we've got -- people are going to know about them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is David. I'd also say bragging about our team members. We're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know that we were doing promotions. Now that we were inviting more customers in through advertising
componenttext: And this is David. I'd also say bragging about our team members. We're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know that we were doing promotions. Now that we were inviting more customers in through advertising and digital as well as radio and other mediums that they know if they really go forward on the merchandising that the customers are going to come in, we're adding more customers all the time. So it's kind of a virtuous circle between our team members and our customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. If I could just add one comment, I think the idea is we're doing multiple things to serve the customer who now today's customers come into the store and also searches online and doing lots of preparation for food shopping or even food shop
componenttext: This is Walter. If I could just add one comment, I think the idea is we're doing multiple things to serve the customer who now today's customers come into the store and also searches online and doing lots of preparation for food shopping or even food shopping online. So I think the fact we're reaching out, there's reaching out both through the store, through the price changes there, which you recognize had a longer lag time, so to speak, to return because it takes a trip to convert that to business. But then also offering the digital offering, offering the customer both of those choices, I think we're kind of working the mix of short term, medium term and long term in terms of offering our customers a batter value.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, can you just elaborate on what exactly is fundamentally changing the cost structure and how much of these changes would stay lower if comps were to recover?
componenttext: I guess, first, can you just elaborate on what exactly is fundamentally changing the cost structure and how much of these changes would stay lower if comps were to recover?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still in the path that we laid out before, which is the $300 million over the 2 years. And those I think we talked about primarily in the salaries and benefits area, also in restructuring the organization. So we are on track with that. You can
componenttext: Well, we're still in the path that we laid out before, which is the $300 million over the 2 years. And those I think we talked about primarily in the salaries and benefits area, also in restructuring the organization. So we are on track with that. You can see that reflected in the results here. I'm not sure what more specifics you're looking for with that, Stephen.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and we're redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading to labor effici
componenttext: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and we're redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading to labor efficiencies. We're doing all kinds of stuff. Ken and David might have some additional color.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just point out our leader in distribution.  Bart Beilman is leading our SOP process that we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin. We were seeing a much higher percentage of our inventory movin
componenttext: Yes, I would just point out our leader in distribution.  Bart Beilman is leading our SOP process that we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin. We were seeing a much higher percentage of our inventory moving to the sales floor and out of our back rooms. It's -- we want to talk about it more in the next call, but we really feel that this is going to be a larger reduction in excess inventory that's sitting in the back of our house in addition to a decrease in shrink and also overall improvement in team member morale because the back rooms are in much better shape. So early days but very exciting, and Ken and I are planning on rolling this out as fast as we can across all the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched in wall store, and the power of that is that's simplifying the work flow in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies of production that w
componenttext: And John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched in wall store, and the power of that is that's simplifying the work flow in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies of production that we once had that one person -- those expert person is producing the product that's then distributed to all the other teams in the stores. We think that that's revolutionary in the way in which we'll operate our stores while the higher-quality product, while the experts producing and will take a lot of capital out of the stores that you once had to produce product in multiple places in our stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And new splash, the food tastes great.
componenttext: And new splash, the food tastes great.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Walter, just kind of put a big frame on that. I think if you look at our business, we say we were the ones that put a lot of energy and time into the customer experience, into the retail experience and the store, and we had such a pretty strong regional s
componenttext: Walter, just kind of put a big frame on that. I think if you look at our business, we say we were the ones that put a lot of energy and time into the customer experience, into the retail experience and the store, and we had such a pretty strong regional structure. And I think we're, as a result of this crossroads and transformation we're going through, we're looking at all the systems that supports the processes and how we do work and how we're structured, everything from soup to nuts, really looking at everything in terms of how we can simplify, eliminate redundancies, do work differently, find more savings through just streamlining the organization, and that has just led to some at least to a land of opportunity for Whole Foods that I think perhaps other supermarkets have been there and done that. And I think we're just arriving and realizing there's lots there even as we continue to work hard on stepping up the experience that we're delivering to our customers. So I think that's one big way to think about it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then, I guess, as a follow-up to your last comments on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets have done, and you also have mentioned price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then, I guess, as a follow-up to your last comments on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets have done, and you also have mentioned price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other initiatives, and those also stand pretty similar to what conventional competitors are doing. So maybe you can provide color on some of the other things or aspects that you are trying to implement that will actually differentiate Whole Foods from the group rather than moving more closely to them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we only remain the case we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things that we need to do to be relevant in the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've all seen the changes. But we're -- that's not our -- if y
componenttext: Well, we only remain the case we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things that we need to do to be relevant in the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've all seen the changes. But we're -- that's not our -- if you look at our 9-point plan and as we continue to talk about it today, we're putting a lot of emphasis on continuing to provide new experiences, different experiences. We're opening up all the digital platforms to able to reach our customers in new ways, in different ways than we've been able to do previously. So really this is about much more than just price investments. I recognize many others have done those as well, and that's part of being in a grocery retail business. You're constantly chewing up not just on these conference calls but you're chewing up every day in the marketplace as markets change. But hopefully what you're running out of this group is a much broader thought process around how we think we can set ourselves apart, continue to differentiate and gain some momentum. And as AC mentioned, the promotions put the marketing around that, which also talks about the quality of their product, the opening up some of these platforms to offer new content and new options for customers. For example, they can shop for food now through wholefoodsmarket.com. That's a new thing we haven't been able to do before. And so in all these ways, I think we're trying to -- and the 365 John mentioned is, of course, another growth opportunity for the company and serving the customers in new ways. So I think you take the whole big picture and you say there is a lot going on here to regain momentum.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ken here. l also want to share the fact that our commitment around culinary is really what separates us compared to the competitions. And so we have the leadership now in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new
componenttext: This is Ken here. l also want to share the fact that our commitment around culinary is really what separates us compared to the competitions. And so we have the leadership now in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new programs. We have the friends of Whole Foods Market which are bringing really great restaurant concepts into our stores and having these partnerships that create a unique experience from a culinary standpoint. That really is, by far, above anything that we're competing against right now. So we really feel like the renewed focus on culinary in our stores is big, big differentiator for us as a company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365 stores that you have to go and see, and we've got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge opport
componenttext: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365 stores that you have to go and see, and we've got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge opportunity for us. That's going to help set us apart. And then all of our stores continue to innovate. You go into our new stores, go into the downtown L.A. or take a trip to Southern California, in 3 weeks, we're opening a new brand. Go see our downtown L.A. store while you're at it. And we're opening great new stores, are doing tremendous sales, tremendous volumes. We'll continue to innovate from an operational standpoint. Everyone is continuing to try to copy us because the innovations are still occurring at Whole Foods Market. That's how we're differentiating. Now if you mean -- sure, we're copying some of the things what some of our competitors do. We're learning from everybody. And competitors who're doing some things better than Whole Foods, we certainly want to -- we're going to learn from that, make our company better. But we are not standing still. In fact, I would argue that we're probably undergoing far more evolution in our company than ever before. And the final and probably the most important point, nobody, nobody comes close to matching our quality standards. We're the only one -- only supermarket in America that's 100% cage-free eggs. That is animal welfare system that's top-rated in Greenpeace for seafood sustainability. We're doing over $3 billion a year in prepared foods and bakery. We're a large restaurant operator. Our stores are very different than our competitors', and we're not standing still. We're continuing to grow, evolve and differentiate ourselves.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's why 800 people were standing in line this morning for our Westford store opening and our 40th store in our North Atlantic this morning..
componenttext: And that's why 800 people were standing in line this morning for our Westford store opening and our 40th store in our North Atlantic this morning..

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Wiltamuth. [indiscernible] are starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that? And are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?
componenttext: It's Mark Wiltamuth. [indiscernible] are starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that? And are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We noticed last, I think starting in November, that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets, and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidths to make s
componenttext: We noticed last, I think starting in November, that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets, and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidths to make sure that we're -- that we follow with them. And so in key items that we saw Trader Joe's change pricing on, we change pricing as well on certain items to make sure we maintained our proper bandwidth to them. So -- but I don't think that was highly unusual. I think that Trader Joe's and all our other competitors regularly raise and lower prices, depending on -- some times, it's just based on -- and generally it's based on markets. Like a couple of years ago, last year, olive oil crop in Italy was terrible, and Trader Joe's raised their olive oil prices. And this year, olive oil crop is much better in Europe, and everybody is lowering. They lowered their olive oil prices. So -- I mean that's -- it's just -- it's kind of the way it works. I don't think it was anything unusual or stand apart from what normally happens.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the -- following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the -- following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1 and will get even better in Q3 and then even bet
componenttext: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1 and will get even better in Q3 and then even better in Q4.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robby Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robby Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Just on 365, I was hoping -- could you remind us -- 19 stores you're going to be opening, assuming these go well, and it sounds like they could, can you remind us the expectation, if this goes really well, the kind of profit contribution 365 could have? Are these expected to be higher-margin stores than the core Whole Foods stores? Just maybe a little bit of a -- maybe some of the metrics you'll be looking at when you decide how many to open over the next few years?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have to open them up and see. It's -- sure, we project things out, but it's just -- you need data. You need actual results. So we'll be able to answer that question a lot better -- I suspect, when we come to our fourth quarter earnings call in
componenttext: I think we have to open them up and see. It's -- sure, we project things out, but it's just -- you need data. You need actual results. So we'll be able to answer that question a lot better -- I suspect, when we come to our fourth quarter earnings call in November, then we'll have some hard data on the first 3 openings and we'll be able to give you some much more concrete information as opposed to just sort of speculation. We're expecting them to have a good returns on invested capital and to be very profitable for us. So yes, we think they're going to be accretive, but -- I mean, we got to get them up to speed.

componenttext: And John, can you remind us do they leverage off being close to other Whole Foods stores? Because you're not clustering the concept based on the stores you've announced so far, and does that make it harder for that chain to be profitable?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, because all the stores are being -- from an -- although the product selection, the pricing, the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices. The actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all the adv
componenttext: No, no, because all the stores are being -- from an -- although the product selection, the pricing, the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices. The actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all the advantages of scale that we have in our regions and scales in purchasing, while we've been able to program the pricing, the products, the strategy, the decor, the design, all of that from Austin. So we think we're getting the best of both worlds there.

componenttext: My question also has to do with 365. I'm curious how you'll market that concept, maybe you're doing it already or once it opens up. And are you seeing anything now, whether it's social media buzz or otherwise, that gives you confidence that the demand is out there?

componenttext: This is David and Ken, we'll both answer that. We can tell you that everybody is very curious about this, so it's definitely not going to be a secret. We're also going to be doing some traditional stuff, advertising in the L.A. Times as well as lots of social media, working with Buzzfeed and few other groups. Anything else?

componenttext: I wanted to ask, as you guys look at your most like loyal customers or even like those core shoppers that they are in there every week there as your regular guys. Have you seen any change in their behavior lately? Or is it really those kind of the casual fringe customer that you've see a little bit of a drop-off with?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. Yes -- no, we're -- we've got a pretty good read on that, and I would say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who continue to stay with us and stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. Yes, I mean, where the erosion has ha
componenttext: This is Walter. Yes -- no, we're -- we've got a pretty good read on that, and I would say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who continue to stay with us and stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. Yes, I mean, where the erosion has happened to the extent it has and the comeback will happen is also what we more broadly call the occasional shoppers who come in at different frequencies and for different amounts, and that's where I think folks may be perhaps be where we see a little bit more inconsistency. So that's the answer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one quick follow-up. As far as marketing goes, how have you guys been, I guess, measuring the marketing efficacy or the return on the marketing? And is there any thought to go back to like -- I think it was last year you guys did the nationa
componenttext: And then just one quick follow-up. As far as marketing goes, how have you guys been, I guess, measuring the marketing efficacy or the return on the marketing? And is there any thought to go back to like -- I think it was last year you guys did the national branding, and that seem to really have an impact to drive some sales for little while. So I was just curious about how you're viewing that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got something up our sleeves but nothing to announce today other than we're working on something, and we're excited about it. I think we're -- when I get the 365 stores launched, get some data on that, get our national affinity program launched, we
componenttext: We've got something up our sleeves but nothing to announce today other than we're working on something, and we're excited about it. I think we're -- when I get the 365 stores launched, get some data on that, get our national affinity program launched, we want to get some pieces in place, and as we get those in place, and I think we will launch a more broad-based marketing strategy. So we'll have probably [indiscernible] something to talk about in Q4 about that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the investments we're making in, as AC detail earlier, it's I think the -- obviously the ultimate measure of those are sales. It's traffic and sales, and we are seeing the first chapter of that, which is kind of the units begin to move a littl
componenttext: And I think the investments we're making in, as AC detail earlier, it's I think the -- obviously the ultimate measure of those are sales. It's traffic and sales, and we are seeing the first chapter of that, which is kind of the units begin to move a little bit, which then leads from there on the digital side, obviously you can measure things differently. One of the real advantages of affinity for us, and we enjoy that in Philadelphia and seem to be in Dallas is that we actually create personalized offers and connections with customers. And so we can actually -- through the tokenize data, we can actually follow what the customer's actually doing over time. And then we can also look at the segments and how we can respond to groups of customers as well. So we're putting in place some really good tools to be able to measure. The investments here are a lot easier to measure there than they are on, say, on the promos that we're doing on the perishables right now because that kind of all comes back just to comps and sales and units and that sort of thing. So that's where I would -- those 2.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think, if I heard you correctly, it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think, if I heard you correctly, it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at other ways, maybe just not promotions but more of an EDLP effort, as you kind of broadened some of the price investments to other categories? Or how do you get that -- how do you think you are going to get that elasticity, I guess?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year we probably did a little more in the EDLP. This year we'
componenttext: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year we probably did a little more in the EDLP. This year we're kind of doing a combination. We focused, for instance, in the produce department where we've taken certain categories and we moved the regular pricing. We moved the regular pricing down in a few categories. At the same time, we've done some really strong promotions. And because you really you got to kind of do both in order to -- the promotions might bring people in, but then once they're in the store, they want to see -- the regular prices they look at are really important for us to going to buy beyond the promotion. So it's very important to do both. But I think, ultimately, it's really through the category management program that we're going to be able to determine what is actually the right mix between -- in each department for adjusting everyday pricing, for doing more promotion. We're going to be able to really look and see how not only -- and we're going to be able to do a lot of testing with that to really understand what is that most effective for our customers. Because as Walter was saying earlier, answering the question about our kind of more core shoppers than more occasional shoppers, different strategies work for these different customers. So what we're in a process of doing is really refining our ability and giving ourselves the tools we need to understand how we both price and market to the different customer -- customers we have, which will respond to different promotions and prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just in terms of the comparisons, if I could just ask one more quick one. They're getting a lot easier as we move forward here. But last year, one of the big initiatives was also some of the remodels. I know some of them were more mino
componenttext: That's helpful. And just in terms of the comparisons, if I could just ask one more quick one. They're getting a lot easier as we move forward here. But last year, one of the big initiatives was also some of the remodels. I know some of them were more minor, some of them are more major. But how should we think about cycling maybe some of the remodels and the impact from those last year?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is David. We are in a -- now with 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refreshment in a lot of our stores last year, but we were continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would
componenttext: Yes, this is David. We are in a -- now with 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refreshment in a lot of our stores last year, but we were continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would say in general, though, we're trying to focus on smaller-size remodel that have a bigger sales impact, doing a lot of focus on prepared foods, bakery and also conversion from full-service venues to self-service venues so we can -- customers are responding well to that, and we are able to get labor inductions at the same time. So that's kind of where we're focusing our capital spending, not on new stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I want to thank everybody for listening in today, and we look forward to updating you on our progress on our Q3 earnings call in late July. If you get a chance and you're in L.A., check out our Silver Lake store, which opens in 3 weeks. Maybe go to
componenttext: Okay, I want to thank everybody for listening in today, and we look forward to updating you on our progress on our Q3 earnings call in late July. If you get a chance and you're in L.A., check out our Silver Lake store, which opens in 3 weeks. Maybe go to the downtown L.A. store. You can see the contrast right there between what Whole Foods Market is evolving to and what the new 365 format will be. Okay, everybody. We'll talk to you soon. Take care. Bye.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered record sales of $3.7 billion and produced a healthy bottom line with a 9.5% EBITDA margin, $0.44 in diluted earnings per share, a record $343 million of operating cash flow and 14% adjusted return on invested capital. We returned $144 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.3 billion in total available capital and $1.1 billion in total debt.
We have committed to a fundamental restructuring of the cost side of our business. We want to appreciate our leadership throughout the company for their strong discipline around managing expenses. We improved salaries and benefits expense by 96 basis points. However, these savings were more than offset by investments in value, technology and marketing as well as deleverage in areas such as occupancy and depreciation. As a result, operating margin declined 29 basis points, excluding a nonroutine supplier credit in the prior year.
We are facing ongoing headwinds from a highly competitive environment as well as cannibalization, but the negative impact on our value -- of our value strategy was the primary factor for the moderation in our comps from Q1. Approximately 80 of the 120 basis point moderation was due to lower increase in average price per item, which is less than 1%, was our lowest increase in 5 years. As we communicated last quarter, our value efforts ramped up in Q2 with increased promotions and broader and deeper price investments in select categories. We have increased our marketing spend to raise the visibility of these investments and are seeing a lift in unit volume. We believe improving our value perception is one of the key components in regaining our sales momentum. While we expect some continued sales impact, we plan to expand our price investments and add weekly deep-discount promotions in select categories, which will be actively marketed nationwide. 
Food retailing is evolving at an incredibly fast pace, and consumers have more options than ever before. In addition to becoming more competitive on price, we're making measurable progress in fundamentally evolving our business and providing an enhanced experience for our customers across all platforms before, during and after their visit.  I will now share some highlights of our progress. 
In our ongoing effort to better understand and offer more value to our customers, we began offering digital coupons within our Whole Foods Market mobile app. This served as the launch of the first component of our national Affinity program, as we now have actionable customer data on a national scale. We have already tripled our number of active users year-over-year and are seeing strong coupon redemptions. Later this summer, customers in Dallas will have access within our app to our newly designed rewards program, which builds upon the best elements of our initial program in Philadelphia, but with lower cost. 
We are committed to expanding our personalization efforts. Once this market -- test market is complete, we intend to roll out our rewards program nationally. 
We intensified our customer acquisition efforts, realizing 30% increase in new customers into our database and a 10% increase in social media followers and engagement in just one quarter. With a rapidly growing customer database and the social imprint approaching 13 million followers, we are continuing to invest in digital strategies to convert our strong online traffic into sales. We're excited to announce that for the first time, customers can now order through our wholefoodsmarket.com website for delivery by Instacart, and we look forward to offering continual enhancements that will provide our customers a more seamless experience over time. Instacart has recently expanded to Orange County, Baltimore, Charlotte and San Antonio, with additional markets coming soon. Collectively, Whole Foods and Instacart deliver fresh groceries to more households in the United States than anyone else. 
We're continuing to hit major milestones in replacing our legacy systems with new technology platforms. We have completed the pilot phase for our new point-of-sale system and are now accelerating the rollout. We are on track to be in all of our U.S. stores before the end of the calendar year. This new unified system will provide many benefits, including operational efficiencies and consolidated item data to support personalized offers, category management and supplier collaboration. 
Our new labor scheduling program is now in place across all of our U.S. customer service teams, and we plan to introduce the program to 2 additional store teams in Q3. With this new program, we are saving administrative time and gaining insight on how to spend labor dollars more efficiently to better serve our customers. The benefits of this new tool will be more fully realized next fiscal year and beyond as we implement it company-wide and incorporate best practices into our labor budgeting process. 
With 19 leases now signed, we're very excited to be just 3 weeks away from opening our first 365 store by Whole Foods Market. Created to complement our Whole Foods Market stores, our new 365 format will offer our same industry-leading standards and dedication to food transparency delivered in a new way. The streamlined format is designed around affordability and convenience and will be supported by enhanced digital experiences. Opening May 25 in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, the 28,000-square-foot store will be quickly followed by stores in Lake Oswego, Oregon, and Bellevue, Washington. We believe there is a customer demand for both formats. And as the second growth vehicle, 365 allows us to attack the value quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. We're excited to get our first 3 stores open and to learn and evolve from there. 
We are continuing to invest in our team members' development and growth, including creating thousands of new jobs this year. Our 86,000 team members are the essential ingredient in creating our best-in-class customer experience. And we were very pleased to have once again earned a spot on Fortune Magazine's annual list of The 100 Best Companies to Work For. We are proud to be one of only 11 companies who have made the list every year since its inception 19 years ago.
Turning now to our updated outlook. We expect to be at or below the low end of our prior sales and earnings per share ranges. While we beat our bottom line expectations in the first half of the year, primarily through better-than-projected leverage in salaries and benefits, our comp trends have yet to stabilize. We're hopeful the comps will improve over the course of the year as our sales-building initiatives gain traction and our comparisons get easier. Beginning in week 11 of Q3, we will anniversary the sharp drop in our comps last year after a weights-and-measures audit generated negative national media attention. We expect the offsetting impact from our value strategy to continue, however, as we ramp up our price investments and promotions over the remainder of the year. Given our lower sales projections, we now expect SG&A leverage to be more in line with the 19 basis points we have produced year-to-date. This reflects the positive impact of our cost savings initiatives, net of higher depreciation and other costs, including additional marketing and technology investments we have approved for later in the year. Please refer to our press release for more details.
In closing, we continue to make measurable progress in our 9-point strategic plan to evolve our business and hope our remarks today highlight the fundamental transformation that is taking place within our company. We believe we are taking the right steps to grow and improve our company and produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term.
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
