componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera? And then also maybe on
componenttext: I just wanted to ask if you can give us a bit more color. In terms of the pricing initiatives that you're having, what are customers seemingly at least responding most to, whether it's by category, whether it's by medium, et cetera? And then also maybe on top of that, from a category management standpoint, any updates there that you can share?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.C.?
componenttext: A.C.?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, this is A.C. In the pricing, like we've mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments. And what we've been seeing is as we -- and we've ramped it up. We've started to reall
componenttext: Vincent, this is A.C. In the pricing, like we've mentioned on our last call, a lot of our investments this year have been in the perimeter in our perishable departments. And what we've been seeing is as we -- and we've ramped it up. We've started to really ramp that up through the year, and in Q2 we made more investments. And we did some large national promotions in produce. We had a big citrus promotion early in the year. We had a really big -- our biggest -- we had our organic strawberry promotion, which was the biggest promotion we've ever done. And for the first time, we've had marketing to go with it. We did national marketing around that, and we saw a phenomenal uplift in that. And I'd say that, generally in the areas where we've done these investments, we've been seeing a good uptick in the units. They haven't been as much as to offset the actual investment themselves, but we think that over the long term, as customers get more used to these promos we're doing and these investments, that we'll start to capture a larger percentage of their shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. The big difference is that we're -- also with these perishable promotions, is we're promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally. So we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on soci
componenttext: This is David. The big difference is that we're -- also with these perishable promotions, is we're promoting across all 450 stores as opposed to the regions doing the promos regionally. So we're getting a much bigger lift and a much bigger imprint on social media with this promotional activity.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. We think this is just lot more visible than what we've done before. You also asked a question about category management, where we stand with that. We're doing a lot of the pick-and-shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll-and-int
componenttext: Right. We think this is just lot more visible than what we've done before. You also asked a question about category management, where we stand with that. We're doing a lot of the pick-and-shovel work right now, determining the categories, the roll-and-intent work for each category, hiring category leaders, really doing all that work. And we see that we're going to probably be laying the foundation through the rest of this fiscal year, and we're going to be then running a pilot at the beginning of next fiscal year and in the fall. And then once we move beyond that pilot, then we'll start to actually roll out category management later next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You noted in the press release that the average price per item was down. I think it was 80 basis points for the quarter. I just wanted to dig into this number a bit if I could. And forgive me if you answered this already, but trying to really get a sense
componenttext: You noted in the press release that the average price per item was down. I think it was 80 basis points for the quarter. I just wanted to dig into this number a bit if I could. And forgive me if you answered this already, but trying to really get a sense of how much in your view was driven by some deflationary pass-through versus, I guess, what you might consider price investments above and beyond deflation. And again, I know these are hard numbers to quantify, but any sense of that would be helpful.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Glenda. What we were trying to say was that while average price per item was still up in the quarter, the increase was the lowest increase that we have seen in 5 years, and it was 80 basis points lower increase than what we saw in Q1. So does that
componenttext: This is Glenda. What we were trying to say was that while average price per item was still up in the quarter, the increase was the lowest increase that we have seen in 5 years, and it was 80 basis points lower increase than what we saw in Q1. So does that help clarify? But no, we don't have any specific way of, other than that, pointing that out of how much of that was inflation versus change in our actual lower prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I appreciate the commentary on digital coupons in your prepared comments. So just overall, as you look at the digital coupon initiatives, how have they performed versus your expectations? And at this point, is there any way to look at to see whether t
componenttext: And I appreciate the commentary on digital coupons in your prepared comments. So just overall, as you look at the digital coupon initiatives, how have they performed versus your expectations? And at this point, is there any way to look at to see whether they're driving better traffic, basket size or even more units in a transaction?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jason. We're still in the early innings of this program, but, I think, as a whole, we're very excited about the results. As you saw, we've significantly increased the number of users for our app. So in addition to both using the coupons, we h
componenttext: Yes, this is Jason. We're still in the early innings of this program, but, I think, as a whole, we're very excited about the results. As you saw, we've significantly increased the number of users for our app. So in addition to both using the coupons, we have a more engaged customer that's now leveraging our app for the other utilities that we're providing. Our intention at this point is to continue to add features to our app, inclusive of the digital coupons, leading up to our Affinity rollout, which we'll be piloting our next city up in Dallas and then doing our national rollout following that test.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll also say that our suppliers are really excited about the digital coupons, one of very first times at Whole Foods that our suppliers will be able to get back data and analytics on the performance of their promotionals at Whole Foods. So
componenttext: This is David. I'll also say that our suppliers are really excited about the digital coupons, one of very first times at Whole Foods that our suppliers will be able to get back data and analytics on the performance of their promotionals at Whole Foods. So again, we're in the early innings, but very exciting.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Philip Terpolilli with Wedbush.
componenttext: We'll go next to Philip Terpolilli with Wedbush.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to focus on procurements. I think you mentioned a couple of things earlier talking about category management and sort of the time line for the next maybe 12 to 24 months. Just kind of curious, maybe the feedback you're getting from some of you
componenttext: Just wanted to focus on procurements. I think you mentioned a couple of things earlier talking about category management and sort of the time line for the next maybe 12 to 24 months. Just kind of curious, maybe the feedback you're getting from some of your suppliers as -- coming out of Expo West and sort of going into the balance of the year. How we think some of the things that you're doing right now could help the model overall.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's A.C. again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them have been waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because
componenttext: It's A.C. again. Suppliers were very excited when we talked with the -- about 1,000 of them at Expo West. A lot of them have been waiting for us to do something like this. We've been a very inefficient customer to deal with for a lot of suppliers because a lot of -- they have to go to 11 different regions often and talk to the buyers in each region. So the idea that they can -- they're going to be able to come to just to the global office and talk to the team here, work out the promotions, work out new items, things like that, is something that they were very excited about and glad to hear. We know -- in talking with the suppliers, we formed supplier advisory groups and we've had some meetings with them. We know that there's a lot of opportunities for us on the cost saving side, for increased promotions aspect. There's a lot of opportunities there for us to reap once we can get really rolling with category management. So we're just seeing -- we're seeing a lot of opportunities.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Bill Kirk of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Bill Kirk of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it looks like there were 3 more leased locations that initially had been signed for regular stores that are now changed to 365. Can you talk about that decision-making process and then, I guess, what would need to be done to pull it off?
componenttext: So it looks like there were 3 more leased locations that initially had been signed for regular stores that are now changed to 365. Can you talk about that decision-making process and then, I guess, what would need to be done to pull it off?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we did announce 3 conversions to Whole Foods from stores in development in Akron, Toledo and Bloomington, Indiana. And then looking at those markets and the size of the stores, we felt that they were better suited to be a 365 location. Particul
componenttext: Yes. Well, we did announce 3 conversions to Whole Foods from stores in development in Akron, Toledo and Bloomington, Indiana. And then looking at those markets and the size of the stores, we felt that they were better suited to be a 365 location. Particularly as we look at the size of stores, we feel that Whole Foods Market stores going forward should be 45,000-plus square feet, and the stores that we converted were approximately 30,000 square feet, so more value markets and the right size for 365. So we -- that's why we changed those 2 (sic) [ 3 ] into 365s.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is David. We haven't started the design process in any of those stores, so there no added expense to change the concept. In fact, the Silver Lake store, which is the very first store, was initially a Whole Foods Market, but we hadn't had the con
componenttext: Yes, this is David. We haven't started the design process in any of those stores, so there no added expense to change the concept. In fact, the Silver Lake store, which is the very first store, was initially a Whole Foods Market, but we hadn't had the concept decided before we signed that lease. So again, just changed the design to be more appropriate to 28,000 square feet.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Edelstein with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Edelstein with Stephens.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could speak more to the cadence in the sales trends during the quarter. We've heard others say it's been choppy month-to-month, even week-to-week. And so really if it has bounced around quite a lot, I'm just curious to maybe even drill do
componenttext: I was hoping you could speak more to the cadence in the sales trends during the quarter. We've heard others say it's been choppy month-to-month, even week-to-week. And so really if it has bounced around quite a lot, I'm just curious to maybe even drill down even just into some of the 3-week trends that you've seen so far into the quarter. I mean, just how true of a trend line is that if it has been quite volatile? So any comments there would be helpful.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the improvement that we've seen in the 3 weeks is in the items per basket, which it would be nice if that trend could continue. But it is 3 weeks. It's a very short amount of time, and I would hesitate to draw any conclusions at all from that because
componenttext: Yes, the improvement that we've seen in the 3 weeks is in the items per basket, which it would be nice if that trend could continue. But it is 3 weeks. It's a very short amount of time, and I would hesitate to draw any conclusions at all from that because certainly things do move around quite a bit from week-to-week and with any short period of time.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it. And we're start
componenttext: We do think a couple of good things are going to happen later on in this quarter. So as every month passes, the cannibalization impacts in Chicago from our 10 new Dominick's stores we opened last fiscal year moderates as we anniversary it. And we're starting to see some positive results there, and that's going to continue the rest of the fiscal year. So we're -- that's going to be a wind to our backs. And so there's been a headwind for the last -- over the last year. Secondly, as we get into the very end of this quarter, we will anniversary the weights-and-measures audit that happened to us in New York City that went national and definitely took a tremendous amount of sales from Whole Foods Market. So when that happens in week 11 of this quarter, we will begin to compare against that. That's going to be a very positive -- that's going to have a very positive effect on comps.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to note that's all settled now, too, as well. That has been settled for a number of months, so that's a -- it's just looking in the rearview mirror. And also, I think, just as we pick up through into the fourth quarter, the comparisons in gene
componenttext: I just want to note that's all settled now, too, as well. That has been settled for a number of months, so that's a -- it's just looking in the rearview mirror. And also, I think, just as we pick up through into the fourth quarter, the comparisons in general just get easier. So the backdrop is a bit choppy in terms of the macroeconomic environment. But I think we're not calling the bottom, but I think there's lots of things that are very encouraging here in terms of a turning point, but too early to call that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your price investments, I knew you've lowered prices on quite a few items this year and there is more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you
componenttext: In terms of your price investments, I knew you've lowered prices on quite a few items this year and there is more to come. I'm curious how you think about the consumer response for price investments versus digital coupons and promo activity. Where do you think that you're getting more bang for your buck so far? And how do you plan to balance the 2 going forward?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One, it's very interesting doing the price investments. The different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular, like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investmen
componenttext: One, it's very interesting doing the price investments. The different -- we see different customers react to different things. The digital coupons have been very, very popular, like with our Affinity customers in Philadelphia. And the price item investments we've done, we're studying the effects, but we're definitely seeing in some markets much more of a response to them than others. We're seeing -- in certain departments, we're seeing a lot more response to them than others. So it's still really early in our price investments, where we've purposely designed this to roll out kind of slow and steady so we could learn from it and see what people really respond to. And I think the really exciting thing, though, that we've been doing is that we're really ramping up our marketing behind them. With the digital coupons, with our national flyer now, it's digital. It's going to be -- we're going to experiment with sending it out to -- in some markets, we're going to be mailing it to people's homes. So that, I think, is really the next big step for us because, I think I said earlier, just lowering some prices here and there and doing some promotions, if people don't really know about them, it's not -- we're not going to get the full effect. And so I'm really excited that we've got now -- we're going to have the marketing muscle behind a lot of what we're doing. We're putting that in place so as we do more investments going forward, we've got -- people are going to know about them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is David. I'd also say, bragging about our team members, we're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know that when we're doing promotions, now that we were inviting more customers in through advertis
componenttext: And this is David. I'd also say, bragging about our team members, we're the best merchandisers in any supermarket in the United States. So our team members know that when we're doing promotions, now that we were inviting more customers in through advertising and digital as well as radio and other mediums, that they know if they really go for it on the merchandising that the customers are going to come in. We're adding more customers all the time, so it's kind of a virtuous circle between our team members and our customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. If I could just add one comment, I think the idea is we're doing multiple things to serve the customer, who now -- today's customers come into the store but also searching online and doing lots of preparation for food shopping or even food
componenttext: This is Walter. If I could just add one comment, I think the idea is we're doing multiple things to serve the customer, who now -- today's customers come into the store but also searching online and doing lots of preparation for food shopping or even food shopping online. So I think the fact we're reaching out, there's reaching out both through the store, through the price changes there, which you recognize had a longer lag time, so to speak, to return because it takes a trip to convert that to business. But then also offering the digital offering, offering the customer both of those choices, I think we're kind of working the mix of short term, medium term and long term in terms of offering our customers a better value.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, can you just elaborate on what exactly is fundamentally changing the cost structure and how much of these changes would stay lower if comps were to recover?
componenttext: I guess, first, can you just elaborate on what exactly is fundamentally changing the cost structure and how much of these changes would stay lower if comps were to recover?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still in the path that we laid out before, which is the $300 million over the 2 years. And those I think we talked about primarily in the salaries and benefits area, also in restructuring the organization. So we are on track with that. You can
componenttext: Well, we're still in the path that we laid out before, which is the $300 million over the 2 years. And those I think we talked about primarily in the salaries and benefits area, also in restructuring the organization. So we are on track with that. You can see that reflected in the results here. I'm not sure what more specifics you're looking for with that, Stephen.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and we're redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading to labor effici
componenttext: We're looking at every aspect of the business, and we're redesigning our back rooms in cases. We're putting in standard operating procedures across the company. We are -- we're pioneering one central kitchen in our stores, which is leading to labor efficiencies. We're doing all kinds of stuff. Ken and David might have some additional color.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just point out our leader in distribution, Bart Beilman, who's leading our SOP process there, we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin, where we're seeing a much higher percentage of our invent
componenttext: Yes, I would just point out our leader in distribution, Bart Beilman, who's leading our SOP process there, we're seeing huge results in our test regions in the mid-Atlantic and also here in Austin, where we're seeing a much higher percentage of our inventory moving to the sales floor and out of our back rooms. It's -- we want to talk about it more in the next call, but we really feel that this is going to be a larger reduction in excess inventory that's sitting in the back of our house in addition to a decrease in shrink and also overall improvement in team member morale because the back rooms are in much better shape. So early days, but very exciting, and Ken and I are planning on rolling this out as fast as we can across all the stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched in our Wall store, and the power of that is it's simplifying the work flow in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies of production that
componenttext: And John mentioned -- this is Ken here. John mentioned the central kitchen that we just launched in our Wall store, and the power of that is it's simplifying the work flow in our store so that we're not -- we don't have the redundancies of production that we once had, that one person, the most expert person is producing the product that's then distributed to all the other teams in the stores. We think that that's revolutionary in the way in which we'll operate our stores. We'll have a higher-quality product. We'll have experts producing it and we'll take a lot of capital out of the stores that we once had to produce product in multiple places in our stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And news flash, the food tastes great.
componenttext: And news flash, the food tastes great.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. Just to kind of put a big frame on that. I think if you look at our business, we say we were the ones that put a lot of energy and time into the customer experience, into the retail experience and the store experience, and we had such a pr
componenttext: This is Walter. Just to kind of put a big frame on that. I think if you look at our business, we say we were the ones that put a lot of energy and time into the customer experience, into the retail experience and the store experience, and we had such a pretty strong regional structure. And I think we're, as a result of this crossroads and transformation we're going through, we're looking at all the systems that supports the processes and how we do work and how we're structured, everything from soup to nuts, really looking at everything in terms of how we can simplify, eliminate redundancies, do work differently, find more savings through just streamlining the organization, and that has just led to some -- it leads to a land of opportunity for Whole Foods that I think perhaps other supermarkets have been there and done that. And I think we're just arriving and realizing there's lots there even as we continue to work hard on stepping up the experience that we're delivering to our customers. So I think that's one big way to think about it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then, I guess, as a follow-up to your last comments on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets have done, and you also have mentioned price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then, I guess, as a follow-up to your last comments on you're kind of doing a lot of the things that the other supermarkets have done, and you also have mentioned price investments, the loyalty program as it relates to the other initiatives, and those also sound pretty similar to what conventional competitors are doing. So maybe you can provide color on some of the other things or aspects that you are trying to implement that will actually differentiate Whole Foods from the group rather than moving more closely to them.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we only ever made the case -- we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things that we need to do to be relevant in the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've all seen the changes. But we're -- that's not our -
componenttext: Well, we only ever made the case -- we're talking about price relevancy. We're talking about doing the things that we need to do to be relevant in the marketplace that we're now competing in today. We've all seen the changes. But we're -- that's not our -- if you look at our 9-point plan and as we continue to talk about it today, we're putting a lot of emphasis on continuing to provide new experiences, different experiences. We're opening up all the digital platforms to able to reach our customers in new ways, in different ways than we've been able to do previously. So really this is about much more than just price investments. I recognize many others have done those as well, and that's part of being in the grocery retail business. You're constantly truing up not just on these conference calls, but you're truing up every day in the marketplace as markets change. But hopefully what you're hearing out of this group is a much broader thought process around how we think we can set ourselves apart, continue to differentiate and gain some momentum. And as A.C. mentioned, the promotions put the marketing around that, which also talks about the quality of the product, the opening up some of these platforms to offer new content and new options for customers. For example, they can shop for food now through wholefoodsmarket.com. That's a new thing we haven't been able to do before. And so in all these ways, I think we're trying to -- and the 365 John mentioned is, of course, another growth opportunity for the company and serving the customers in new ways. So I think you take the whole big picture and you say there is a lot going on here to regain momentum.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ken here. I also want to share the fact that our commitment around culinary is really what separates us compared to the competition. And so we have the leadership now in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new
componenttext: This is Ken here. I also want to share the fact that our commitment around culinary is really what separates us compared to the competition. And so we have the leadership now in the company to bring that focus and that commitment to really developing new programs. We have the Friends of Whole Foods Market, which are bringing really great restaurant concepts into our stores and having these partnerships that create a unique experience from a culinary standpoint. That really is, by far, above anything that we're competing against right now. So we really feel like the renewed focus on culinary in our stores is a big, big differentiator for us as a company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365, stores that you have to go and see, and we've got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge oppor
componenttext: Yes, John here. So how are we differentiated? I mean, a, we're going to create a whole new brand, 365, stores that you have to go and see, and we've got 19 of those signed up and many more in negotiation right now. We think that's going to be a huge opportunity for us. That's going to help set us apart. And then all of our stores continue to innovate. You go into our new stores, go into the downtown L.A. or take a trip to Southern California, in 3 weeks, we're opening a new brand. Go see our downtown L.A. store while you're at it. And we're opening great new stores that are doing tremendous sales, tremendous volumes. We'll continue to innovate from an operational standpoint. Everybody is continuing to try to copy us because the innovations are still occurring at Whole Foods Market. That's how we're differentiating. Now if you mean -- sure, we're copying some of the things that some of our competitors do. We're learning from everybody. And competitors who are doing some things better than Whole Foods, we certainly want to -- we're going to learn from that, make our company better. But we are not standing still. In fact, I would argue that we're probably undergoing far more evolution in our company than ever before. And the final and probably the most important point, nobody, nobody comes close to matching our quality standards. We're the only one -- only supermarket in America that's 100% cage-free eggs, that has an animal welfare system, that's top-rated in Greenpeace for seafood sustainability. We're doing over $3 billion a year in prepared foods and bakery. We're a large restaurant operator. Our stores are very different than our competitors', and we're not standing still. We're continuing to grow, evolve and differentiate ourselves.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's why 800 people were standing in line this morning for our Westford store opening and our 40th store in our North Atlantic region this morning.
componenttext: And that's why 800 people were standing in line this morning for our Westford store opening and our 40th store in our North Atlantic region this morning.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations to Laura and the team up there. That's good, Laura.
componenttext: Congratulations to Laura and the team up there. That's good, Laura.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Wiltamuth. Our surveys are starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that? And are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?
componenttext: It's Mark Wiltamuth. Our surveys are starting to show some Trader Joe's discounting out there. Are you seeing that? And are you reacting to it? Or what are your thoughts on what you're seeing in the market right now?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We noticed last, I think starting in November, that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets, and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and our other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidths that
componenttext: We noticed last, I think starting in November, that Trader Joe's had lower prices in certain items in certain markets, and it's -- we've monitored Trader Joe's and our other competitors very closely, and we make sure we have certain price bandwidths that we make sure that we're -- that we follow with them. And so in key items that we saw Trader Joe's change pricing on, we changed pricing as well on certain items to make sure we maintained our proper bandwidth to them. So -- but I don't think that was highly unusual. I think that Trader Joe's and all our other competitors regularly raise and lower prices, depending on -- sometimes, it's just based on -- and generally it's based on markets. Like a couple of years ago, last year, olive oil crop in Italy was terrible, and Trader Joe's raised their olive oil prices. And this year, olive oil crop is much better in Europe, and everybody is lowering. They lowered their olive oil prices. So -- I mean that's -- it's just -- it's kind of the way it works. I don't think it was anything unusual or stand apart from what normally happens.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the -- following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the -- following up on the cannibalization question, how was the sequential progress on cannibalization from first quarter into the second quarter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1 and will get even better in Q3 and then even bet
componenttext: Well, the cannibalization impact does ease over the course of the year as we anniversary the openings in Florida and Chicago, which were our 2 hardest hit markets. So it was a little better in Q2 than in Q1 and will get even better in Q3 and then even better in Q4.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robby Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robby Ohmes with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on 365, I was hoping -- could you remind us -- 19 stores you're going to be opening, assuming these go well, and it sounds like they could, can you remind us the expectation, if this goes really well, the kind of profit contribution 365 could have? A
componenttext: Just on 365, I was hoping -- could you remind us -- 19 stores you're going to be opening, assuming these go well, and it sounds like they could, can you remind us the expectation, if this goes really well, the kind of profit contribution 365 could have? Are these expected to be higher-margin stores than the core Whole Foods stores? Just maybe a little bit of a -- maybe some of the metrics you'll be looking at when you decide how many to open over the next few years.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have to open them up and see. It's -- sure, we project things out, but it's just -- you need data. You need actual results. So we'll be able to answer that question a lot better -- I suspect, when we come to our fourth quarter earnings call in
componenttext: I think we have to open them up and see. It's -- sure, we project things out, but it's just -- you need data. You need actual results. So we'll be able to answer that question a lot better -- I suspect, when we come to our fourth quarter earnings call in November, then we'll have some hard data on the first 3 openings and we'll be able to give you some much more concrete information as opposed to just sort of speculation. We're expecting them to have very good returns on invested capital and to be very profitable for us. So yes, we think they're going to be accretive, but -- I mean, we got to get them up to speed.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, can you remind us do they leverage off being close to other Whole Foods stores? Because you're not clustering the concept based on the stores you've announced so far, and does that make it harder for that chain to be profitable?
componenttext: And John, can you remind us do they leverage off being close to other Whole Foods stores? Because you're not clustering the concept based on the stores you've announced so far, and does that make it harder for that chain to be profitable?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, because all the stores are being -- from an -- although the product selection, the pricing, the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices, the actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all the adv
componenttext: No, no, because all the stores are being -- from an -- although the product selection, the pricing, the overall programming is all occurring from our global offices, the actual operations of the store is going to be in the regions. So they get all the advantages of scale that we have in our regions and -- scales in purchasing, while we've been able to program the pricing, the products, the strategy, the decor, the design, all of that from Austin. So we think we're getting the best of both worlds there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Magee with SunTrust.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Magee with SunTrust.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question also has to do with 365. I'm curious how you'll market that concept, maybe you're doing it already or once it opens up. And are you seeing anything now, whether it's social media buzz or otherwise, that gives you confidence that the demand is
componenttext: My question also has to do with 365. I'm curious how you'll market that concept, maybe you're doing it already or once it opens up. And are you seeing anything now, whether it's social media buzz or otherwise, that gives you confidence that the demand is out there?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David and Ken. We'll both answer that. We can tell you that everybody is very curious about this, so it's definitely not going to be a secret. Jeff Turnas, our President of 365, did desk-side interviews with all sorts of folks in New York last wee
componenttext: This is David and Ken. We'll both answer that. We can tell you that everybody is very curious about this, so it's definitely not going to be a secret. Jeff Turnas, our President of 365, did desk-side interviews with all sorts of folks in New York last week. There was probably close to 100 to 150 stories written about us last week, showing what we're going to be doing in the first couple of stores, showing the way they're going to look and so a lot of stuff. We're also going to be doing some traditional stuff, advertising in the L.A. Times as well as lots of social media, working with BuzzFeed and few other groups. Anything else?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just last week, we had a launch event in New York where we invited all of the press to and our partners. We had over 200 people there to sort of introduce the concept. And like David said, using BuzzFeed is going to be one of our big vehicles to
componenttext: Yes. And just last week, we had a launch event in New York where we invited all of the press to and our partners. We had over 200 people there to sort of introduce the concept. And like David said, using BuzzFeed is going to be one of our big vehicles to get out into the social media.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, as you guys look at your most like loyal customers or even like those core shoppers that they are in there every week, they are your regular guys, have you seen any change in their behavior lately? Or is it really those kind of the casual
componenttext: I wanted to ask, as you guys look at your most like loyal customers or even like those core shoppers that they are in there every week, they are your regular guys, have you seen any change in their behavior lately? Or is it really those kind of the casual fringe customer that you've see a little bit of a drop-off with?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. Yes -- no, we're -- we've got a pretty good read on that, and I would say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who continue to stay with us and stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. Yes, I mean, where the erosion has ha
componenttext: This is Walter. Yes -- no, we're -- we've got a pretty good read on that, and I would say we're very pleased with the core shoppers who continue to stay with us and stay in pretty consistent frequency and also basket. Yes, I mean, where the erosion has happened, to the extent that it has, and the comeback will happen, is also what we more broadly call the occasional shoppers who come in at different frequencies and for different amounts, and that's where I think folks maybe, perhaps, be -- where we see a little bit more inconsistency. So that's the answer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one quick follow-up. As far as marketing goes, how have you guys been, I guess, measuring the marketing efficacy or the return on the marketing? And is there any thought to go back to like -- I think it was last year you guys did the nationa
componenttext: And then just one quick follow-up. As far as marketing goes, how have you guys been, I guess, measuring the marketing efficacy or the return on the marketing? And is there any thought to go back to like -- I think it was last year you guys did the national branding, and that seemed to really have an impact to drive some sales for little while. So I was just curious about how you're viewing that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got something up our sleeves, but nothing to announce today other than we're working on something and we're excited about it. I think we're -- when we get the 365 stores launched, get some data on that, get our national Affinity program launched, we
componenttext: We've got something up our sleeves, but nothing to announce today other than we're working on something and we're excited about it. I think we're -- when we get the 365 stores launched, get some data on that, get our national Affinity program launched, we want to get some pieces in place, and as we get those in place, and I think we will launch a more broad-based marketing strategy. So we'll have -- probably, again, we'll have something to talk about in Q4 about that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the investments we're making in, as A.C. detailed earlier, it's I think the -- obviously, the ultimate measure of those are sales. It's traffic and sales, and we are seeing the first chapter of that, which is kind of the units begin to move a
componenttext: And I think the investments we're making in, as A.C. detailed earlier, it's I think the -- obviously, the ultimate measure of those are sales. It's traffic and sales, and we are seeing the first chapter of that, which is kind of the units begin to move a little bit, which then leads from there on the digital side, obviously, you can measure things differently. One of the real advantages of Affinity for us, and we enjoy that in Philadelphia and soon to be in Dallas, is that we actually can create personalized offers and connections with customers. And so we can actually -- through the tokenized data, we can actually follow what the customer's actually doing over time. And then we can also look at the segments and how we can respond to groups of customers as well. So we're putting in place some really good tools to be able to measure the investments. They are a lot easier to measure there than they are on, say, on the promos that we're doing on the perishables right now because that kind of all comes back just to comps and sales and units and that sort of thing. So that's where we are with those 2.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think, if I heard you correctly, it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the price investments. I think, if I heard you correctly, it sounds like you're getting a good uptick in the units but not quite enough to offset the magnitude of the price investment, and I'm just wondering if you're looking at other ways, maybe just not promotions but more of an EDLP effort as you kind of broaden some of the price investments to other categories? Or how do you get that -- how do you think you are going to get that elasticity, I guess?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year we probably did a little more on the EDLP. This year we'
componenttext: Well, our price investments are really a combination of promotions and EDLPs. We evaluate each category, each department in the store and kind of have that two-pronged strategy. We have -- last year we probably did a little more on the EDLP. This year we're kind of doing a combination. We focused, for instance, in the produce department, where we've taken certain categories and we moved the regular pricing. We moved the regular pricing down in a few categories. At the same time, we've done some really strong promotions. And because you really you got to kind of do both in order to -- the promotions might bring people in, but then once they're in the store, they want to see -- the regular prices they look at are really important for if they're to going to buy beyond the promotion. So it's very important to do both. But I think, ultimately, it's really through the category management program that we're going to be able to determine what is actually the right mix between -- in each department for adjusting everyday pricing, for doing more promotion. We're going to be able to really look and see how not only -- and we're going to be able to do a lot of testing with that to really understand what is the most effective for our customers. Because as Walter was saying earlier, answering the question about our kind of more core shoppers, then more occasional shoppers, different strategies work for these different customers. So what we're in a process of doing is really refining our ability and giving ourselves the tools we need to understand how we both price and market to the different customer -- customers we have, which will respond to different promotions and prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just in terms of the comparisons, if I could just ask one more quick one. They're getting a lot easier as we move forward here. But last year, one of the big initiatives was also some of the remodels. I know some of them were more mino
componenttext: That's helpful. And just in terms of the comparisons, if I could just ask one more quick one. They're getting a lot easier as we move forward here. But last year, one of the big initiatives was also some of the remodels. I know some of them were more minor, some of them were more major. But how should we think about cycling maybe some of the remodels and the impact from those last year?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is David. We are in a -- now with 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refreshment in a lot of our stores last year, but we were continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would
componenttext: Yes, this is David. We are in a -- now with 450 stores in our base, we're constantly remodeling and refreshing our stores. So we did the core refreshment in a lot of our stores last year, but we were continuing to do that work as well as remodels. I would say in general, though, we're trying to focus on smaller-size remodel that have a bigger sales impact, doing a lot of focus on prepared foods, bakery and also conversion from full-service venues to self-service venues so we can -- customers are responding well to that, and we are able to get labor reductions at the same time. So that's kind of where we're focusing our capital spending, not on new stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I want to thank everybody for listening in today, and we look forward to updating you on our progress on our Q3 earnings call in late July. If you get a chance and you're in L.A., check out our Silver Lake store, which opens in 3 weeks. Maybe go to
componenttext: Okay, I want to thank everybody for listening in today, and we look forward to updating you on our progress on our Q3 earnings call in late July. If you get a chance and you're in L.A., check out our Silver Lake store, which opens in 3 weeks. Maybe go to the downtown L.A. store. You can see the contrast right there between what Whole Foods Market is evolving to and what the new 365 format will be. Okay, everybody. We'll talk to you soon. Take care. Bye.

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]  Please note this call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Mayer, Executive Vice President of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. In addition, our remarks today include references to non-GAAP measures. For a reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the GAAP figures, please see the tables in our earnings release. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everybody. In the third quarter, we delivered record sales of $8.7 billion. We produced $0.37 in diluted earnings per share, $189 million of operating cash flow, 8.8% EBITDA margin and 13% adjusted return on invested cap
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everybody. In the third quarter, we delivered record sales of $8.7 billion. We produced $0.37 in diluted earnings per share, $189 million of operating cash flow, 8.8% EBITDA margin and 13% adjusted return on invested capital. In keeping with our capital allocation strategy, we returned $239 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases ending the quarter with $1.1 billion in available capital. We opened 12 new stores including our first 365 by Whole Foods Market. As we discussed last quarter, we expanded our POTUS price investments and launched weekly deep discount promotions in several categories. We supported our efforts with an enhanced ad campaign, which in addition to produce, featured weekly meat, seafood and prepared foods offers and highlighted our quality differences. We produced a 45 basis point improvement in comps from last quarter as a significant improvement in items per basket more than offset decreases in transactions and average price per item. The combination of our value strategy, disinflation in some categories and customer's trading down to lower-priced items resulted in a year-over-year decline in average price per item. While our value strategies continued to negatively impact comps and gross margin, we are seeing a broad-based lip in items per basket and are encouraged with improving traffic trends in certain key departments and particularly produce. Our ongoing expense discipline is reflected in the 82 basis point improvement in salaries. However, these savings were more than offset by higher healthcare, depreciation, marketing and technology investments as a percentage of sales. Our marketing and technology investments were on budget, but greater-than-expected healthcare cost and lower-than-forecast sales resulted in the SG&A deleverage. Our catastrophic claims and cost for certain your prescription medicines were above forecast and while we're working to reverse these trends, these higher costs are expected to continue in the short term. As you recall back in February, we added digital coupons to our app, introducing the first component of our national affinity program. Coupons quickly became the most used feature within our app and customers can look forward to a continued expansion of offers. Today, we took another big step forward in our efforts to better understand and provide personalized offers to our customers with the market test launch of our new rewards programs in the Dallas and Fort Worth metro areas. Local customers can register at wholefoodsmarket.com to save instantly on member only deals like 10% off their first purchase, earn rewards for free products and receive surprises just for shopping in our stores. With each scan at the checkout, easy-to-use, customers increase their savings and personalized their future rewards. This new program builds upon our initial pilot in Philadelphia while adding improvements that allow us to be more strategic in the ways in which customers can earn and redeem their rewards. Once the test is complete, we look forward to national rollout of the program sometime next year. Just 2 weeks ago, we opened our second 365 store. We want to really   appreciate Jeff, Isabelle François and their team for all the hard work and enthusiasm that went into pulling up a highly successful launch of our new value brand. Designed around affordability and convenience and supported by enhanced digital experiences, 365 delivers a fresh new format to the marketplace and the customer response has been overwhelmingly positive. Through lower capital and operating cost, we were able to offer great values which we believe are attracting a broader customer basic than we typically see at Whole Foods Market stores. While 365 offers a curated mix at sharp price points, we are seeing larger basket sizes with more items versus our metro leverages. This is a pleasant surprise that has led us to a redesign to the front end already. Our 365 stores are first for us in so many ways from a streamlined operating model to centralized buying to auto-replenishment of inventory. With 20 stores in development, we're very excited about the learning potential and we are already using the shape -- already using this to shape and evolve not just feature 365 stores, but Whole Foods Market stores as well. This week, we also welcome 2 new flagship Whole Foods Market stores in Brooklyn, New York and Santa Clara, California. Averaging 50,000 square feet, most stores are designed to take advantage of the dense urban locations with extended prepared foods experiences. Our Williamsburg store in Brooklyn has taken our prepared foods venues to the next level, with the food hall, featuring some of New York City's best and most beloved up-and-coming favorites, like Luke's lobster trail cart, number 7 veggie and East Coast [indiscernible]. We work very closely with each partner to customize their menu and provide our customers a unique dining experienced they simply can't get anywhere else. Our store in Santa Clara, which is located in the heart of Silicon Valley, includes a taproom with local beers and wine and menu items designed by Top Chef finalist Melissa King. [ph] This store also features our partnership with imperfect produce as part of an ongoing commitment to reduce food waste. 
Turning now to the Q4 outlook. We opened 3 stores and expect to open 2 more. While we are hopeful this sequential improvement in comps continues especially in light of an easier 110 basis point comparison over the next 9 weeks. We have yet to see stability in our 2 year comp trends. In addition, we expect some ongoing headwinds from our value strategy and disinflation. If comps were in line with the negative 2.4% we have reported quarter-to-date and healthcare costs continue, the trends continue, we would expect sales growth of approximately 2% and diluted earnings per share of $0.23 to $0.24 for the quarter. As we stated, our strategies to adjust our operating model through lower margin and lower cost structure. Every major conversation we've had about investments and pricing technology and marketing is accompanied by conversation about lowering our cost structure to enhanced technology tools, labor restructuring and work process changes. Last November, we announced our goal to reduce cost structure by $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal '17. While we have some headwinds to overcome in the form of lower sales and a higher healthcare costs, that larger goal remains intact. As we look towards 2017, we expect ending square footage growth of approximately 6%, down from 7% this year. Next quarter, we will provide more information on the expected number of Whole Foods and 365 openings along with other fiscal year targets. While we remain confident in our long-term growth potential, we plan to grow square footage at a more moderate pace this next year to lessen the negative impact of cannibalization on our existing stores and to allow us to focus more time and resources on our key initiatives. We are reviewing our entire development pipeline and as appropriate, are making adjustments to capital budgets and operating models to reflect a more conservative projections for comps and gross margins as well as to apply the learnings from 365. In closing, food retailing has continued to evolve in incredibly fast pace and customers have more options than ever before and in the phase of this challenging environment, we're starting to see some encouraging signs in terms of our sales. We are making measurable progress and fundamentally evolving our business and providing an enhanced experience for our customers before, during and after their store visit. We remain focused on executing our 9-point plan which we believe will produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the longer term. We will now take some questions. Call will end at 4:45 central time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: This is David. Kind of first thing I would say is customers are really accepted kind of this new design. So we're seeing our meat and seafood percentage of sales being very similar to what they are at Whole Foods even though they're 100% self-service. Ken?

componenttext: Yes, aspects we've got a lot of engaging technology for our customers, the digital experience, we've been able to test out a number of concepts. componenttext: I think this is Walter having deadline and having the store opened really allows to push to get that rewards program up and going and then we are able to pivot all of those learnings into the broader Affinity program that we're launching today in Dallas. And this team here just gone through the entire development pipeline, as we mentioned in the script, and look for opportunities to learn and apply in every single situation in a very vigorous manner. So a lot of excitement about what we've learned to launching this format. Thanks for the question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer the second part, then Dave and Ken and others can pick up the first part. Essentially, we are tracking really closely the impact of -- we're doing several experiments in the 2 different markets to serve and understand and we've got a pre
componenttext: Well, I'll answer the second part, then Dave and Ken and others can pick up the first part. Essentially, we are tracking really closely the impact of -- we're doing several experiments in the 2 different markets to serve and understand and we've got a pretty good handle on that. But it's too early for us to share data on what that looks like. I will say broadly that at least my view is that we're creating a new customer and we're attracting new customer, we are broadening the import and the effective Whole Foods Market in the marketplace through these stores. We're reaching customers that we have historically have not reached. That's clearly what the data shows. So David, Ken over to you, do you want to answer [indiscernible].

componenttextpreview: We're seeing the first 3 stores as test and experiment so we're kind adjusting all the time. But the big one was that we're busier than we thought. So several we have capacity issues with getting customers through our register systems. And also the big fa
componenttext: We're seeing the first 3 stores as test and experiment so we're kind adjusting all the time. But the big one was that we're busier than we thought. So several we have capacity issues with getting customers through our register systems. And also the big factors, the baskets are much bigger because of kind of smaller tellers registers that we're using were not effective for the size of the baskets we're getting. So we adjusted the design for we're going back and adjust them for Silver Lake and in all the future designs. So the great thing is with these first 3 stores, we are testing out a few product variations, a few layout, where answers and with the idea being by the time to get the store for in Ohio that will be kind of completely dialed in.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And one of the bigger evolutions too is our component in the Portland stores included to the overall design versus it being a separate sort of experience versus in Silver Lake, it was by color which is kind of off to the side which is now next level is right within the concept of the store which is great design too and we see that whole approach of using the fonts concept in the Whole Foods. We really think that, that's going to be a huge differentiator for us as we grow and involve that into Whole Foods model.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Walter. I think we'll have a lot more to say about 365 when we get to our Q4 call in November. We're very happy with the initial start of the first couple of stores. I'm very happy with the way it came out. We think we created a very successful ne
componenttext: Thanks, Walter. I think we'll have a lot more to say about 365 when we get to our Q4 call in November. We're very happy with the initial start of the first couple of stores. I'm very happy with the way it came out. We think we created a very successful new business model which we're going to expand rapidly and we'll have more information about that next quarter. One thing relevant is we're opening our third 365 store in Seattle area in Bellevue in September. And that's a very interesting opening for us because we don't think the cannibalization from 365 to Whole Foods Market is particularly great because as Walter indicated, we're getting rethinking customer in there. The Bellevue will be a good test because we're going up against one of our flagship stores there. And for your -- in both of our Lake ago in Portland and our Silver Lake store now in our LA area, the Whole Foods Market stores are not particularly close to it. So Bellevue is very close so that's going to be a very interesting, We'll have more information when we do our Q4 report of what kind of cannibalization impact is going to have. So we're very excited about that. We're very excited about 365 and we look forward to better informing you as time goes on.

componenttext: And by the way, just a final choice to that, once affinity is launched, and we're actually tracking individual customers, one of the interesting things for us to see that we have will be able to see what individual customers are doing. We think some time using 365, sometimes they use the Whole Foods Market, they may be distinct moves and I think we'll be able to answer these questions are relatively short period of time very, very clearly but net-net it looks like A, we've created a broader market for our company, for our products, our standards, our experiences. That's what the information suggest but as John mentioned, we'll be back with a lot more specifics around that in the future in November when we're back for the queue. So thanks for the question.

componenttextpreview: So I guess, the first area want to start is your expenses. We saw again another strong quarter of expense control and if my math is right, excluding D&A, I think your expenses are close to 5 are up maybe 1% year-to-date even with about 7% square footage g
componenttext: So I guess, the first area want to start is your expenses. We saw again another strong quarter of expense control and if my math is right, excluding D&A, I think your expenses are close to 5 are up maybe 1% year-to-date even with about 7% square footage growth. I know you're not giving guidance today, but as we look out to next year, is there any clarity you can help us provide in terms of the $300 million in of savings, whether more of it this year whether we should see my benefits in 2017?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Rupesh, this is Glenda. We certainly wanted to  reiterate in our remarks today that our $300 million in target remains intact but we have never put a specific timeline on that. We have made measurable progress on it in 2016 with the large restructurin
componenttext: Hi, Rupesh, this is Glenda. We certainly wanted to  reiterate in our remarks today that our $300 million in target remains intact but we have never put a specific timeline on that. We have made measurable progress on it in 2016 with the large restructuring that we did at the beginning of the year and with other initiatives that are ongoing at Whole Foods Market. So we feel good about that. The obviously -- it will be a lot easier for us to get there if we have higher sales and we didn't have this healthcare hurdle to overcome but if we do have a lot underway both in the way we're doing work process at Whole Foods, with the way technology, tools are being enhanced to help us reduce labor, for example, auto-replenishment is going to be a big 1 when we get to that because we have a lot of people in the stores who are buyers and we have no buyers in the 365 stores while the inventory is automatically ordered. So that's a big one. It's going to happen to us -- for us at some point.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, we made ongoing and significant investments in produce this year and kind of on a region-by-region basis. And we expected when we made these investments that initially, we would see a drop in sales, as well as margin. But we've been solely seeing a ni
componenttext: Hi, we made ongoing and significant investments in produce this year and kind of on a region-by-region basis. And we expected when we made these investments that initially, we would see a drop in sales, as well as margin. But we've been solely seeing a nice pickup in average produce items in the basket and that's helped to offset part of the investment. And we're definitely seeing a positive trend. We did a lot of investment the last 6 weeks or so with summer fruit, with cherries and blueberries and strawberries, things like that and so a really nice, really moved out ton of product and so we're seeing on a nice trend in that area. In our experience, it's produce is extremely competitive area. And in our experience, it's hard to turn around a trend in produce, but we feel like we really have and we're continuing -- we're going to continue to invest in that area and continue to see a nice pickup in items per basket.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: David, I'd also say we're about 6 weeks into our national flyers so first time in our company's history where customers are actually seeing these produce sales across all channels, across all companies at the same time. So we hope that, that's having an effect as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, A.C. here. Absolutely saw, I'd say, overall we were pretty flat to slight deflation in costs this quarter. And where we saw the most deflation in terms of our retail prices were in produce, as we mentioned. That's where our biggest investments have be
componenttext: Hi, A.C. here. Absolutely saw, I'd say, overall we were pretty flat to slight deflation in costs this quarter. And where we saw the most deflation in terms of our retail prices were in produce, as we mentioned. That's where our biggest investments have been. And may be saw a little bit of deflation as well, a little bit of deflation in beef cost and a little bit deflation in our actual retail prices, mainly due to expanded promotion strategy that we were doing. Those are the 2 biggest areas. I'd say, we're definitely seeing also a little deflation in our bulk products, things like almonds and other, prices like that really dropped off the cliff and we've lowered our prices and pretty significantly in a couple of major commodities there to.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: How about dairy, anything on going on there?
componenttext: How about dairy, anything on going on there?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dairy, it varies a little bit in dairy. We know eggs are kind of in excess around the country, so egg prices are flat to deflationary. Milk prices, for us, have been fairly steady. We have, in select markets we have lowered milk prices and a few areas in
componenttext: Dairy, it varies a little bit in dairy. We know eggs are kind of in excess around the country, so egg prices are flat to deflationary. Milk prices, for us, have been fairly steady. We have, in select markets we have lowered milk prices and a few areas in select markets. So certainly the prices aren't going up.

componenttext: Well, it's also exciting like in Chicago, there are 2 stores we opened 7 stores after them so and then this year, we're coming back around cycling on those. And it's wonderful to see these things start to bloom. But generally, it remains a very, very competitive market place out there. I wonder some point whether some of them will rationalize them and closes. We saw it happened at least in 1 of the competitors in the last number of months. But that's the world we're in and customers have lots of choices and we're showing with you kind our thoughts are we continue to push Whole Foods Market forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: I mean lapping out of cannibalization is certainly helping your year goes but you had some significant drops in your year ago comparisons and the 2 year stack is now negative. Do you think that's mostly just the price investments coming through, or what do think is the primary factor for the 2-year stack down there?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is a number of factors. Cannibalization remains a factor but that's possibly slightly lessening as we anniversary some of the Chicago openings. Yes, competition, I mean, it is not a big secret, is that? There's a lot of the competitors in the mar
componenttext: Well, it is a number of factors. Cannibalization remains a factor but that's possibly slightly lessening as we anniversary some of the Chicago openings. Yes, competition, I mean, it is not a big secret, is that? There's a lot of the competitors in the marketplace and there's a lot of new formats in the marketplace from home meal replacement to meal kits, fast cargo restaurant growth, more entrants in the natural organic food space, mainstream, mainstreaming of natural organic which have been well reported. These are all factors. Hopefully, to market leader, very high sales per-square foot. We probably shared the broad of it as there's a bit of regression to the mean as we lose customers from a convenience standpoint, people don't drive as far as I used to drive because good enough, there's good enough alternatives, in many cases, close by them. People may not be driving as frequently as far as they used to because they can stop by a Kroger or AGB or regimens to get products they can get -- used to own to be able to get Whole Foods, now there's some overlap in our product base in our competitor. i mean I think there's no sense of denying it. Compositions bigger and we're responding to it as we take an intelligent, measured way and we still remain very bullish about our future prospects.
