componenttext: It's just not meaningful either way. It didn't really help us in Q3, and it's not really going to hurt us in Q4. Help us in Q4. However, it's not that big a deal, we didn't see that much change.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's perfect. And then if I can quickly follow up, typically Whole Foods will provide a pretty specific outlook for the coming quarter. This time, there was a little bit of a change. The guidance was more about what will happen if trends don't
componenttext: Okay. No, that's perfect. And then if I can quickly follow up, typically Whole Foods will provide a pretty specific outlook for the coming quarter. This time, there was a little bit of a change. The guidance was more about what will happen if trends don't change. I'm just curious is this a structural change in how the company is going to provide guidance from here? Or is this more -- maybe a one-off decision just given some of the uncertainty today?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is just for 1 quarter. So we simplified the guidance for that reason, but we have typically, in many cases, said if current trends continue, this is what you would see in the quarter or in the period ahead because until trends change, unless ther
componenttext: Well, it is just for 1 quarter. So we simplified the guidance for that reason, but we have typically, in many cases, said if current trends continue, this is what you would see in the quarter or in the period ahead because until trends change, unless there's some specific event or reason for them to be different, then the best thing that we have to go on is the current trends. So we did not reiterate our prior '16 targets, but we did give specific guidance for the quarter.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we hoped our 2-year stack comps would stabilize and that has not happened yet. So until that happens it's hard for us to give too much confident guidance. So better to hedge a bit, better to give a range and all the analysts are very smart people,
componenttext: I mean, we hoped our 2-year stack comps would stabilize and that has not happened yet. So until that happens it's hard for us to give too much confident guidance. So better to hedge a bit, better to give a range and all the analysts are very smart people, so they can draw their own conclusions.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'd all like to be further along. I think just the responsible thing is just to be conservative and make sure that we've got the boundaries clearly defined with -- you have the information that we now have about what we see, as Glenda said, so -- thank y
componenttext: We'd all like to be further along. I think just the responsible thing is just to be conservative and make sure that we've got the boundaries clearly defined with -- you have the information that we now have about what we see, as Glenda said, so -- thank you for that question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: I'll start and then Jason can add on. Well, the partnership with Nielsen is going to give us a tremendous amount of consumer data that we haven't had before. As we move into doing more globally managed, category management in our stores, we really need th
componenttext: I'll start and then Jason can add on. Well, the partnership with Nielsen is going to give us a tremendous amount of consumer data that we haven't had before. As we move into doing more globally managed, category management in our stores, we really need this consumer information in order to properly set up the categories and know where to do our promotions and know how to price the different categories. So that's a lot of information that we haven't had. Mostly what we've had is our own information so we're looking at ourselves and this allows us to look much more carefully at the whole industry, all our competitors and what we need to do to be more competitive.

componenttext: Yes, just to add on, as you've heard us talk about many times, we operate a lot of our regional structure side of things very autonomously and this is allowing us to also unify our data to help support some of our other large programs like the Infor program we've talked about, which is helping us revolutionize the supply chain and purchasing side of our business. And so that will play a very important role in data there. It'll also help us collaborate more with our suppliers. So we'll have one source of the truth as far as how we'll be looking at talking with them about sales and collaboration in our planning processes.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference o
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Foods' Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Mayer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. In addition, our remarks today include references to non-GAAP measures. For a reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to the GAAP figures, please see the tables in our earnings release. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everybody. In the third quarter, we delivered record sales of $8.7 billion. We produced $0.37 in diluted earnings per share, $189 million of operating cash flow, 8.8% EBITDA margin and 13% adjusted return on invested cap
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everybody. In the third quarter, we delivered record sales of $8.7 billion. We produced $0.37 in diluted earnings per share, $189 million of operating cash flow, 8.8% EBITDA margin and 13% adjusted return on invested capital. In keeping with our capital allocation strategy, we returned $239 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the quarter with $1.1 billion in available capital. We opened 12 new stores, including our first 365 by Whole Foods Market. As we discussed last quarter, we expanded our produce price investments and launched weekly deep discount promotions in several categories. We supported our efforts with an enhanced ad campaign, which in addition to produce, featured weekly meat, seafood and prepared foods offers and highlighted our quality differences. We produced a 45 basis point improvement in comps from last quarter as a significant improvement in items per basket, more than offset decreases in transactions and average price per item. The combination of our value strategy, disinflation in some categories and customers' trading down to lower-priced items resulted in a year-over-year decline in average price per item. While our value strategies continued to negatively impact comps and gross margin, we are seeing a broad-based lift in items per basket and are encouraged with improving traffic trends in certain key departments, particularly produce. Our ongoing expense discipline was reflected in the 82 basis point improvement in salaries. However, these savings were more than offset by higher health care, depreciation, marketing and technology investments as a percentage of sales. Our marketing and technology investments were on budget, but greater-than-expected health care costs and lower-than-forecast sales resulted in the SG&A deleverage. Our catastrophic claims and costs for certain new prescription medicines were above forecast and while we are working to reverse these trends, these higher costs are expected to continue in the short term. 
As you recall, back in February, we added digital coupons to our app, introducing the first component of our national affinity program. Coupons quickly became the most used feature within our app and customers can look forward to a continued expansion of offers. Today, we took another big step forward in our efforts to better understand and provide personalized offers to our customers with the market test launch of our new rewards programs in the Dallas and Fort Worth metro areas. Local customers can register at wholefoodsmarket.com to save instantly on member-only deals like 10% off their first purchase, earn rewards for free products and receive surprises just for shopping in our stores. With each scan at the checkout, easy-to-use, customers increase their savings and personalize their future rewards. This new program builds upon our initial pilot in Philadelphia, while adding improvements that allow us to be more strategic in the ways in which customers can earn and redeem their rewards. Once the test is complete, we look forward to a national rollout of the program sometime next year. 
Just 2 weeks ago, we opened our second 365 store. We want to really appreciate Jeff Turnas, Isabelle François and their team for all the hard work and enthusiasm that went into pulling off a highly successful launch of our new value brand. Designed around affordability and convenience and supported by enhanced digital experiences, 365 delivers a fresh new format to the marketplace, and the customer response has been overwhelmingly positive. Through lower capital and operating costs, we were able to offer great values, which we believe are attracting a broader customer base than we typically see at Whole Foods Market stores. While 365 offers a curated mix at sharp price points, we are seeing larger basket sizes with more items versus our metro averages. This is a pleasant surprise that has led us to a redesign of the front end already. 
Our 365 stores are firsts for us in so many ways, from a streamlined operating model to centralized buying to auto-replenishment of inventory. With 20 stores in development, we're very excited about the learning potential and we are already using the shape -- already using these to shape and evolve not just feature 365 stores but Whole Foods Market stores as well. This week, we also welcome 2 new flagship Whole Foods Market stores in Brooklyn, New York and Santa Clara, California. Averaging 50,000 square feet, both stores are designed to take advantage of the dense urban locations with extended prepared foods experiences. Our Williamsburg store in Brooklyn has taken our prepared foods venues to the next level, with a food hall, featuring some of New York City's best, most beloved and up-and-coming favorites, like Luke's Lobster Tail Cart, No. 7 Veggie and East Coast Poke. 
We work very closely with each partner to customize their menu and provide our customers with a unique dining experience they simply can't get anywhere else. Our store in Santa Clara, which is located in the heart of Silicon Valley, includes a taproom with local beers and wine and menu items designed by Top Chef finalist, Melissa King. This store also features our partnership with Imperfect Produce as a part of the ongoing commitment to reduce food waste. 
Turning now to the Q4 outlook. We have opened 3 stores and expect to open 2 more. While we are hopeful the sequential improvement in the comps continues, especially in light of an easier 110 basis point comparison over the next 9 weeks. We have yet to see stability in our 2-year comp trends. In addition, we expect some ongoing headwinds from our value strategy and disinflation. If comps were in line with a negative 2.4% we have reported quarter-to-date and health care costs continue, the trends continue, we would expect sales growth of approximately 2% and diluted earnings per share of $0.23 to $0.24 for the quarter. As we stated, our strategy is to adjust our operating model to a lower margin and lower cost structure. Every major conversation we've had about investments in pricing, technology and marketing is accompanied by a conversation about lowering our cost structure through enhanced technology tools, labor restructuring and work process changes. 
Last November, we announced our goal to reduce our cost structure by $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal '17. While we have some headwinds to overcome in the form of the lower sales and the higher health care costs, that larger goal remains intact. 
As we look towards 2017, we expect ending square footage growth of approximately 6%, down from 7% this year. Next quarter, we will provide more information on the expected number of Whole Foods and 365 openings, along with other fiscal year targets. While we remain confident in our long-term growth potential, we plan to grow square footage at a more moderate pace this next year, to lessen the negative impact of cannibalization on our existing stores and to allow us to focus more time and resources on our key initiatives. We are reviewing our entire development pipeline and as appropriate, are making adjustments to capital budgets and operating models to reflect more conservative projections for comps and gross margins as well as to apply the learnings from 365. 
In closing, food retailing has continued to evolve at an incredibly fast pace and customers have more options than ever before. And in the face of this challenging environment, we are starting to see some encouraging signs in terms of our sales. We are making measurable progress in fundamentally evolving our business and providing an enhanced experience for our customers before, during and after their store visit. We remain focused on executing our 9-point plan, which we believe will produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the longer term. 
We will now take some questions. The call will end at 4:45 central time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: No, Walter that's pretty much it. The comps for the quarter as a whole were pretty stable from start to finish. We did see a little improvement, as you said, in the last 10 days and then no significant changes into the -- what we've seen in Q4 so far.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up here. As we think about 365, I mean, obviously, [indiscernible] has got a lot of positive press. But if you take a step back and highlight some of the things that you've learned so far from the concept and what can be
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up here. As we think about 365, I mean, obviously, [indiscernible] has got a lot of positive press. But if you take a step back and highlight some of the things that you've learned so far from the concept and what can be applied to the store? Can you just elaborate that -- on it a bit?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We love that question and we'd be happy to do that and Ken and Dave are going to roll with it.
componenttext: We love that question and we'd be happy to do that and Ken and Dave are going to roll with it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. Probably the first thing I would say is customers really accepted kind of this new design. It's a fresh look, it's a fresh feel, they're kind of accepting it as a brand-new brand, and just lots of kind of, it's a -- even though it's a value
componenttext: This is David. Probably the first thing I would say is customers really accepted kind of this new design. It's a fresh look, it's a fresh feel, they're kind of accepting it as a brand-new brand, and just lots of kind of, it's a -- even though it's a value brand, it's still a really fun place to shop and I think in addition to that, we're finding that customers are readily accepting items that are full-service at Whole Foods in the self-service environment at much lower prices in the 365. So we're seeing our meat and seafood percentage of sales being very similar to what they are at Whole Foods even though they're 100% self-service. Ken?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, one of the big things is the way we set up the team structure there, we've learned a lot from that in terms of creating the leadership and the way the team members operate in the stores is significantly informing us on how we want to evolve Whol
componenttext: And also, one of the big things is the way we set up the team structure there, we've learned a lot from that in terms of creating the leadership and the way the team members operate in the stores is significantly informing us on how we want to evolve Whole Foods. Also, the way in which they're ordering. We're using the technology to help us order, actually, almost to the point where they're not actually -- the technology is ordering for the store, which is a huge advancement for us. Jason, do you want to add anything in technology.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the other aspects. We've got a lot of engaging technology for our customers, the digital experience, we've been able to test out a number of concepts. One of them, that particularly of interest is a partnership we have at a company called Sag
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the other aspects. We've got a lot of engaging technology for our customers, the digital experience, we've been able to test out a number of concepts. One of them, that particularly of interest is a partnership we have at a company called Sage, which gives nutritional transparency for items that we're selling in the store. And we're looking forward to take many of these digital experiences that we've been working on and bring them back to Whole Foods as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with just the 2 stores, every 365 will open with our new loyalty card program. Give me 10, which is 10% off key items at the 365 stores. And in just 6 weeks, we've had over 16,000 signups.
componenttext: And with just the 2 stores, every 365 will open with our new loyalty card program. Give me 10, which is 10% off key items at the 365 stores. And in just 6 weeks, we've had over 16,000 signups.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think having the -- this is Walter again, having the deadline of having that store opened really allowed to push to get that rewards program up and going and then we are able to pivot all those learnings into the broader Affinity program that we're laun
componenttext: I think having the -- this is Walter again, having the deadline of having that store opened really allowed to push to get that rewards program up and going and then we are able to pivot all those learnings into the broader Affinity program that we're launching today in Dallas. So I just think that what I've seen is the learnings that come from the store have really -- are rapidly moving through the rest of the company. And this team here has gone through the entire development pipeline as we mentioned in the script, and looked for opportunities to learn and apply in every single situation in a very vigorous manner. So a lot of excitement about what we've learned through launching this format. Thanks for the question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: One question, 2 fast parts, on 365. In terms of -- Walter, I know you mentioned that you've already had a bit of a redesign, if you could elaborate on that. And the second part is, I know, granted, it's still early, only a couple of months after the first
componenttext: One question, 2 fast parts, on 365. In terms of -- Walter, I know you mentioned that you've already had a bit of a redesign, if you could elaborate on that. And the second part is, I know, granted, it's still early, only a couple of months after the first store opening, but anything that you can see, even qualitatively, in terms of your closest core stores in that area if trends in either direction have changed?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer the second part, then David and Ken and others can pick up the first part of it. Essentially, we are tracking really closely the impact of -- we're doing several experiments in the 2 different markets to sort of understand that, and we'v
componenttext: Well, I'll answer the second part, then David and Ken and others can pick up the first part of it. Essentially, we are tracking really closely the impact of -- we're doing several experiments in the 2 different markets to sort of understand that, and we've got a pretty good handle on that. But it's too early for us to share data on what that looks like. I will say broadly that, at least my view is that, we're creating a new customer here, we're attracting a new customer. We are broadening the import and the effect of Whole Foods Market in the marketplace through these stores. We're reaching customers that we historically have not reached. That's clearly what the data shows. And so, David and Ken over to you. Do you want to answer the first part of the question?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're seeing the first 3 stores as a test and experiment, so we're kind of adjusting all the time. But the big one was that we were busier than we thought, so at Silver Lake we had capacity issues with getting customers through our register s
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're seeing the first 3 stores as a test and experiment, so we're kind of adjusting all the time. But the big one was that we were busier than we thought, so at Silver Lake we had capacity issues with getting customers through our register systems, so. And also the big factor is that the baskets were much bigger. So the kind of smaller teller-style registers that we were using were not effective for the size of the baskets we were getting. So we adjusted the design for Lake Oswego, we're going back and adjusting for Silver Lake and in all other future designs. So the great thing is with these first 3 stores, we are testing out a few product variations, a few layout variances with the idea being by the time we get to store 4 in Ohio that will be kind of completely dialed in.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one of the bigger evolutions too is our Friends of component in the Portland store is included into the overall design versus it being a separate sort of experience versus in Silver Lake, it was by CHLOE which was kind of off to the side, whereas now
componenttext: And one of the bigger evolutions too is our Friends of component in the Portland store is included into the overall design versus it being a separate sort of experience versus in Silver Lake, it was by CHLOE which was kind of off to the side, whereas now Next Level Burger is right within the concept of the store which is a great design, too, and we see that whole approach of using the Friends of concept into Whole Foods. We really think that, that's going to be a huge differentiator for us as we grow and evolve that into our Whole Foods model.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Friends of 365 and Whole Foods is a great way to introduce young entrepreneurs like CHLOE with Next Level Burger -- sorry, Next Level Burger and CHLOE, and also as the big side -- potential benefit or actual benefit of reducing our labor costs in our exis
componenttext: Friends of 365 and Whole Foods is a great way to introduce young entrepreneurs like CHLOE with Next Level Burger -- sorry, Next Level Burger and CHLOE, and also as the big side -- potential benefit or actual benefit of reducing our labor costs in our existing stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, do you want to add something, too?
componenttext: John, do you want to add something, too?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Walter. I think, we'll have a lot more to say about 365 when we get into our Q4 call in November. We're very happy with the initial start of the first couple of stores. We're very happy with the way it came out. We think we've created a very
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Walter. I think, we'll have a lot more to say about 365 when we get into our Q4 call in November. We're very happy with the initial start of the first couple of stores. We're very happy with the way it came out. We think we've created a very successful new business model which we're going to expand rapidly, and we'll have more information about that next quarter. One thing relevant is we're opening our third 365 store in Seattle area in Bellevue in September. And that's a very interesting opening for us because we don't think the cannibalization from 365 to Whole Foods Market is particularly great, because as Walter indicated, we're getting -- we think we're getting a new customer in there. But Bellevue will be a good test because we're going up against one of our flagship stores there. And where in both of our Lake Oswego in Portland and our Silver Lake store in LA area, the Whole Foods Market stores are not particularly close to it. So Bellevue is very close, so that's going to be very interesting. We'll have more information when we do our Q4 report of what kind of cannibalization impact it's going to have. So we're very excited about that. We're very excited about 365, and we look forward to better informing you as time goes on.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And by the way, just a final punctuation on that is again, once Affinity is launched, and we're actually tracking individual customers, what will be very interesting for us to see -- but we have theories now, but we'll be able to see what individual custo
componenttext: And by the way, just a final punctuation on that is again, once Affinity is launched, and we're actually tracking individual customers, what will be very interesting for us to see -- but we have theories now, but we'll be able to see what individual customers are doing. We think they'll sometimes use the 365, sometimes they'll use the Whole Foods Market. And there may be distinct groups, and I think we'll be able to answer these questions in a relatively short period of time very, very clearly. But net-net, it looks like, A, we've created a broader market for our company, for our products, our standards, our experiences, that's what the information suggests. But as John mentioned, we'll be back with a lot more specifics around that and its future in November when we're back for the Q. So thanks for the question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, the first area I wanted to start with is your expenses. We saw again another strong quarter of expense control, and if my math is right, excluding D&A, I think your expenses are close to flat or up maybe 1% year-to-date even with about 7% squa
componenttext: So I guess, the first area I wanted to start with is your expenses. We saw again another strong quarter of expense control, and if my math is right, excluding D&A, I think your expenses are close to flat or up maybe 1% year-to-date even with about 7% square footage growth. I know you're not giving guidance today, but as we look out to next year, is there any clarity you can help us provide in terms of, of the $300 million in savings, whether more of that hit this year or whether we should see my benefit in 2017?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rupesh, this is Glenda. We certainly wanted to reiterate in our remarks today that we -- that our $300 million target remains intact, but we have never put a specific time line on that. We have made measurable progress on it in 2016 with the large restruc
componenttext: Rupesh, this is Glenda. We certainly wanted to reiterate in our remarks today that we -- that our $300 million target remains intact, but we have never put a specific time line on that. We have made measurable progress on it in 2016 with the large restructuring that we did at the beginning of the year and with other initiatives that are ongoing at Whole Foods Market. So we feel good about that. The, obviously, it would be a lot easier for us to get there if we had higher sales and we didn't have this health care hurdle to overcome. But we do have a lot underway, both in the way we're doing work processes at Whole Foods, with the way technology tools are being enhanced to help us reduce labor, for example, auto-replenishment is going to be a big one when we get to that, because we have a lot of people in the stores who are buyers and we have no buyers in the 365 stores, all the inventory is automatically ordered, so that's a big one that's going to happen to -- for us at some point.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the technology also enhances the customer experience, that's the other beautiful thing. It's a 2-for-1 deal. When you make these investments, you're going to create something that the customers really enjoy experiencing, so.
componenttext: Just the technology also enhances the customer experience, that's the other beautiful thing. It's a 2-for-1 deal. When you make these investments, you're going to create something that the customers really enjoy experiencing, so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll also say -- really want to appreciate all of our team members and our regional presidents for the real hard work that they're doing on the restructuring. And they realized the competitive nature of what's happening and the need for us
componenttext: This is David. I'll also say -- really want to appreciate all of our team members and our regional presidents for the real hard work that they're doing on the restructuring. And they realized the competitive nature of what's happening and the need for us to reduce expenses, and they are all collaboratively working really hard to do it. And then all of our regional presidents have gone and seen the 365 stores and are kind of electrified by some of the labor savings and some of the structural changes that we've done there and are already starting to go back and figure out ways to put some of those pieces in place at the Whole Foods Market stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, we just have so many things we're working on to really create this transformation of the company that appreciating them for being able to help us work through so many things at the same time making our way forward. So thank you for the question.
componenttext: I'd say, we just have so many things we're working on to really create this transformation of the company that appreciating them for being able to help us work through so many things at the same time making our way forward. So thank you for the question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Shane Higgins with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Shane Higgins with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Walter, you mentioned that traffic trends in produce were actually improving a bit. Can you just elaborate on that a little bit? And just give some context around where your price investments have been focused and the kind of response that you've seen?
componenttext: Walter, you mentioned that traffic trends in produce were actually improving a bit. Can you just elaborate on that a little bit? And just give some context around where your price investments have been focused and the kind of response that you've seen?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just say quickly and then A.C. is going to give you the substance of it. Basically, yes, that's right. We've seen a positive variance to store traffic there. And I think that's directly attributed to the results we're doing in produce A.C. will
componenttext: Yes, I'll just say quickly and then A.C. is going to give you the substance of it. Basically, yes, that's right. We've seen a positive variance to store traffic there. And I think that's directly attributed to the results we're doing in produce A.C. will give you the details.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We made ongoing and significant investments in produce this year and kind of on a region-by-region basis. And we expected when we made these investments that initially, we would see a drop in sales as well as margin. But we've been slowly seeing a nice pi
componenttext: We made ongoing and significant investments in produce this year and kind of on a region-by-region basis. And we expected when we made these investments that initially, we would see a drop in sales as well as margin. But we've been slowly seeing a nice pickup in average produce items in the basket and that's helped to offset part of the investment. And we're definitely seeing a positive trend. We did a lot of investment the last 6 weeks or so with summer fruit, with cherries and blueberries and strawberries and things like that. And so really nice -- really we've moved a ton of product. And so we're seeing a nice trend in that area. In our experience, it's -- produce is an extremely competitive area. And in our experience, it's hard to turn around a trend in produce, but we feel like we really have, and we're continuing to -- we're going to continue to invest in that area and continue to see a nice pickup in items per basket.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David. I'd also say we're about 6 weeks into our national flyer, so the first time in our company's history where customers are actually seeing these produce sales across all channels, across the whole company at the same time, so we hope that, that's hav
componenttext: David. I'd also say we're about 6 weeks into our national flyer, so the first time in our company's history where customers are actually seeing these produce sales across all channels, across the whole company at the same time, so we hope that, that's having an effect as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you do have plans to add these just to make some more investments across other categories? Are you going to roll those out in the next couple of quarters? Or how should we think about that?
componenttext: And you do have plans to add these just to make some more investments across other categories? Are you going to roll those out in the next couple of quarters? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we said broadly is that we kind of gave you the goal of lowering our gross margins by 200 basis points over 2 years, and we kind of -- this is kind of sketched out a sequential decline quarter-to-quarter as we continue to make those, but we're not re
componenttext: What we said broadly is that we kind of gave you the goal of lowering our gross margins by 200 basis points over 2 years, and we kind of -- this is kind of sketched out a sequential decline quarter-to-quarter as we continue to make those, but we're not revealing any further details beyond that in terms of we're going to do what it takes to be competitive and so that's where we'll leave it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned some disinflation. Could you talk about the categories where you're seeing it? And did you see any downstep in the produce as the quarter played out?
componenttext: You mentioned some disinflation. Could you talk about the categories where you're seeing it? And did you see any downstep in the produce as the quarter played out?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.C. here. Absolutely. So I'd say, overall, we were pretty flat to slight deflation in costs this quarter. And where we saw the most deflation in terms of our retail prices were in produce, as we mentioned, that's where our biggest investments have been.
componenttext: A.C. here. Absolutely. So I'd say, overall, we were pretty flat to slight deflation in costs this quarter. And where we saw the most deflation in terms of our retail prices were in produce, as we mentioned, that's where our biggest investments have been. And meat, we saw a little bit of deflation as well, a little bit of deflation in beef costs and little deflation in our actual retail prices, mainly due to an expanded promotion strategy that we were doing. Those are the 2 biggest areas. I'd say, we've definitely seen also a little deflation in our bulk products, things like almonds and other, prices like that really dropped off the cliff, and we've lowered our prices pretty significantly in a couple of major commodities there to.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how about dairy, anything [indiscernible] going on there?
componenttext: And how about dairy, anything [indiscernible] going on there?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dairy, it varies a little bit in dairy. We know eggs are kind of in excess around the country, so egg prices are flat to deflationary. Milk prices, for us, have been fairly steady. We have -- in select markets, we have lowered milk prices in a few areas i
componenttext: Dairy, it varies a little bit in dairy. We know eggs are kind of in excess around the country, so egg prices are flat to deflationary. Milk prices, for us, have been fairly steady. We have -- in select markets, we have lowered milk prices in a few areas in select markets. So, certainly, the prices aren't going up in dairy.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then for Walter, are you having more competitive openings versus a year ago? Maybe you could talk about that because I know you talked a little bit about cannibalization, but what's going on with its competitive openings versus your base?
componenttext: And then for Walter, are you having more competitive openings versus a year ago? Maybe you could talk about that because I know you talked a little bit about cannibalization, but what's going on with its competitive openings versus your base?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well let's see, I don't know that we have those numbers. I don't know that we share them with the group here, but I would say, look, the competitive -- the shift in the marketplace around just a tremendous amount of competitors opening all around as peopl
componenttext: Well let's see, I don't know that we have those numbers. I don't know that we share them with the group here, but I would say, look, the competitive -- the shift in the marketplace around just a tremendous amount of competitors opening all around as people rushing into this space continues. I think it's -- it might be flat to slightly up in terms of the Q-to-Q thing, if I look at -- if I remember the numbers correctly. So, I think, your -- let's see here, we just saw the numbers. I'd say, it's up slightly. Up slightly this quarter in terms of the competitive impact and the cannibalization effects down slightly. Perhaps those are -- I mean, it's just -- it's very, very competitive out there right now, and as A.C. mentioned, there is deflation in a number of categories that you're working headwinds. And in addition to that, we're pushing aggressively into our value efforts, so all those things create the sort of combination that, I think, brings us the results.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I can also say, it's actually been a lot of fun and really exciting to open our 365 stores against all of our competitors. So it's definitely a very exciting time.
componenttext: David, I can also say, it's actually been a lot of fun and really exciting to open our 365 stores against all of our competitors. So it's definitely a very exciting time.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's also exciting like in Chicago, to start cycling over, we opened 7 stores last year in that metro. And then this year, we're coming back around and cycling on those and it's wonderful to see those things really start to bloom. So -- but generall
componenttext: Well, it's also exciting like in Chicago, to start cycling over, we opened 7 stores last year in that metro. And then this year, we're coming back around and cycling on those and it's wonderful to see those things really start to bloom. So -- but generally, it remains a very, very competitive market out there. I wonder at some point whether some of them will rationalize and close as we saw happen with at least one of the competitors in the last number of months. But that's the world we're in and customers have lots of choices, and we're sharing with you kind our thoughts about how we continue to push Whole Foods Market forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean lapping out of cannibalization is certainly helping your year agos, but your -- you had some significant drops in your year ago comparisons and the 2-year stack is now negative. Do you think that's mostly just the price investments coming through,
componenttext: I mean lapping out of cannibalization is certainly helping your year agos, but your -- you had some significant drops in your year ago comparisons and the 2-year stack is now negative. Do you think that's mostly just the price investments coming through, or what do you think is the primary factor for the 2-year stack going down?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, do you want to get that one?
componenttext: John, do you want to get that one?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a number of factors. Certainly the cannibalization remains a factor, but that's possibly slightly lessening as we anniversary some of the Chicago openings. Yes, competition, I mean, it's not a big secret, is it? There's a lot more competitors i
componenttext: Well, it's a number of factors. Certainly the cannibalization remains a factor, but that's possibly slightly lessening as we anniversary some of the Chicago openings. Yes, competition, I mean, it's not a big secret, is it? There's a lot more competitors in the marketplace, and there's a lot of new formats in the marketplace from home meal replacement through meal kits, fast casual restaurant growth, more entrants in the natural and organic food space, mainstream -- mainstreaming of natural and organic which has been well reported. These are all factors. Whole Foods Market being the leader, having very high sales per square foot. We probably feel the brunt of it as there's a bit of a regression to the mean as we lose customers from a convenience standpoint. People don't drive as far as they used to drive because good enough, there's good enough alternatives, in many cases, close by to them. They may not -- so people may not be driving as frequently as far as they used to because they can stop by a Kroger or an HEB or a Wegmans where -- to get products that they can -- used to only be able to get at Whole Foods, now there's some overlap in our product base in other competitors. So I mean, I think there's no sense of denying it. Competition is bigger, and we're responding to it as, we think, an intelligent, measured way. And we still remain very bullish about our future prospects.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did mention in the script, again, got a nice little tailwind of 100 and some-odd basis points over the 9 weeks, which we hope to see if we can take advantage of. But we'll see how it all goes. So...
componenttext: We did mention in the script, again, got a nice little tailwind of 100 and some-odd basis points over the 9 weeks, which we hope to see if we can take advantage of. But we'll see how it all goes. So...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, one thing is probably, it continues to be underreported, is we keep opening a lot of great stores. Just yesterday, we opened up 2 flagship stores, that are -- I mean, we're just kicking butt. They're just amazing stores, they're awesome stores. Th
componenttext: I mean, one thing is probably, it continues to be underreported, is we keep opening a lot of great stores. Just yesterday, we opened up 2 flagship stores, that are -- I mean, we're just kicking butt. They're just amazing stores, they're awesome stores. They are doing huge sales. And they're going to be very profitable for us.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, that's in Brooklyn and Santa Clara, California, the 2 flagship stores I was mentioning. So thank you for the question.
componenttext: Again, that's in Brooklyn and Santa Clara, California, the 2 flagship stores I was mentioning. So thank you for the question.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the July 4th answer you gave, I wasn't quite sure what you said. Or did I completely make that up?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The impact on both Q3 and Q4 of the July 4th shift was completely insignificant.

So we did not reiterate our prior '16 targets, but we did give specific guidance for the quarter.

componenttext: I'll start and then Jason can add on. Well, the partnership with Nielsen is going to give us a tremendous amount of consumer data that we haven't had before. As we move into doing more globally managed, category management in our stores, we really need this consumer information in order to properly set up the categories and know where to do our promotions and know how to price the different categories. So that's a lot of information that we haven't had. Mostly what we've had is our own information so we're looking at ourselves and this allows us to look much more carefully at the whole industry, all our competitors and what we need to do to be more competitive.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth and Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K.
In addition, our remarks today include references to non-GAAP measures. For a reconciliation of our non-GAAP measures to GAAP figures, please see the tables in our earnings release. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q4, sales increased 2% to a record $3.5 billion. We opened 5 new stores, including 2 365 stores. We continue to make selective investments on key items to narrow pricing gaps while offering strong weekly deal
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q4, sales increased 2% to a record $3.5 billion. We opened 5 new stores, including 2 365 stores. We continue to make selective investments on key items to narrow pricing gaps while offering strong weekly deals, which were supported by the continuation of our enhanced ad campaign.
We also successfully launched our new affinity Rewards programs in the Dallas/Fort Worth metro area. In a heightened competitive and promotional environment, we have remained focused on our initiatives to build sales over the long term and are seeing encouraging signs of customers responding, as reflected in our third consecutive quarter of improving items per basket.
As our value, personalization and marketing efforts gain traction and new sales-building initiatives roll out throughout the year, we expect our traffic trends to improve as well. In a challenging operating environment, we maintained our expense disciplines, delivering 8% EBITDA margin, $0.28 in earnings per share and $352 million in operating cash flow.
As highlighted in our press release, we have made measurable progress this year on our 9-point plan to position Whole Foods Market for continued success in an increasingly competitive marketplace. This includes one of our most important initiatives, which is to reduce expenses by a $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017.
We are pleased to report that as of year-end, we are more than 50% of the way toward our goal. The biggest reductions to date have been achieved through various labor-saving measures, including evolving our marketing and HR functions from a store to a metro model; reducing buying positions as we transform our purchasing operations; and combining certain store teams, such as meat and seafood, in lower-volume stores.
Many of these efforts allow us to focus our store labor investments where they are most needed, ensuring product availability, maintaining high standards and serving our customers. In addition to labor and benefits savings, we significantly reduced our supplies and packaging expense through a more consolidated purchasing program across regions. 
Another major accomplishment was the launch of our new value format, 365 by Whole Foods Market. We're using the learnings from our first 3 stores to shape and evolve our next round of 365 openings, and we're excited about the opportunities this streamlined operating model presents for our existing and future Whole Foods Market stores as well. 
We're also pleased to share that our unified point-of-sale system, including EMV technology, is now up and running across all of our U.S. stores. This was a significant undertaking involving the conversion of more than 6,200 checkout lanes. This system provides the foundation to enhance our promotional capabilities, including more dynamic and personalized offers through our mobile app and Rewards programs.
As we evolve our business model, our commitment to our core values, mission and culture has never been stronger, and we appreciate our team members for continuing to deliver a world-class shopping experience to our customers. In a year that presented many ongoing headwinds for food retailers, including deflation, increased competition from existing as well as new business models, and lackluster consumer demand, we produced industry-leading sales per square foot of $915 and a healthy 13% return on invested capital.
While sales were lighter than forecast, we achieved many of the fiscal year targets we provided in Q4 last year, including $1.52 in earnings per share, excluding buybacks and an 8.6% EBITDA margin. We produced more than $1.1 billion of operating cash flow and invested $716 million of capital, primarily in new and existing stores and technology initiatives, resulting in $400 million of free cash flow. And in keeping with our capital allocation strategy, we returned more than $1.1 billion to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
Turning to our outlook for fiscal year 2017. We expect sales growth of 2.5% to 4.5% and earnings per share, excluding potential future buybacks of $1.42 or greater. Our priorities include progressing to an always on unified marketing and media plan, using insights from our customer data and analytics to improve the relevancy, effectiveness and efficiency of our value and marketing investments; intensifying our personalization efforts, including the rollout of our optimized Rewards program to all U.S. stores; taking a more strategic approach to our assortments, pricing and promotions, including the continued development of category management tools, processes and capabilities to better inform our investments; evolving our purchasing structure to a hybrid model with global teams leading our category management efforts and regional teams focused on local products; leveraging our new culinary team's leadership and expertise to offer full spectrum of the highest quality, ready-made meal solutions, in-store or delivered to your door, including a pilot for curated meal kits; and offering our customers more convenience through expanded online delivery to more cities and additional ZIP Codes in existing markets.
So far in Q1, we have relocated our Center City Philadelphia store, which had the second-highest opening sales week in our company's history. And opened our first store in El Paso, Texas, which garnered significant media attention across Mexico and is doing twice its projected sales volume. Our new stores, on average, continue to be profitable in year 1, and we have many other exciting openings this year, including Bryant Park in New York City in January and Lakeview, Chicago this spring. At the same time, we believe it is prudent in this challenging retail environment to continue to moderate our lease signings, ending square footage growth and capital expenditures as a percentage of sales.
We have seen stability in comps over the last 2 quarters and an improvement in trends quarter-to-date for both traffic and basket size. We are encouraged that our value and marketing efforts appear to be gaining traction with customers and believe we will see momentum as our sales building initiatives are rolled out throughout the year. The competitive landscape is very dynamic, however, and it is uncertain how long the deflationary environment will continue. The high end of our 2% -- negative 2% to flat comp range reflects a negative 2.5% 2-year comp, slightly better than Q4's negative 2.8%, while the low end reflects the possibility that 2-year trends could get marginally worse before they get better, as we have seen quarter-to-date.
As we have stated, our strategy is to adjust our operating model to a lower margin and lower cost structure. Every major conversation we have about investments in pricing, technology and marketing is accompanied by a conversation about lowering our cost structure to enhanced technology tools, labor restructuring and work process changes. Last November, we announced our goal to reduce our cost structure by $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017. We expect to reach our goal but expect these savings to be more than offset by our investments to drive traffic and sales as well as higher occupancy, depreciation and other costs. Therefore, we expect a decline in operating margin of up to 60 basis points for the year, with greater declines in the first half, primarily related to higher year-over-year preopening expense in the first quarter and marketing expense in the first and second quarters. Please see our press release for more detailed guidance.
In closing, food retail is evolving at an incredibly fast pace and consumers have many more options for how and where they buy their food than ever before. At the same time, the market opportunity is expanding as the consciousness about fresh, healthy foods continues to awaken. Our company mission, commitment to transparency and a culture of innovation are more relevant and timely than ever. And where our company is today is just a shadow of where we think it will be in the future.
We sell the highest quality food in the world. Our standards lead the industry. And no one delivers the dynamic and compelling in-store experience that we do. We continue to see strong customer reception to our brand in new and existing markets as evidenced by recent openings. Our stores are highly profitable, with only 7 out of 456 stores at year-end not producing positive EBITDA before rent. 
We will keep innovating and creating opportunities for people to connect and find a sense of community in our stores and in the digital world. Promotions and price investments are an integral part of our conversation but we are not participating in a race to the bottom. Our strategy revolves around leading a race to the top in terms of the differentiated customer experience: continuing to raise the bar on our quality standards and selection, providing new levels of transparency and accountability and leveraging technology to deliver an improved shopping experience.
We believe we have the right strategies in place to position the company to produce strong results and returns for our shareholders over the long term. In a separate release today, we announced some coming structural and leadership changes. I want to take the opportunity to acknowledge and appreciate both Walter and Glenda for their many years of partnership and service to the company.
The significance of their countless contributions cannot be overstated. And we are grateful that both will continue to be involved in shaping our future.
We'll now take questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Just curious, I mean, obviously with Walter and Glenda departing, that must have been a very tough decision for you and -- I mean for the company, but maybe any color on that in general? And then what thoughts are related to CFO search? And then if there's any thought -- John, I'm assuming, you will be taking over the CEO [ph] role. So just a little color there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Glenda. I'll go first. For me, I've been with Whole Foods or I would have been with Whole Foods 29 years next year when I retire, I'll turn 63 this year, so that's almost half my life. It just feels like time for me and excited about the opportuni
componenttext: This is Glenda. I'll go first. For me, I've been with Whole Foods or I would have been with Whole Foods 29 years next year when I retire, I'll turn 63 this year, so that's almost half my life. It just feels like time for me and excited about the opportunity to be here and assist with the thorough search for a new CFO and have plenty of time for a smooth transition. So we will probably start the search process sometime in January.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter, and about the [ph] earnings -- I would say I have also been here a few years, and I think we have -- life is not a straight line. But I think we have, as a team, John and I and the team here that's around the table, we have really worked h
componenttext: This is Walter, and about the [ph] earnings -- I would say I have also been here a few years, and I think we have -- life is not a straight line. But I think we have, as a team, John and I and the team here that's around the table, we have really worked hard the last year or 2, work through kind of the changes of the environment, the structural changes in retail. And I think you all know, we have -- we've gone here, we've gone there, trying to figure out exactly the right places to land. I think you can see on the coherence of the script today how [ph] it's really come together in a very thoughtful and strategic manner in terms of how we go forward, and we have a very optimistic view this coming year, and I think the board has decided, of course, John and I are on the board, that moving to a more streamlined structure is the right thing at this juncture to lead the company forward to the next level, and I will be here to continue to cheer that on, and I think that's where we are.

componenttext: I like to just dig to your commentary around value and marketing efforts beginning to gain traction and as it relates to basket and traffic. So your basket growth, it's fairly [ph] encouraging actually particularly against deflation, price investments. So what is the best [ph], I guess, saying, about your most loyal customers and the recognition for the work that you're doing in the store? But then on the other side of that, traffic is still an issue. And what are your thoughts around why that's lagging? And then as it relates to that, Q1, it sounds like you talked about traffic getting better. I assumed that means that traffic quarter-to-date is better than a 4.2 in Q4.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Walter. I'll take a couple of cracks, there's a lot of questions in there. But the first one is on the basket. What's really -- yes, you did a good job on there. The first one that's really exciting looking at these results is if you look acros
componenttext: So this is Walter. I'll take a couple of cracks, there's a lot of questions in there. But the first one is on the basket. What's really -- yes, you did a good job on there. The first one that's really exciting looking at these results is if you look across the Quantel [ph] data for the baskets, every single basket was moving up. And so what that says is that there's some real stability here. And particularly in the $100 basket, it's showing some nice growth, showing that our most loyal customers are continuing to shop with us. And the cool thing about the data and analytics we have now is we can actually look into that $100 basket, and we know what the drivers are in there. And we've got that to build on. Look, with respect to the -- and that's a capability we never really had before. With respect to the trips, I mean, it's -- clearly, this is a challenged environment for retail in general and trips, but actually in this queue, we saw in the time period, we've seen an improvement. We've seen it. It's still not where we want it, but it has improved sequentially. And I think that we've always said we got to go items first and from items we go to trips. And I think we're going to come on strong with the marketing investments issue that I think you're going to be pleased to see with our new leaders, Sonia [ph], that's the obelisk [ph]. And we're going to really worked hard to go right after those trips. So I think items lead first, and from then -- and then comes the trips.

componenttext: So on the 365 stores, I just want to get an update in terms of how those are performing aggregate versus your expectations? And any early read on cannibalization with your Bellevue location?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. So cannibalization is lower in Bellevue than we had anticipated. So we see the customers are seeing on this [ph] as 2 separate choices and -- or shopping at both. So the Bellevue Whole Foods is doing better than we expected with that. Still
componenttext: This is David. So cannibalization is lower in Bellevue than we had anticipated. So we see the customers are seeing on this [ph] as 2 separate choices and -- or shopping at both. So the Bellevue Whole Foods is doing better than we expected with that. Still early days for both our stores so we opened Silver Lake 6 or 7 months ago but then we, with Bellevue and Lake Oswego, it's early days 8 to 12 weeks. [ph] So still pretty early in the learning cycle but we're very excited about what we've seen so far. We've kind of built in a pause in the development cycle here until we open the next store in the spring in Austin. So we're learning from the data that we received from the customer shopping in the store and we're making adjustments and tweaks, and really trying to make sure we perfect 365 before we really hit the gas on new store opening.

componenttext: This is David. Just a couple of things, we're again pointing back to 365. 365 is to the first area we're doing an auto replenishment. So in other words, we automatic orders, less labor to actually do orders in the stores. So we're learning from that process and we've started a few tests of category management in a few different regions and again, video results are good so we think that's really on long-run real cost savings there. And then on the regional presidents are working very hard on the combination teams, as John said in the script. you talked about meat and seafood but we're also combining a lot of teams. So we're seeing reductions in labor at the store level as we kind of work array through those. So still a lot of runway there as well.

componenttext: This is Jason. As you know, we went live about 14 weeks ago in Dallas with our enhanced Affinity rewards program. And so I think unless we open you will see [indiscernible] we're opening a next store in Austin, so home-based store. And when do we expect that might open, David?

componenttext: We think we're going to -- we'll have more data at that time, of course, on our 3 existing stores, a little color, I would say though is that the labor hours that we projected for all 3 stores we're able to operate the stores at those labor hours and so we think as we grow, that was not a surprise we're able to do that. componenttextpreview: This is Walter. I just want to reinforce something to consider, this is an and, not a whole for Whole Foods and part of what has helped us is to stay true to the $300 millon run rate and improve our results has been the learnings in the 365. Tremendous fu
componenttext: This is Walter. I just want to reinforce something to consider, this is an and, not a whole for Whole Foods and part of what has helped us is to stay true to the $300 millon run rate and improve our results has been the learnings in the 365. Tremendous future in laboratory for us to explore more automation, to explore new labor schedules, new labor combinations, JE and his team had done a fantastic job. So the FX of 365 go well beyond just the 3 stores that are opened so far for.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tom for Ken. I was looking to get a bit of clarity around your price investments. The press release makes reference to the deflationary environment yet you also note that the average price per item was flat year-over-year. Should we interpret this to
componenttext: It's Tom for Ken. I was looking to get a bit of clarity around your price investments. The press release makes reference to the deflationary environment yet you also note that the average price per item was flat year-over-year. Should we interpret this to mean that input costs were down by more than prices? Or given your mix difference, it was the deflation, in some categories, more than offset by inflation and others?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is A.C. Yes, I would say that overall, costs were -- costs and retails were pretty flat. We did see, in cost, in early in the quarter, we were definitely seeing some deflation. As the quarter went on, it moderated and we actually saw an uptick in cer
componenttext: This is A.C. Yes, I would say that overall, costs were -- costs and retails were pretty flat. We did see, in cost, in early in the quarter, we were definitely seeing some deflation. As the quarter went on, it moderated and we actually saw an uptick in certain categories like our salmon which is a very big part of our seafood sales, so a dramatic increase towards the end of the quarter. And a couple of produce items, specifically avocados, through the big disruption in Mexico when we started to see an increase in there too. So I would say, overall, it was fairly balanced. And one thing to remember to, with us is that, when should an commodity products really dropped down, it doesn't affect us as much. So for instance, there's been a large decrease in the commodity eggs this year but those aren't the eggs we sell. Our eggs are all raised under contract to our quality standards by our producers who produce them based on cost to produce. So we're not as affected as much as the big commodity swings with the products that we sell. So I'd say, overall, things were pretty flat for us in the quarter.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like what I was saying earlier, and we've said in the script, it's not a race to the bottom that we're going to -- Whole Foods is always going to be about delivering the best quality of food and experience to our customers. So when other people might be p
componenttext:
Like what I was saying earlier, and we've said in the script, it's not a race to the bottom that we're going to -- Whole Foods is always going to be about delivering the best quality of food and experience to our customers. So when other people might be promoting certain commodity, commodity pricing, we're going to continue to maintain our standards and promote our higher-quality products. We did in the beginning -- in the summertime, we find the last, and I think this is true for a lot of retailers, the latter part of the summer is a slower period for us and we found that promotions during that period don't have as much of an impact as if they do, once you get past mid-July, promotions will have a stronger impact. So we have a lot of promotions early in the quarter, especially in our perishable areas and then as we got to later in the quarter, especially going into late July and August, we did a little less promotions but we started to pick that back up now and we're moving into a -- as we move into the holiday period, we've got some really.
[Audio Gap]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I would mention too, they're a great national global team of purchasing, we're doing more common promotions. So for the first time, for Thanksgiving, we're doing a direct mail piece that is going out. We're dropping to 12 million households arou
componenttext: One thing I would mention too, they're a great national global team of purchasing, we're doing more common promotions. So for the first time, for Thanksgiving, we're doing a direct mail piece that is going out. We're dropping to 12 million households around our Thanksgiving promotion. This is a common set of promotions across all stores. So first time we've ever done that show really kind of exciting about that for Thanksgiving and then doing a similar process for both Christmas and New Year's resolution.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. I just think what A.C. said is so important to really land here. We're going to be price program. We've been told about that for a couple of years about truing up onto the market that's changing and being competitive and being -- we learne
componenttext: This is Walter. I just think what A.C. said is so important to really land here. We're going to be price program. We've been told about that for a couple of years about truing up onto the market that's changing and being competitive and being -- we learned to be more selective and careful and really analytic where that needs to happen and I think you're starting to see some of the green shoots from that effort. But what AC is also saying is a truly important, we figured out more probably our strategy, our go-to-market as a company, is we're a quality-first company and that's why we are also investing in the marketing this year to really let people know remember, what's great about this company and with the products that we sell and the environment we created and the the team members that we have and just hammer hone the fact. That is where we win as a company. That's how we do it. So that's the other important part of the answer to go along with the pricing and price investments.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just add on, this is Jason, we've had some significant focus on some of our digital marketing and promotions. As we previously mentioned, we got about 5 million subscribers in our CRM databases which allow us to push out the promotions through e-mail. And
componenttext: Just add on, this is Jason, we've had some significant focus on some of our digital marketing and promotions. As we previously mentioned, we got about 5 million subscribers in our CRM databases which allow us to push out the promotions through e-mail. And we've seen a lot of uptake in that particular space. So we'll be doing a number of offers throughout the holiday period there. While also continuing to add more digital coupons and I'm seeing a lot of traction in that space. It's really, as we call the 4, sort of our Affinity light the sort of precursor to our rewards program so more offers are going in there. And this really allows us to have the ability to target offers as well as learn better around the behaviors of what's driving folks into stores and making sure that we're giving offers that are relevant for our customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One last thing, John here. Going forward, a lot of our price investments we're going to make, we want to tied very closely to our category management strategy. I think we made some price investments that we didn't -- that weren't as data-driven ürgen as
componenttext: One last thing, John here. Going forward, a lot of our price investments we're going to make, we want to tied very closely to our category management strategy. I think we made some price investments that we didn't -- that weren't as data-driven ürgen as it needed to be. And you've learned a lot of lessons from that. And now, as we begin to roll out category management, we're going to relate high the future price investments into the overall category management strategy. So I think that's important for people to understand.

componenttext: This is Kenneth, we can talk about the customer inside. So our process, we are bringing that into our look every week and every period in terms of similar process when we look at sales comps as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Kelly, A.C. here. As John just mentioned a few minutes ago, we want to be a lot more strategic with our price investments. We realized 2 things over this past year. One is that our customers really are mostly -- the most important thing for us is to m
componenttext: Hi, Kelly, A.C. here. As John just mentioned a few minutes ago, we want to be a lot more strategic with our price investments. We realized 2 things over this past year. One is that our customers really are mostly -- the most important thing for us is to maintain quality both in our products and our experience. So it's very clear that we're not going to lower our quality in order to get lower pricing. The second thing that we realized is that we do a lot better with our promotional activity than just lowering regular pricing. So we have maintained our -- as I said earlier, we're going to continue to really push our promotional activity. And then the third thing is really tying our price investments to category management. We were absolutely committed to continuing to invest in prices but in a much more strategic way, we found through category management especially now that we have a Nielsen data to use along with it and we can make a much more effective price investments if we do it through that strategy.

componenttext: Yes, maybe a little bit.
